abstract: WILL the forces of globalism continue to push the world toward American-style capitalism?    As the 21st century begins, advocates of the free market have no doubt that they have won the economic argument. Socialism is dead. Moreover, as a means of creating wealth and material progress, American capitalism seems to be clearly superior to the Asian variety, with its greater level of government planning, or the European version, with its emphasis on social welfare and protection of workers from losing their jobs.
lead_paragraph: WILL the forces of globalism continue to push the world toward American-style capitalism?

abstract: Judge D Irvin Couvillion rules that Burton W Kanter, one of nation's most prominent tax lawyers, was 'architect' of long-running kickback and tax-evasion scheme in which money was siphoned from funds managed by Prudential and Travelers insurance companies; concludes that Internal Revenue Service overwhelmingly proved its civil fraud case against Kanter; Tax Court holds that $13 million in kickbacks were paid from 1972 through 1988 by four developers and another man to Claude Ballard and Robert Lisle, who were senior executives with Prudential overseeing its real estate investments; court says Ballard and Lisle then steered financing and contracts to developers, and gave 10 percent of kickbacks to Kanter; says kickbacks were funneled to 'sham' companies that Kanter controlled; Kanter denies any wrongdoing and says he will appeal; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: A Tax Court judge has ruled that one of the nation's most prominent tax lawyers, Burton W. Kanter of Chicago, was ''the architect'' of a long-running kickback and tax-evasion scheme in which money was siphoned from funds managed by the Prudential and Travelers insurance companies.

abstract: Akihiro Takahashi, 68, vividly recalls atomic bombing of Hiroshima, even if most Japanese say 1995 Kobe earthquake was the century's most significant event; 18-year-old Ayako Matsushima worries about Japan's ability to compete in new century, but welcomes gains made by women in work force; photos; chronology of Japanese history since 1931 (M)
snippet: Akihiro Takahashi, 68, vividly recalls atomic bombing of Hiroshima, even if most Japanese say 1995 Kobe earthquake was the century's most significant event; 18-year-old Ayako Matsushima worries about Japan's ability to compete in new century, but ...
lead_paragraph: Akihiro Takahashi had noticed the American bombers flying high in the bright sky overhead. Then came the terrible blast. For this 68-year-old former director of the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum, the clouds from the bombing still hover starkly over Japan, even if recent polls show that the 1995 Kobe earthquake is cited by more people as the century's most significant event.

abstract: Scientists at IBM's Almaden Research Center in California are pushing the frontiers of computation; Isaac Chuang, a physicist, is working on a quantum computer; a conventional computer stores and retrieves information represented as ones and zeros, while a quantum computer simultaneously computes upon a potentially vast number of pieces of information in the space of the same one or zero; photo (M)
snippet: Scientists at IBM's Almaden Research Center in California are pushing the frontiers of computation; Isaac Chuang, a physicist, is working on a quantum computer; a conventional computer stores and retrieves information represented as ones and zeros...
lead_paragraph: ISAAC CHUANG has built a machine that may one day leave the world's fastest supercomputers behind, but just now the thing is busy helping its master perform a little magic. Mr. Chuang holds out a paper clip in his cupped hand, and the clip instantly suspends itself in thin air, trapped in a force field generated by the weird device five feet away -- a quantum computer.

abstract: Arts & Ideas look ahead at works-in-progress; Prof Sarah B Pomeroy discusses her study of women in ancient Sparta, usually believed to have been as grim as their menfolk; Pomeroy says Sparta actually was one of few Greek states to educate their women, who drank wine and were famous for their beauty (S)
snippet: Arts & Ideas look ahead at works-in-progress; Prof Sarah B Pomeroy discusses her study of women in ancient Sparta, usually believed to have been as grim as their menfolk; Pomeroy says Sparta actually was one of few Greek states to educate their wo...
lead_paragraph: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

abstract: Enriqueta Marquez Martinez, 73, tells of poverty in Mexico and her family's frequent resort to United States, where three of her 10 children have settled permanently but where she herself could never live for long; Sandra Munoz Marquez, her 24-year-old American-born niece, is happy to have been brought up in Mexico and to have an American passport; photos; chronology of Mexican history since 1911 (M)
snippet: Enriqueta Marquez Martinez, 73, tells of poverty in Mexico and her family's frequent resort to United States, where three of her 10 children have settled permanently but where she herself could never live for long; Sandra Munoz Marquez, her 24-yea...
lead_paragraph: The spare farmsteads and bony milk cows of San Jose de Olivares, a desert plateau in central Mexico, are maintained by women and older people. Enriqueta Marquez Martinez, 73, was born there. She has lived much of her life in absolute poverty, never knowing whether there would be food for the next family meal. All of her 10 children went at one time or another to work in the United States, and three settled there permanently. Eventually, when she was in her 60's, Mrs. Marquez also began to travel to the United States.

abstract: The last day of the 1900's arrived like any other at the foot of International Bridge No. 1: old women and cowboys, teenagers and tourists, all of them and thousands of others crossed back and forth from Mexico as if the notion of two countries were mostly an inconvenience not of their making.    ''It's like it was one city,'' said Terry Medinilla, a salesman at El Porvenir, a clothing store that depends on customers walking across the bridge from Mexico. ''We can't be without them, and they can't be without us.''

abstract: Robin Finn article says physical malformations and other ill effects of dog breeding should serve as warning to those eager to improve human species through genetic engineering; photo (M)

abstract: It was late afternoon in Hoboken, N.J. He was wearing a plastic, cobalt-colored top hat advertising ''Millennium 2000.'' She was donning a pair of plastic, glow-in-the-dark glasses proclaiming ''2000.'' And together, Jeff and Stacy Vitale looked like they were primed for a party for the ages tonight.    Their destination? Not Times Square, since they had worked all day in Midtown Manhattan, buying the millennial gear along the way.

abstract: Cohoes Bancorp Inc says it set one-year repurchase program for 10 percent of its common stock; buyback is company's third in last six months (S)
snippet: Cohoes Bancorp Inc says it set one-year repurchase program for 10 percent of its common stock; buyback is company's third in last six months (S)
lead_paragraph: Cohoes Bancorp Inc., an upstate New York bank with 21 branches, said yesterday that it had set a one-year repurchase program for about 10 percent of its common stock. The company, the parent of Cohoes Savings Bank, would pay about $9.1 million for the shares based on yesterday's closing price of $10.0625, up 31.25 cents. The buyback is the company's third in the last six months. The company had about nine million common shares outstanding as of Nov. 1, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.

abstract: Ugly Duckling Corp, used car dealer, says it has sold its Cygnet Dealer finance unit to its chairman and principal shareholder, Ernest Garcia, for $17.5 million in cash, $12 million promissory note and assumption of $8 million in debt (S)
snippet: Ugly Duckling Corp, used car dealer, says it has sold its Cygnet Dealer finance unit to its chairman and principal shareholder, Ernest Garcia, for $17.5 million in cash, $12 million promissory note and assumption of $8 million in debt (S)
lead_paragraph: The Ugly Duckling Corporation, a used car dealer that sells to people with troubled credit histories, said yesterday that it had sold its Cygnet Dealer Finance unit to the company's chairman for about $37.5 million in cash and debt. The company, which is based in Phoenix, said an entity controlled by its chairman and principal shareholder, Ernest Garcia, had bought the unit, which provides financing for small, independent dealers. The transaction consisted of $17.5 million in cash, a $12 million 10-year promissory note backed by Verde Investments Inc. and the assumption of $8 million in debt owed to Verde. Ugly Duckling said it wanted to focus on its used-car dealerships.

abstract: Although it had seen many huge crowds over the years, for inaugurations, Fourth of July fireworks, protests and parades, never in memory had the Mall in the nation's capital drawn multitudes for New Year's. But on this mild winter night with a lovely sunset, hundreds of thousands of people here thronged to the Mall for a long-planned celebration on the last New Year's Eve of the 1900's.    ''It's a very friendly crowd,'' Sgt. Frank R. Onolfi of the United States Park Police said as afternoon turned to evening.
lead_paragraph: Although it had seen many huge crowds over the years, for inaugurations, Fourth of July fireworks, protests and parades, never in memory had the Mall in the nation's capital drawn multitudes for New Year's. abstract: Pentecostal movement, which was born in Los Angeles in 1906, has caught on among half a billion people and is likely to continue growing in next century because it is well suited to a world of continual change, of immigration and refugees, of people adrift and yearing for a bit of respect and a sign of hope from God; photos (M)

lead_paragraph: THE Pentecostal movement was born in Los Angeles in 1906 on forlorn Azusa Street, inside an abandoned church previously used as a stable and still reeking of horses. Led by a half-blind black preacher from Louisiana named William J. Seymour, a band of whites, blacks and Hispanics defied the strictures of segregated worship, gathered together and prayed for a sign from the Holy Spirit.

abstract: Elliot L Richardson, who refused Pres Richard M Nixon's order to fire special Watergate prosecutor, dies at age of 79; he served in wide variety of positions in both Massachusetts and in federal government, but he will be best remembered as Nixon's attorney general, who resigned rather than dismiss Archibald M Cox; after Richardson resigned, his second-in-command, William D Ruckelshaus, was fired after also refusing to fire Cox; those events became known as Saturday Night Massacre; Robert H Bork, then solicitor general, accepted assignment and fired Cox; photos (M)
snippet: Elliot L Richardson, who refused Pres Richard M Nixon's order to fire special Watergate prosecutor, dies at age of 79; he served in wide variety of positions in both Massachusetts and in federal government, but he will be best remembered as Nixon'...
lead_paragraph: Elliot L. Richardson, the archetype of the cultivated New England Brahmin who served in an astonishingly broad range of high public positions, and who was best known for his refusal during Watergate to obey President Richard M. Nixon's order to fire a special prosecutor, died yesterday in his native Massachusetts. He was 79.

abstract: In a rainbow blizzard of confetti and a symphony of neon and fireworks, a mighty crush of New Year's merrymakers welcomed the year 2000 in Times Square, the world's most famous intersection.    Undeterred by fears of terrorism or Y2K havoc, the Times Square crowd showed every sign of being the biggest and noisiest ever, bent on watching history happen, watching themselves on huge video screens and hoping that friends and relatives were watching them on television at home.
lead_paragraph: In a rainbow blizzard of confetti and a symphony of neon and fireworks, a mighty crush of New Year's merrymakers welcomed the year 2000 in Times Square, the world's most famous intersection.

abstract: The pastel sky over the Bay of Fundy darkened from peach glow to dim lavender. Taps sounded; the flag descended; and there came the soft thunder of a muffled stampede: hearty applause from more than 300 pairs of gloved and mittened hands.     That is how, at 3:57 p.m. today, this easternmost town in the continental United States bade farewell to the last day of the 1990's, with a bone-chilling ceremony at the candy-cane-striped lighthouse at West Quoddy Head, the easternmost point of this easternmost town. A children's chorus did its tentative best, politicians spoke, and everybody went home for hot chocolate.
lead_paragraph: The pastel sky over the Bay of Fundy darkened from peach glow to dim lavender. Taps sounded; the flag descended; and there came the soft thunder of a muffled stampede: hearty applause from more than 300 pairs of gloved and mittened hands.

abstract: Hollywood, the semi-real place that helped the 20th century  shape so much of its own image, bid it farewell tonight with a citywide spectacular of song and showmanship, kitsch and multiculturalism grandly intended to herald the emerging Los Angeles of the next millennium.    Perhaps inevitably, the icon of choice was not a microchip, a container ship, a freeway or even a digital video camera, but the hoariest symbol of local self-promotion: the HOLLYWOOD sign.
lead_paragraph: Hollywood, the semi-real place that helped the 20th century shape so much of its own image, bid it farewell tonight with a citywide spectacular of song and showmanship, kitsch and multiculturalism grandly intended to herald the emerging Los Angeles of the next millennium.

abstract: Edward Rothstein article says struggle between modernity--the Englightment's idea of shared humanity and universal principles--and identity--the force that dissents from the universal--will cast its shadow into 21st century; drawing (M)
snippet: Edward Rothstein article says struggle between modernity--the Englightment's idea of shared humanity and universal principles--and identity--the force that dissents from the universal--will cast its shadow into 21st century; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: EACH day, in the courtyard of the nation's most secure federal prison in Florence, Colo., a strange convocation takes place. Three men stand in isolated mesh cages and talk for an hour. One prosecutor has called it ''the oddest kaffeeklatsch in the history of Western civilization.'' Its members are Timothy J. McVeigh, who bombed the federal office building in Oklahoma City; Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomer; and Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the mastermind of the World Trade Center bombing. And recently, a place was reserved for Luis Felipe, the leader of the violent Latin Kings gang in New York, who arranged three murders from his prison cell.

abstract: Unita Blackwell, 66, recalls her involvement with civil rights movement in South; Marcus Moore, a biracial 19-year-old and editor in chief of Emory University's black student magazine, says that civil rights movement seems distant to him and that race relations will improve once the icons of hard-core segregation, like George Wallace, are all gone; photos; chronology of events in civil rights movement (M)
snippet: Unita Blackwell, 66, recalls her involvement with civil rights movement in South; Marcus Moore, a biracial 19-year-old and editor in chief of Emory University's black student magazine, says that civil rights movement seems distant to him and that ...
lead_paragraph: Those who risked their lives for the civil rights movement, like Unita Blackwell, did so to prevent the next generations from having to do the same, a dream largely realized. Ms. Blackwell, 66, the daughter of Mississippi sharecroppers, was regularly attacked and arrested while trying to register black voters, and helped found the Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party, an alternative to the all-white regular Democrats. She also created several education and housing programs in the state, and in 1976 became mayor of the Delta hamlet of Mayersville (population: 500), which she helped incorporate; it is a position she still holds. Her generation's work seems distant to Marcus Moore, the 20-year-old son of a black Army officer and a white German mother. He grew up in Columbus, Ga., one of many children of interracial marriages at Fort Benning, and is now a senior majoring in African-American studies at Emory University in Atlanta. He is editor in chief of ''The Fire This Time,'' Emory's black student magazine, and has been active in campus demonstrations to persuade fraternities to stop displaying the Confederate flag. He helps teach science at a local elementary school and plans to get a Ph.D. in urban anthropology. DAVID FIRESTONE

abstract: Aleksandr Lebedev, 85, who rose from a peasant's son to become first Soviet deputy minister of higher education, and Maria Kovalyova, a 21-year-old student in Moscow, share a dismay at Russia's slipshod democracy and bandit capitalism over the last decade; photos; chronology of Russian history since 1917 (M)
snippet: Aleksandr Lebedev, 85, who rose from a peasant's son to become first Soviet deputy minister of higher education, and Maria Kovalyova, a 21-year-old student in Moscow, share a dismay at Russia's slipshod democracy and bandit capitalism over the las...
lead_paragraph: Revolution and change convulsed Russia twice in the last century, the first time in 1917, when the Bolsheviks seized power, and then in 1991, when the communist system they introduced, at such a fearful cost, collapsed under its own weight. Each time ordinary lives were swept up, sometimes swept away. In midcentury, millions died, killed by war, famine and a totalitarian regime.

abstract: Ann Powers Critic's Notebook recap of 1999 music scene, featuring fluff, smut and letting off steam on ethnic, gender and other issues of new generation; photos (M)
snippet: Ann Powers Critic's Notebook recap of 1999 music scene, featuring fluff, smut and letting off steam on ethnic, gender and other issues of new generation; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Ask any critic to comment upon this final year of the Century of American Music, and you're likely to hear a heavy sigh. The year 1999 gave us fluff and smut, the inflatable sweethearts of the teenage market and the foul-mouthed bullies of hip-hop and rock. Releases from aspiring legends like Nine Inch Nails, R. Kelly and Mary J. Blige failed to make the anticipated cultural impact, while previously dismissed artists like Limp Bizkit and Kid Rock rose to rule the Zeitgeist. People actually looked to Cher, rising again with her smash ''Believe,'' as a beacon of artistic integrity.

abstract: Michael Wines article on what will become of Russia in next century, given its lost sense of purpose after end of the cold war, its history of being ruled by strongmen and its suspicion of or hostility to the outside world; photo (M)
snippet: Michael Wines article on what will become of Russia in next century, given its lost sense of purpose after end of the cold war, its history of being ruled by strongmen and its suspicion of or hostility to the outside world; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: ANYONE trying to divine the next step on Russia's wandering course toward nationhood might start with this arresting fact: the last time Russians lived within borders as constricted as the current ones, Ivan the Terrible had been dead for only a few decades, St. Petersburg was a frozen swamp, and New York City was still the property of the Dutch.

abstract: EUROPE    FRANCE: MORE EXPLOSIVES LINKED TO BASQUES  The French police have seized a ton of explosives they said belonged to the Spanish Basque separatist guerrilla group E.T.A., a week after two powerful van bombs were found and defused in Spain. The explosives were found in an unused garage outside the city of Pau near the Spanish border.    Suzanne Daley (NYT)    BRITAIN: HONORS FOR ACTORS  Elizabeth Taylor, Julie Andrews and Sean Connery have new titles: Dame Elizabeth, Dame Julie and Sir Sean. The three actors were among 2,000 people honored in the annual New Year's list drawn up by the government and bestowed by the queen. Also honored were sports heroes, milkmen, crossing guards and the multimillionaire head of the Virgin Group, now Sir Richard Branson.   (AP)    AFRICA    SUDAN: CABINET QUITS  Three weeks after declaring a state of emergency, President Omar el-Bashir said he had accepted his cabinet's resignation, paving the way for him to consolidate his power. In a speech marking Sudan's 44th anniversary of independence, Mr. Bashir said ministers and state governors had expressed their desire to resign and he had accepted their resignations. However, he asked them to stay on as caretakers until he could reform the cabinet.   (AP)    NIGER: PREMIER AGAIN  A former prime minister, Hama Amadou, 49, was reappointed to the position by President Mamadou Tandja, who was sworn in on Dec. 22. Mr. Amadou also held the title in 1995, under President Mahamane Ousmane, who is now parliamentary speaker.    (Agence France-Presse)    CONGO: REBELS TELL OF AMBUSH  Rebels killed about 80 government soldiers in an ambush, a rebel leader said, a day after Congolese representatives held an unsuccessful meeting with a rebel envoy. Jean-Pierre Bemba, whose Congolese Liberation Movement is fighting to topple President Laurent Kabila with Ugandan backing, said government troops had been ambushed along the Congo River.    (AP)    ASIA    SRI LANKA: REBELS REPULSED  Troops repulsed Tamil Tiger rebels trying to overrun defenses at a key northern military base, the defense ministry said. The ministry said 9 soldiers and 9 rebels had been killed and 41 soldiers hurt, although independent confirmation of the figures was not possible.    (Reuters)    EAST TIMOR: U.N. AIDE APOLOGIZES  The United Nations administrator in East Timor apologized for its failure to predict and prevent a wave of violence after the territory's overwhelming vote for independence from Indonesia. Sergio Vieira de Mello, who is overseeing East Timor's transition to independence, made the apology during a visit to the coffee-growing area of Ermera, said the United Nations spokesman Fred Eckhard.   (AP)    EAST TIMOR: GUSMAO RULES HIMSELF OUT  Jose Alexandre Gusmao said he foresaw full independence for East Timor in at most two years but that he did not plan to become its first president. Mr. Gusmao had been widely expected to become an independent East Timor's first leader, but said he intended to signal that leaders of the independence struggle did not have an automatic right to power.    (Agence France-Presse)    THE AMERICAS    HONDURAS, NICARAGUA: MILITARY PACT  Honduras and Nicaragua have agreed to freeze ground troop deployments and withdraw naval forces from the Caribbean Sea to avert military conflict pending resolution of a border dispute, an official with the Organization of American States said. Relations soured in November when the Honduran Congress ratified an accord that claimed for Honduras and Colombia 52,000 square miles of Caribbean coastal waters, parts of which are also claimed by Nicaragua.    (Reuters)    PARAGUAY: CABINET MINISTER QUITS  Agriculture Minister Oscar Denis quit after his Liberal Party voted to abandon the coalition government of President Luis Gonzalez Macchi. The party's leadership voted to pull out after talks to obtain more government posts failed. The decision faces ratification by party members at a convention in February.    (Reuters)    COLOMBIA: LEADER VETOES GENOCIDE BILL  In an unex-pected reversal, President Andres Pastrana vetoed a bill that would have made genocide and forced disappearance criminal acts. His administration shifted course after the armed forces complained that such a law would leave soldiers open to prosecution, in civilian rather than military courts, for deaths inflicted in combat with leftist guerrillas.    Larry Rohter (NYT)    MIDDLE EAST    IRAN: CALL TO DESTROY ISRAEL  Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the supreme leader, called for the destruction of Israel, saying it was the only way to solve the Middle East's problems. His remarks came as millions of people rallied across Iran to protest Israel's control of Jerusalem, where Muslims believe Muhammad began his journey to heaven.    (AP)    LEBANON: HEZBOLLAH'S VOW  The Hezbollah movement said it intended to keep up its attacks on Israeli troops in south Lebanon, a day after a suicide bombing narrowly missed an Israeli patrol near the village of Qlaia, wounding 12 Lebanese civilians and an Israeli soldier. ''Hezbollah operations will not stop before or after the negotiations'' between Israel and Syria, a Hezbollah press official said.    (Agence France-Presse)

abstract: The red sun was falling, the cooking fires were burning and the village elder's naked shoulders were shivering in the afternoon cool as he described the eagerly awaited arrival of the new year. abstract: U S West Inc., the local telephone company merging with Qwest Communications International Inc., said yesterday that it had sold 65 percent of its stake in Global Crossing Ltd. to take advantage of a rise in Global Crossing's shares. U S West sold about 24 million shares, valued at $1.15 billion. It bought the shares in June before canceling a planned merger with Global Crossing, a two-year-old company that is building a worldwide phone and data network. Global Crossing stock has risen about 84 percent since October. Global Crossing and U S West agreed to merge in May, but the deal fell apart in July after Qwest made a bid for both U S West and the Frontier Corporation. U S West eventually agreed to Qwest's $45.2 billion bid.

lead_paragraph: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

abstract: Bill Carter article says the hit television show will disappear in 21st century as technological advances make it possible to individualize programs for every viewer and make it impossible for producers to establish a new show among a wide variety of viewers at the same time; photo (M)
snippet: Bill Carter article says the hit television show will disappear in 21st century as technological advances make it possible to individualize programs for every viewer and make it impossible for producers to establish a new show among a wide variety...
lead_paragraph: TELEVISION in the next century will surely be about choice. No matter what form the television set itself takes, the number of programs it delivers will be virtually limitless with the notion of separate, distinct channels all but extinct. Instead, every home will have the ME channel -- really a series of channels, one for each member of the family, offering a completely individualized lineup of programs assembled from the all-but-infinite selections pulsing through the digital web.

abstract: Gholam-Reza Hassani, the most conservative voice of Islam in Iran's clerical hierarchy, predicts downfall of American power in 21st century; says core of problem in modern world, which is at its worst in US, is that spiritual development has receded as technological progress has advanced; photo (M)
snippet: Gholam-Reza Hassani, the most conservative voice of Islam in Iran's clerical hierarchy, predicts downfall of American power in 21st century; says core of problem in modern world, which is at its worst in US, is that spiritual development has reced...
lead_paragraph: FOR some in the ancient world, where civilizations crumbled into dust 1,000 years before the birth of Jesus, the arrival of a new millennium doesn't captivate the imagination quite as it does elsewhere. Instead of seeing the last 2,000 years as a ladder for mankind's ascent, they view much of the last two millenniums, and especially the 20th century, as a chronicle of moral decay.

abstract: Octavia Butler, whose books meld science fiction with African-American spiritualism, discusses prospects for social change in 21st century; she does not expect any improvement in racial and sexual attitudes, but nevertheless remains hopeful about the human race; photo (M)
snippet: Octavia Butler, whose books meld science fiction with African-American spiritualism, discusses prospects for social change in 21st century; she does not expect any improvement in racial and sexual attitudes, but nevertheless remains hopeful about ...
lead_paragraph: IN Octavia E. Butler's latest novels, ''Parable of the Sower'' and ''Parable of the Talents,'' the near future is grim and dangerous. Americans have been devastated by an economic meltdown that makes water too expensive to bathe in. A religious right has captured the White House, unleashing a tide of intolerance, misogyny and ruthless persecution. Yet rising from the rubble of society is a movement of renewal called Earthseed. Its leader, an ''empath,'' is a complex and conflicted black woman.

abstract: Sol Gittleman letter, commenting on Dec 22 editorial, says 21st century could well be the German century; drawing

abstract: Alfred Bardelli, 91, sole surviving member of negotating team that concluded United Auto Workers' first contract with Ford Motor Co in 1941, says workers went through hell at Ford until contract was signed; Khalilah A Johnson, 23-year-old attending job-training classes for 12 hours a day, says she intends to rise out of poverty and become a Ford engineer; chronology of milestones in auto industry history (M)
snippet: Alfred Bardelli, 91, sole surviving member of negotating team that concluded United Auto Workers' first contract with Ford Motor Co in 1941, says workers went through hell at Ford until contract was signed; Khalilah A Johnson, 23-year-old attendin...
lead_paragraph: The enormous growth and subsequent unionization of the auto industry created opportunities for millions of Americans to enter the middle class. Alfred Bardelli, whose family immigrated from Italy to a Pennsylvania coal town 10 months after his birth in 1909, began cutting glass for windows in 1928 at Ford Motor's Rouge complex in Dearborn, near Detroit. It was the world's largest factory then, with 103,000 workers. He joined the United Automobile Workers in 1937, a time of violent clashes between union organizers and company security personnel. He is the sole surviving member of the negotiating team that concluded the U.A.W.'s first contract with Ford in 1941.

abstract: Meditrust Cos generates $146 million in proceeds from sale of health care assets and from early repayment of mortgage note receivables in fourth quarter; company has received gross proceeds of $1.4 billion from sale of assets since November 1998, when it announced its restructuring plan (S)
snippet: Meditrust Cos generates $146 million in proceeds from sale of health care assets and from early repayment of mortgage note receivables in fourth quarter; company has received gross proceeds of $1.4 billion from sale of assets since November 1998, ...
lead_paragraph: The Meditrust Companies has generated $146 million in proceeds from the sale of health care assets and from the early repayment of mortgage note receivables in the fourth quarter. The company said it had also repaid $250 million of its credit facility that otherwise was to mature on Jan. 17. The $146 million was generated from the sale of 20 assisted-living properties, one rehabilitation center and the early repayment of 10 nursing home mortgages. Since November 1998, when it announced a restructuring plan, the company has received gross proceeds of $1.4 billion from the sale of assets.

abstract: Despite a few sputters and glitches, the world's computers appear to have survived the year 2000 rollover without major problems -- and with humanity's faith in technology intact, at least for another day.     As clocks passed midnight around the world, there were a flurry of reports of apparently minor problems: a timing device at a electric plant in Wisconsin jumped ahead 35 days, but it was quickly reset; a monitoring system at a Japanese nuclear plant malfunctioned, but it did not affect the operation of the reactor; in Australia, ticketing machines on some buses jammed.
lead_paragraph: Despite a few sputters and glitches, the world's computers appear to have survived the year 2000 rollover without major problems -- and with humanity's faith in technology intact, at least for another day.

abstract: TAYLOR-Frieda. The partners and staff of Lipsky, Goodkin & Company, PC, with profound sorrow, mourn the passing of Frieda Taylor, the mother of our esteemed partner and founder, Stewart Taylor. This courageous woman, cherished her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She was deeply committed to their well being, always giving to them an abundance of love, compassion, understanding and deep devotion. She enriched the lives of all who came in contact with her warmth and trust. Our heartfelt condolences to her children, grandchildren and great grandchildren. She will be missed, but truly remembered. Lipsky, Goodkin and Company.

abstract: Fritz Israel, 74, who was German soldier in World War II, recalls the war and how he learned about Holocaust, while Bernd Matzner, a 27-year-old who grew up in East Germany, reflects on country's unification and future; chronology of German history since 1919 (M)

abstract: Among institutions of higher education that have developed a niche for themselves and are expected to be on cutting in 21st century include University of Phoenix, MIT, Alverno College, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and Truman State University; photo (M)
snippet: Among institutions of higher education that have developed a niche for themselves and are expected to be on cutting in 21st century include University of Phoenix, MIT, Alverno College, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and Truman State University; ...
lead_paragraph: Despite warnings that too many people are overeducated, new high school graduates and adults long out of school are expected to flock to college in ever-growing numbers in the years ahead, even as the notion of higher education expands and changes. There will always be a Harvard (and a Yale and a Princeton). But other traditional colleges are likely to be bypassed as students seek convenience and specially tailored services -- and colleges respond. The watchwords will be high technology and cost efficiency, and courses will be delivered in many ways. For better or worse, the future is full of niches to be filled. Here are some institutions that higher education experts expect to be on the cutting edge.

abstract: Prime Min Goh Chok Tong says Singapore's economy grew 8.2 percent in fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for full year 1999; photo (S)
snippet: Prime Min Goh Chok Tong says Singapore's economy grew 8.2 percent in fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for full year 1999; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: Singapore's economy grew 8.2 percent in the fourth quarter and 5.6 percent for the full year 1999, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong said in a New Year message. Mr. Goh noted that the recovery in the economy had been ''much faster than we had expected,'' buttressed by external factors like ''the strong upswing in electronics, the beginnings of a turnaround in Japan and continued robust growth in the United States.'' He said the outlook for 2000 was positive.

abstract: Schlumberger Ltd says it has completed spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc, in $3.61 billion transaction that creates world's largest offshore drilling company (S)
snippet: Schlumberger Ltd says it has completed spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc, in $3.61 billion transaction that creates world's largest offshore drilling company (S)
lead_paragraph: Schlumberger Ltd., a leading oil services company, said yesterday that the spinoff of its Sedco Forex Offshore unit and its merger with Transocean Offshore Inc. had been completed in a $3.61 billion transaction that creates the world's largest offshore drilling company. Schlumberger investors received one share in Sedco Forex for each share held. The shares were exchanged for 0.1936 share in the new company, Transocean Sedco Forex Inc. Schlumberger shareholders retained a 52 percent stake in the new company. Schlumberger is getting out of offshore rig rentals to concentrate on developing technology that gets more oil out of wells. The merger lets Transocean, the third-largest offshore driller, add to its fleet of deep-water rigs.

abstract: ''If I could erase this year and do it over, I would,'' said Anthony Boyce, a heroin addict who wanted to check into a detoxification program and celebrate the dawn of the new year by sleeping through it. ''I need to clear my head and not think about what to do next,'' said Mr. Boyce, 47. ''When you're carrying a load on your shoulders 24 hours a day, it gets to where you can't think of a way out.''    At the Positive Health Project, a walk-up sanctuary at 305 West 37th St., some of the homeless and destitute shared their modest hopes and considerable fears as a few blocks away Times Square was being readied for New Year's Eve. The project dispenses more than 13,000 clean syringes and 36,000 condoms a month, along with advice about staying healthy on the street.

lead_paragraph: Last summer I was changing planes at Singapore's swank new airport, which has lounges spread all over, at which transit passengers can watch satellite TV. As I walked through the airport, I bought a snack and sat down in one of these lounges. There I found two elderly Indian women, in traditional sari robes, watching American professional wrestling. These two petite Indian ladies were sitting transfixed, gazing at huge wrestlers in Tarzan suits body-slamming one another. All I could think was: ''What in the world are they making of this?''

abstract: ''But where are the snows of yesteryear?'' the poet Francois Villon asked in the 15th century, not even halfway through the millennium we are making a fuss about leaving. Nothing new under the sun, though in his case it was not an early global-warming alert but a lament for departed loveliness. Nothing new there either.    Maybe the past is prologue, but here at the changing of the hundred- and thousand-year guard, prologue is chiefly the past. The flood of writing on the subject, including this additional teacupful, looks back more than forward. ''Millennium'' has a great gong sound, but is it the gong announcing the end of an era or summoning the one to come? The first is bronze, the second is tin.
lead_paragraph: ''But where are the snows of yesteryear?'' the poet Francois Villon asked in the 15th century, not even halfway through the millennium we are making a fuss about leaving. Nothing new under the sun, though in his case it was not an early global-warming alert but a lament for departed loveliness. Nothing new there either.

lead_paragraph: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

abstract: John Fleetwood recalls moving from Kansas City to Southern California in 1939 to work in aircraft manufacturing; Thuy Ti Nguyen, who left Vietnam when she was two and moved first to New Orleans and then to Oakland and Los Angeles, where she is studying law, describes her hopes for the future; photos; chronology of California's history since 1913 (M)
snippet: John Fleetwood recalls moving from Kansas City to Southern California in 1939 to work in aircraft manufacturing; Thuy Ti Nguyen, who left Vietnam when she was two and moved first to New Orleans and then to Oakland and Los Angeles, where she is stu...
lead_paragraph: Not so long ago, when people referred to immigrants in Southern California, they usually meant someone like John Fleetwood. Mr. Fleetwood, 80, came from Kansas City in 1939 to work in aircraft manufacturing. He climbed his way up to running the operation that produced the Apollo command modules. His daughter has become the mayor of the town in which he lived for many years, Downey. He left when it started to become heavily populated by the next wave of immigrants, Hispanics.

abstract: The first to greet the new day on Taveuni Island were the birds, singing from the treetops at the ocean's edge, skimming along the surf, filling the pale pre-dawn with celebration. abstract: Clinton administration officials said today that President Boris N. Yeltsin's surprise resignation would not dramatically alter relations with Russia and could improve the chances that Moscow and Washington will break a stalemate over a major arms control treaty. abstract: Bridge column recalls remarkable bridge game played in 1917 in Constantinople harbor, to determine whether crew of US gunboat Scorpion would be interned by Turks or their German allies; captain, Herbert Babbitt, challenged Turkish minister, Talat Pasha, to rubber, with ship as stake; Babbitt won, and crew got its wish to remain in Turkish waters until end of war (M)
snippet: Bridge column recalls remarkable bridge game played in 1917 in Constantinople harbor, to determine whether crew of US gunboat Scorpion would be interned by Turks or their German allies; captain, Herbert Babbitt, challenged Turkish minister, Talat ...
lead_paragraph: The most remarkable bridge game of the past century, or indeed the millennium, occurred in 1917 in the Turkish harbor of Constantinople, now Istanbul. An American gunboat, the Scorpion, was attached to the American Embassy there, and it was boarded by the Turks, who were German allies, when the United States entered World War I.

abstract: ROWLEY-Louis N.. Jr. Age 90 of Shelton, CT., formerly of Port Washington, L.I., on December 30, 1999. Beloved husband of Maybelle ''Billie'' (nee Chemidlin) for over 66 years, he is also survived by his sons; Rev. Louis E. Rowley of Mount Vernon, New York, Robert S. Rowley of Danbury, CT, and David C. Rowley of Swarthmore, PA., eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM on Saturday, January 8 at Crosby Commons, 580 Long Hill Ave., Shelton, CT. Memorial Contributions may be made to the United Methodist Church 1515 Middle Neck Road, PO Box 929, Port Washington, NY 11050, or to the charity of your choice.

Beloved husband of Maybelle ''Billie'' (nee Chemidlin) for over 66 years, he is also survived by his sons; Rev. Louis E. Rowley of Mount Vernon, New York, Robert S. Rowley of Danbury, CT, and David C. Rowley of Swarthmore, PA., eight grandchildren and five great grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 2:00 PM on Saturday, January 8 at Crosby Commons, 580 Long Hill Ave., Shelton, CT. Memorial Contributions may be made to the United Methodist Church 1515 Middle Neck Road, PO Box 929, Port Washington, NY 11050, or to the charity of your choice.

abstract: Sheryl Gay Stolberg article on how life may be changed for good or ill through biotechnology in the century ahead; drawing (M)
snippet: Sheryl Gay Stolberg article on how life may be changed for good or ill through biotechnology in the century ahead; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: UNLIKE the sheep named Dolly, the mouse named Lucy has barely made a ripple in the news. Lucy, born on Oct. 26, 1998, is the creation of scientists at Chromos Molecular Systems, a biotechnology company in Vancouver, British Columbia. She has black-brown fur and is not unlike mice bred in laboratories around the world, the company says, with one exception: Lucy has an artificial chromosome that she has passed to her offspring.

abstract: Mack-Cali Realty Corp says it sold stakes in office buildings in Princeton and Parsipanny, NJ, and in Phoenix, Ariz, for more than $100 million, and bought office buildings in Moorestown, NJ, for $8 million (S)
snippet: Mack-Cali Realty Corp says it sold stakes in office buildings in Princeton and Parsipanny, NJ, and in Phoenix, Ariz, for more than $100 million, and bought office buildings in Moorestown, NJ, for $8 million (S)
lead_paragraph: The Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust in Cranford, N.J., said late on Thursday that it had sold stakes in properties in New Jersey and Arizona for more than $100 million. The company sold a 71,000-square-foot office building in Princeton, N.J., and a 119,000-square-foot office property in Phoenix, each for about $9 million. The company said it sold a 55 percent stake in five buildings in Parsippany, N.J., for $84 million. Mack-Cali, which owns or has stakes in 257 properties, used part of the proceeds to buy three office buildings in Moorestown, N.J., for $8 million.

abstract: Saddling up all its horses, putting all its helicopters in the air and sending nearly all its officers out on the street in uniform, the New York Police Department yesterday mounted one of its largest security operations ever -- three years in the planning and costing $6 million -- and by early this morning it appeared to have paid off with a genial and almost uneventful New Year's Eve.    Some 8,000 police officers blanketed Times Square alone -- a force larger than that of most of the country's municipal police departments -- for the most famous and symbolic gathering. But the police also had to cover 328 other officially scheduled celebrations in all five boroughs, including a gathering of tens of thousands of people at Grand Army Plaza in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: Saddling up all its horses, putting all its helicopters in the air and sending nearly all its officers out on the street in uniform, the New York Police Department yesterday mounted one of its largest security operations ever -- three years in the planning and costing $6 million -- and by early this morning it appeared to have paid off with a genial and almost uneventful New Year's Eve.

abstract: Lily Yen, 96-year-old retired teacher and homemaker in Shanghai, recalls the terrible upheavals that overtook China in her lifetime; says young people today are materialistic and do not listen; Grace Shen, 21-year-old student, says her generation is not selfish, but wants to take advantages of the new choices they have; photo; chronology of China's history since 1911 (M)
snippet: Lily Yen, 96-year-old retired teacher and homemaker in Shanghai, recalls the terrible upheavals that overtook China in her lifetime; says young people today are materialistic and do not listen; Grace Shen, 21-year-old student, says her generation ...
lead_paragraph: Lily Yen, born to a merchant family in Shanghai, was one of very few women in China able to attend a university in the early part of the 20th century. She volunteered to teach schoolgirls in a poor, inland rural province. War and recurrent political campaigns intruded, and Mrs. Yen's family was divided when half her relatives moved to Taiwan in 1949. Now 96 and a retired homemaker, she thinks today's young people are too self-centered and have lost the spirit of sacrifice.

abstract: In a beautiful, almost ethereal scene, about 2,000 Christians quietly ascended the Mount of Olives as midnight approached. Following a lighted crucifix, they carried votive candles that flickered in the still darkness of a city devoid of any official celebration of the millennium.     At the top, they planted the crucifix and gathered round, moved by the serenity. Then, switching in a flash from the sublime to the cheesy, it turned into a Dick Clark New Year's Eve special with a Fellini-esque cast, set in the heart of the Holy Land.
lead_paragraph: In a beautiful, almost ethereal scene, about 2,000 Christians quietly ascended the Mount of Olives as midnight approached. Following a lighted crucifix, they carried votive candles that flickered in the still darkness of a city devoid of any official celebration of the millennium.

abstract: President Jiang Zemin spoke here of China's glorious future and a few adventurous souls ventured to the Great Wall, but most Beijingers spent the ticking over of the calendar doing what average folks here do when given half a chance: they went shopping.    This week, dozens of shopping centers and department stores across Beijing announced that they would stay open for much of New Year's Eve to honor the event, with a number not closing until 2 a.m. and some not at all.

abstract: McCRORY-Sylvia (nee Hogben). of Pound Ridge, NY; born London, England. She was the daughter of Lancelot Hogben and Enid Charles. She will be remembered as a loving Grandmother, Mother and Wife. Breeder of Liafail Irish Setters. She volunteered at Pound Ridge, Hiram Halle Memorial Library. She is survived by her husband Wallace W. McCrory, M.D., Chief of Pediatrics, NY Hospital, Cornell Medical Center (Emeritus); her children Pamela Sylvia McCrory of Lawrenceville, NJ, Michael Wallace Lancelot McCrory of Tucson, AZ and Christen Claire Gilley of Streetsboro, OH; her two brothers, Adrian Hogben and Dr. David Hogben; and cherished grandchildren James, David, Wendy, Holly and Andrew. Calling hours 2-4PM Monday, Jan. 3rd at the Cassidy-Flynn Funeral Home, Mt. Kisco, NY. Friends may send memorial donations to the American Friends Service Committee. Please omit flowers.

abstract: Ambrose Ackah, 64-year-old retired Ghanaian teacher, believes that Africa can achieve peace and even unity, while Paul Yankey, a 19-year-old who struggled to complete secondary school, is not hopeful about the future and says he wants to emigrate; photos; chronology of Ghana's history since 1902 (M)
snippet: Ambrose Ackah, 64-year-old retired Ghanaian teacher, believes that Africa can achieve peace and even unity, while Paul Yankey, a 19-year-old who struggled to complete secondary school, is not hopeful about the future and says he wants to emigrate;...
lead_paragraph: In 1957, the Gold Coast became the first country to gain independence in sub-Saharan Africa, led by Kwame Nkrumah. Nkrumah's vision of African solidarity inspired independence movements across the continent, but his rule ended in a morass of corruption and an army coup in 1966. Nkrumah's hometown lies in western Ghana, a small town called Nkroful, where Ambrose Ackah was born some 64 years ago. Mr. Ackah, the son of farmers and one of seven children, was the first one in his family to attend school. He became an elementary school teacher and retired three years ago.

abstract: GIBSON-Leslie Fuller Larned. Died December 14 at home in Washington, CT. A devoted wife, mother and grandmother, Mrs. Gibson divided her time between her home in CT, a residence in NYC, her son's in Birdsboro, PA, and at Bear Island in Penobscot Bay, ME, a property jointly held with other members of the Fuller family. She was the elder daughter of Edward P. (Ned) Larned and of Lesley Fuller Larned (Mrs. J. Nelson Borland II in later life). She was a devoted niece of Rosamond L. Fuller (Mrs. Alphonse Kenison) of Newcastle, ME; the same of, and to, R. Buckminster Fuller of world-wide address. Among her activities, she was a contributor to Scenic Hudson, and served on its Board of Directors. Her father was a brother of William P. Larned, at one time topranked singles tennis player. Together they were champions in doubles. On December 18, at the First Congregational Church on Washington Green, Rev. Cheryl Anderson led a memorial service for Mrs. Gibson. Immediate survivors are her husband, R. Dana Gibson, a painter (they married in Wiscasset, ME in 1942); also a sister, Mrs. Albert F. Winslow (Katherine P. Larned) of Tuxedo Park, NY; also a son, George Brayton Larned Gibson of Birdsboro, PA; his wife, Lynn Updegrave Gibson, and three grandchildren, Miles, Graham and Lila. Contributions may be sent to ''Save the Shepaug,'' care of the Steep Rock Association, PO Box 279 Washington Depot, CT. 06794 or to Scenic Hudson. Interment will take place in the cemetery by Washington Green when available in April.

abstract: The hijackers of an Indian Airlines plane won the release of three prominent militants jailed in India. All of them sped away from the airport in Afghanistan, trying to get out of the country. The names and nationalities of the hijackers are still unknown. With the release, more than 150 haggard passengers, kept on board for eight days, were freed unharmed. They flew to New Delhi, for family reunions, both wrenching and joyous.
lead_paragraph: The hijackers of an Indian Airlines plane won the release of three prominent militants jailed in India. abstract: Anita Gates reviews play Inappropriate by A Michael DeSisto and Lonnie McNeil; photo (S)
snippet: Anita Gates reviews play Inappropriate by A Michael DeSisto and Lonnie McNeil; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: ''Inappropriate'' is not ''Rent.'' A theatergoer might be forgiven for thinking it is, since the show, a rock musical, stars an ensemble of young actors wearing headset microphones, attitude and the combination of layers, mismatches, glitter and sportswear that make up homeless-person chic. Averie Boyer, who is excellent in his understated way as one of the central performers (there are no character names), even looks something like Anthony Rapp, who played Mark in ''Rent's'' original Broadway and Off Broadway cast.

abstract: William Safire column on the possibility of greatly extending human life in next century (M)
snippet: William Safire column on the possibility of greatly extending human life in next century (M)
lead_paragraph: Of all the instincts in animals, the strongest is the will to survive. In the human animal, that inborn defense is sometimes overcome by the maternal instinct, by love of country or comrades in battle, or by an illness like depression. But in most of us, nothing makes the weak strong or the fearful brave as much as our bodies' innate drive to stay alive.

abstract: Avraham Biran, an archaeologist who was born 90 years ago in Galilee highlands, says Palestinians do not relate to the land the way Jews do, but he predicts that there will be a Palestinian state, even in his lifetime, and that Israel will endure for hundreds of years; Ayman Abu-Shirbi, 13-year-old Palestinian, sees his future as a scientist and citizen of Palestine; photos; chronology of Palestine's history since 1916 (M)
snippet: Avraham Biran, an archaeologist who was born 90 years ago in Galilee highlands, says Palestinians do not relate to the land the way Jews do, but he predicts that there will be a Palestinian state, even in his lifetime, and that Israel will endure ...
lead_paragraph: Avraham Biran, 90, and Ayman Abu-Shirbi, 13, define themselves through scholarship. A second-generation descendant of the earliest Zionist pioneers, Dr. Biran grew up under Ottoman rule in Rosh Pina, a village in the Galilee highlands founded by his Romanian great-grandparents. One of Israel's pre-eminent archaeologists, he has spent most of his life connecting the Israel of today to the Israel of the Bible.

abstract: The land that made Carnival and the samba art forms loves nothing more than a party. So the beginning of the 2000's in Rio de Janeiro turned into what authorities proudly called the largest celebration in Brazilian history: an estimated 3.5 million people lining Copacabana, Ipanema and more than 25 miles of other beaches in a tropical spectacle that blended the spiritual and the profane.    For believers of Candomble, Brazil's home-grown mixture of Catholicism and African-derived animist beliefs, New Year's Eve is traditionally the feast day of Iemanja, the fair-skinned goddess of the sea who appears in the guise of the Virgin Mary and is considered the mother of all living things. Beaches are always packed with worshipers who come to seek her blessing on that night, but with the celebration of the millennium, everything that has gone on in the past was multiplied.
lead_paragraph: The land that made Carnival and the samba art forms loves nothing more than a party. abstract: Experimental vehicles are being built by General Motors, Ford Motor Co and DaimlerChrysler under umbrella of government-sponsored Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles; they face huge obstacles; Big Three are all focusing on diesel-electric hybrid cars, even though federal and state environmental regulators are adopting new rules for tailpipe emissions that will make it difficult after 2003 to sell cars with diesel engines; Honda Motor and Toyota Motor, operating with much smaller government subsidies, are already mass producing small high-mileage cars that combine gasoline engines and electric motors; manufacturing costs for all hybrid cars, including Japanese models, are steep; selling them at competitive prices remains money-losing proposition; and there is little sign that Americans want high-mileage cars in era of relatively low gasoline prices and rising national prosperity; photos; diagrams (L)

lead_paragraph: So now at last begins the year 2000, a juncture in time so long anticipated it is hard to believe it has arrived, disguised as a mere Saturday. The year is so utterly new, all four digits overturned at once, that simply seeing the date in print jars the eye.

abstract: Touch Kea, 75, barber to King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, recalls horrors of Khmer Rouge genocide in late 1970's, while Touch Sopharath, a 19-year-old granddaugher of his and a law student, looks forward to a normal life; chronology of Cambodian history since 1953 (M)
snippet: Touch Kea, 75, barber to King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, recalls horrors of Khmer Rouge genocide in late 1970's, while Touch Sopharath, a 19-year-old granddaugher of his and a law student, looks forward to a normal life; chronology of Cambodian...
lead_paragraph: Few countries suffered as deeply as Cambodia over the last half-century. The tiny, beautiful Southeast Asian land was a battleground among the great powers and the scene of hugely destructive American bombing during the Vietnam War. Then its own internal demons rose from within its people's brutalized psyche. Cambodia became the scene of horrific mass killings by the radical communist Khmer Rouge, who from 1975 to 1979 took the lives of as many as one-fourth of the population of eight million.

abstract: Half a million? A million? A zillion? The world will never know how many humans squeezed their way into the Designated Watching Zones around Times Square to see the ball drop, but it is not impossible to estimate how many people could have been there.    Around 11:20 p.m., the mayor said the crowd was ''pushing two million.'' But a calculation shows that the theoretical capacity of the area open to spectators was considerably less.

abstract: Finance Min Bambang Sudibyo says Indonesian government will recapitalize its own central bank after state auditors indicate that Bank Indonesia has negative net worth; two new investigations into central bank are announced; photo (S)
snippet: Finance Min Bambang Sudibyo says Indonesian government will recapitalize its own central bank after state auditors indicate that Bank Indonesia has negative net worth; two new investigations into central bank are announced; photo (S)
lead_paragraph: The Indonesian government will have to recapitalize its own central bank after state auditors refused to give Bank Indonesia a clean bill of health, the Finance Minister, Bambang Sudibyo, said. Two new investigations into the bank were also announced, including one to be led by Indonesia's attorney general. An audit released to Parliament by the state audit agency indicated that the central bank had negative net worth, Mr. Sudibyo said. There has been widespread talk that state auditors took issue with 51 trillion rupiah ($7.1 billion) lent by Bank Indonesia to banks as emergency liquidity support.

abstract: Earlier in the day, the mayor, who gave himself the job of ubiquitous master of ceremonies of the city's new year celebration, said he began his last morning of the 1900's at 5:30 a.m. having trouble getting his lights on. ''I was convinced that it was Y2K,'' the mayor said, but ''actually I was sleepy.''     Mr. Giuliani spent much of his day in front of cameras. He started at 6:40 a.m. with a news conference at the All-Star Cafe in Times Square, then had interviews from 7 to 8 a.m. with NBC, ABC, CBS and Fox News. He also had two news conferences at the Office of Emergency Management's Command Center at the World Trade Center.
lead_paragraph: Earlier in the day, the mayor, who gave himself the job of ubiquitous master of ceremonies of the city's new year celebration, said he began his last morning of the 1900's at 5:30 a.m. having trouble getting his lights on. abstract: Italian government reports budget deficit declined by almost half, to $16.4 billion, after tax evaders were forced to pay up (S)
snippet: Italian government reports budget deficit declined by almost half, to $16.4 billion, after tax evaders were forced to pay up (S)
lead_paragraph: Italy's budget deficit declined by almost half this year as tax evaders were forced to pay up, the government said. The deficit dropped to 31.6 trillion lire ($16.4 billion) from 58.34 trillion lire in 1998, the Treasury announced. The decline was partly because of a December surplus of some 25 trillion lire. ''The result was better than expected, and Italians have good reason to be satisfied,'' Treasury Minister Giuliano Amato said.

abstract: The snow everyone had been waiting for all winter finally came. The narrow streets leading down to Red Square, usually clotted with traffic, were empty. For all its imperfections, Moscow on New Year's Eve seemed suddenly, subtly perfect.    Muscovites who would normally elbow each other rushing to work flowed out of the subway station and toward the edges of the Kremlin. All that had changed in Moscow and all that had stayed the same in this decade of unimaginable twists was here.
lead_paragraph: The snow everyone had been waiting for all winter finally came. The narrow streets leading down to Red Square, usually clotted with traffic, were empty. For all its imperfections, Moscow on New Year's Eve seemed suddenly, subtly perfect.

abstract: Cost of college education is expected to outpace inflation well into the new century and perhaps forever; graph (M)
snippet: Cost of college education is expected to outpace inflation well into the new century and perhaps forever; graph (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN Mozart was alive, it took two to three months for a craftsman to make a watch and about 18 minutes for an ensemble to perform ''Eine Kleine Nachtmusik.'' Today, it takes two minutes for a machine to make a watch. But a performance of Mozart's familiar composition still takes musicians more than a quarter-hour.

abstract: Think Tank column describes drawings for each month in Julius Work Calendar for Year 1000, window on life in England at start of second millennium; drawings for May and July; excerpts are from book The Year 1000 by Robert Lacey and Danny Danziger (M)
snippet: Think Tank column describes drawings for each month in Julius Work Calendar for Year 1000, window on life in England at start of second millennium; drawings for May and July; excerpts are from book The Year 1000 by Robert Lacey and Danny Danziger ...
lead_paragraph: Its appearance, with 12 months represented in 12 pages, is not so different from that of a calendar you might find hanging on a kitchen wall (except for the words in Latin). But the Julius Work Calendar is nearly 1,000 years old. It was probably created by a cleric working in the manuscript studio at Canterbury Cathedral in England. Down the left side of the page are the days of the month in Roman numerals, and on the right the names of saints and religious festivals. Across the bottom runs a delicate drawing illustrating the task of the month. Over all the calendar offers a window on life in England at the start of the second millennium.

lead_paragraph: SOFTWARE is the DNA of the high-technology age, the mediator between man and machine, conveying our questions or orders to the computers that surround us. lead_paragraph: LUCIANA MARIA DOS SANTOS lives on the south side of the world's third-largest city in Favela 19, or Slum 19, a collection of shacks traversed by a stream that doubles as the sewage system. abstract: Arts & Ideas look ahead at works-in-progress; social anthropologist Sarah Blaffer Hrdy discusses her view that major themes in George Eliot novels were response to social Darwinism and to Herbert Spencer, who assumed that child gets mental powers from father and beauty from mother; Hrdy says Eliot, who was rejected by Spencer, got her revenge in fiction and also understood that inherited traits are unpredictable (M)
snippet: Arts & Ideas look ahead at works-in-progress; social anthropologist Sarah Blaffer Hrdy discusses her view that major themes in George Eliot novels were response to social Darwinism and to Herbert Spencer, who assumed that child gets mental powers ...
lead_paragraph: The centruy's turn has been a time of retrospectives: what was the most important event, who was the most influential thinker? Arts & Ideas decided to take a look ahead at what some of today's researchers are working on. From the most raked-over field, like the history of the ancient world, to the latest medical technology, scholars are coming up with fresh insights. Some ideas may turn into breakthroughs, and others may turn out to be dead-ends, but the journey is rarely boring. Here is a handful of works in progress.

abstract: Streetscapes column on six-story Romanesque Revival apartment building called Brockholst on Columbus Avenue and 85th Street in Manhattan, which is undergoing restoration by longtime owner Marcus Retter in West Side neighborhood that is experiencing revival; photos (M)
snippet: Streetscapes column on six-story Romanesque Revival apartment building called Brockholst on Columbus Avenue and 85th Street in Manhattan, which is undergoing restoration by longtime owner Marcus Retter in West Side neighborhood that is experiencin...
lead_paragraph: THE Brockholst, built in 1890 at 85th Street and Columbus Avenue, is something of a poor man's Dakota -- lesser in all respects than the famous apartment house farther south, but still majestically craggy, with wide, rambling marble-paneled halls and some of the most interesting apartments on the West Side. When Marcus Retter bought the Romanesque revival building nearly half a century ago, the West Side was headed downhill. But now the neighborhood -- and the Brockholst -- are on the way up.

abstract: Claudia Hanlin opens Wedding Library, resource center for brides, on East 81st Street in Manhattan; photo (Pulse column) (S)
snippet: Claudia Hanlin opens Wedding Library, resource center for brides, on East 81st Street in Manhattan; photo (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: Remembering the anxiety she endured when she put her wedding together five years ago, Claudia Hanlin, a 34-year-old former strategic managing consultant, vowed to simplify the famously nerve-racking experience of coordinating a wedding. Ms. Hanlin recently opened the Wedding Library, a research refuge at 50 East 81st Street (212-327-0100), where brides-to-be can browse through bound portfolios of photographers, caterers, florists, stationers, makeup artists, bakers and calligraphers and also hear tapes from bands and watch videos of weddings for inspiration. ''I wanted to offer people a chance to see some great suppliers without overwhelming them,'' said Ms. Hanlin, whose library is open free to the public. Suppliers, who pay to be included in the archive, provide everything from a society band for a lavish Pierre Hotel soiree to a Porta Potti for a barefoot-on-the-beach reception, but Ms. Hanlin thinks it's important to keep the number of options manageable. ''We try to find the supplier to fit the need of every kind of bride,'' she said. ''I got hundreds of photography portfolios and narrowed it down to 10.'' KAREN ROBINOVITZ

abstract: what writer's writers write*
snippet: what writer's writers write*
lead_paragraph: The saddest words of tongue or pen? ''Writer's writer,'' a synonym for obscurity. Every writer understands exactly what that fearful possessive hints at: a modicum of professional admiration accompanied -- or subverted -- by dim public recognition and even dimmer sales. Yet the writer's writer is said to write not in hope of fame but out of quiet passion, and is thereby accorded a purity not granted to the household name. Both Andre Dubus and Gina Berriault labored long under this doubtful encomium. Both escaped it; both came to be celebrated as writers, released at last from the piously diminishing apostrophe.

abstract: Philip Weiss article on apartment house developer Fred C Trump, who died in 1999; he built Queens foundation for son Donald's Manhattan real-estate empire; photos (M)
snippet: Philip Weiss article on apartment house developer Fred C Trump, who died in 1999; he built Queens foundation for son Donald's Manhattan real-estate empire; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: Donald Trump remembers exactly when he realized his father was beginning to fade. About six years ago, they were driving down Fifth Avenue when he gave his father big news: he had just bought the land beneath the Empire State Building. ''That's a tall building, isn't it?'' Fred C. Trump replied. ''How many apartments are in that building?'' At first, Donald thought he was kidding. But his father, 87, was developing Alzheimer's.

abstract: New Jersey State Teen Arts, organization devoted to promoting arts education for students in public and private schools, publishes 31st annual calender that features artwork of teenagers; drawing (S)
snippet: New Jersey State Teen Arts, organization devoted to promoting arts education for students in public and private schools, publishes 31st annual calender that features artwork of teenagers; drawing (S)
lead_paragraph: The year is just a couple of days old, so there's plenty of time to get your money's worth if you invest in a year 2000 calendar. That's particularly true if you choose a calendar that features artwork of teenagers from New Jersey. The New Jersey State Teen Arts calendar is the 31st put out by New Jersey State Teen Arts, which is dedicated to promoting arts education for students in public and private schools, mainly through mentorships (the organization just got a grant from Channel 11 to set up mentorships with video professionals). The calendars have gone to legislators and schools, but there are some left at no charge beyond $2.50 for shipping, from New Jersey Teen Arts, 1422 Route 179, Lambertville, N.J. 08530; (609) 397-0505. The group also publishes an anthology of writing by teenagers, puts on a touring art show (at the State Aquarium in Camden through this month) and holds an annual arts festival. This year's, at the College of New Jersey in Trenton, will be May 24 and 25. You can mark the dates.

lead_paragraph: The knickers were a mistake. abstract: John Ashbery article on Rudy Burckhardt, photographer, filmmaker, painter, occasional writer and guru to several generations of New York artists and poets, who killed self in 1999; photo (M)0
snippet: John Ashbery article on Rudy Burckhardt, photographer, filmmaker, painter, occasional writer and guru to several generations of New York artists and poets, who killed self in 1999; photo (M)0
lead_paragraph: Rudy Burckhardt, a Swiss-born photographer, filmmaker, painter, occasional writer (''Love in Three Acts: A Swiss Play'') and guru (he would have hated the term) to several generations of New York artists and poets, committed suicide on Aug. 1 by walking into a pond near his summer home at Searsmont, Maine. He seems to have arranged his death according to the same offhand, slightly eccentric principles that guided his life. His wife, the painter Yvonne Jacquette, reports that Rudy's middle name was August, and that a couple of days before taking his life he pointed out to her that Aug. 1 is ''Swiss independence day.'' (He had never shown any pronounced fondness for the land of his birth.) At about the same time, he painted a portrait of himself, which he labeled ''The Last Portrait.'' When Yvonne asked him about the title he merely shrugged and made an evasive answer. On the evening of July 31 the Burckhardts had a pleasant dinner with the poet Bill Berkson and his wife. The next day Rudy was simply gone.

abstract: Anyone who was once a Beatle, even the ''quiet'' one, can never fade away and live a simple life -- no matter how big the mansion, how high the walls. George Harrison learned that in a spasm of violence, one with echoes of John Lennon's murder nearly two decades ago.     An intruder -- obsessed with the Beatles to the point of believing they were witches -- broke into his home outside London and stabbed him in the chest, also slightly injuring his wife, Olivia. Mr. Harrison should recover from the resulting lung injury, his surgeon said, in a matter of weeks.   HUBERT B. HERRING

abstract: Editorial on various campaign proposals for using federal budget surplus; warns that if current spending levels are not cut this year, and rise at rate of inflation, ten-year surplus shrinks to $250 billion, or even less; recalls enduring lesson of Reagan years, that it really does take smoke and mirrors to produce tax cuts, spending initiatives and balanced budget all at the same time
snippet: Editorial on various campaign proposals for using federal budget surplus; warns that if current spending levels are not cut this year, and rise at rate of inflation, ten-year surplus shrinks to $250 billion, or even less; recalls enduring lesson o...
lead_paragraph: For two decades, American politics were defined by what David Stockman, the Reagan-era budget director, memorably proclaimed to be deficits as far as the eye could see. With the arrival of this new year, the United States economy will shortly break the record set in the 1960's and achieve the longest boom in history. As a result, political candidates are now debating how to spend surpluses rather than how to reduce deficits. But the new game can be as tricky as the old one. The true size of any surplus is debatable. Even its existence is provisional, depending on yet unrealized spending cuts. So far the presidential candidates are more interested in talking about what a surplus might buy than in the painful choices that lie ahead.
headline: {'main': 'That Elusive Surplus', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'That Elusive Surplus', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Andrew Sullivan article on David W Belin, lawyer for Warren Commission, and Leonard C Lewin, journalist who wrote parody of government study into awful consequences that could result from peace in Vietnam, who both died in 1999; cites them as veterans of paranoia's glory days; notes even Belin eventually conceded that commission's stand that Pres John F Kennedy was murdered by lone gunman was overwhelmed by public doubt; Lewin's pseudo-report, liberal fantasy about evils of military-industrial complex, has been taken up by militia right in 1990's as real government document; photos (M)
snippet: Andrew Sullivan article on David W Belin, lawyer for Warren Commission, and Leonard C Lewin, journalist who wrote parody of government study into awful consequences that could result from peace in Vietnam, who both died in 1999; cites them as vete...
lead_paragraph: The year 1999 was not, it turned out, a vintage year for paranoia. Heaven knows why. We were prepared for all manner of hysteria: survivalist panics, religious retreats, cultic chaos. None of it materialized. Perhaps it was the genuine fear of a Y2K computer crash that distracted us from premillennial fantasies. Perhaps it was the transparency of the Internet and the power of hackers that made government secrecy seem less intimidating. Or maybe the paranoids of the mid-1990's simply blew themselves out with their ''X-Files'' excesses.

abstract: MEIER-June. On December 26, 1999. Wife of the late Frank Meier. Mother of Diane, Gordon and Richard. Grandmother of Bennett, Bradford, Rebecca and John. As master-craftsman, teacher and advocate, she helped to rediscover and resurrect lost decorative arts from decoupage to all manner of painted finishes and taught a new generation to appreciate the beauty of the past and weave it into the context of the present. In lieu of flowers, please make donations to The Isabel O'Neil Foundation for the Art of the Painted Finish. A private memorial service is being planned.

abstract: BabyBox.com, Brooklyn-based Web site, specializes in gifts for newborns to 12-month-old babies (S)
snippet: BabyBox.com, Brooklyn-based Web site, specializes in gifts for newborns to 12-month-old babies (S)
lead_paragraph: BabyBox.com opened its Web site, specializing in gifts for newborn to 12-month-old babies, on Dec. 7. Featuring 36 ''shopping aisles'' with baby items ranging from teether rattles ($8.95) to grand Alsatian bassinets ($615-720), BabyBox.com, based in Brooklyn, consolidates on one site (www.babybox.com) a selection of upscale goods that would normally require a trip to many boutiques.

abstract: Robert Byrne column notes that National Chess Congress, held in Philadephia from Nov 22 to 28, finished with four-grandmaster tie for first place; says Joel Benjamin, Aleksandr Goldin, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Ivanov were each awarded $1,425; diagram (M)
snippet: Robert Byrne column notes that National Chess Congress, held in Philadephia from Nov 22 to 28, finished with four-grandmaster tie for first place; says Joel Benjamin, Aleksandr Goldin, Alexander Shabalov and Alexander Ivanov were each awarded $1,4...
lead_paragraph: The National Chess Congress, held in Philadelphia from Nov. 22 to 28, finished with a four-grandmaster tie for first place. Joel Benjamin of Manhattan, Aleksandr Goldin of Russia, Alexander Ivanov of Brookline, Mass., and Alexander Shabalov of Pittsburgh each scored 5-1 in the 84-entrant, Swiss-system event and each was awarded a prize of $1,425. No tiebreak coefficients were used. The tournament, run by the Continental Chess Association, was held at the Adam's Mark Hotel.
