abstract: OLAN-Susan Marie Torian. Died on December 22, 1999, at her home in Dallas. She lived an active life in Dallas, Austin, Madison, and New York as a writer and investigator. Above all else, Susan dedicated her life to fighting for justice and equality among races, nations, genders, and those of differing sexual orientations. Susan died confident that she had lived a life of integrity having done her best to make this world a better place. She is survived by her daughter, Anita Marie Olan, of Los Angeles, California; her aunt Minerva Quinlan of Hingham, Massachusetts; and her brother, Philip Torian, of Dallas, Texas.

abstract: Back-to-back storms with gale force winds that reached 120 miles per hour ripped through France and other parts of Europe. The French Ministry of Culture and Communication said it would take more than $60 million just to repair damage to historic monuments like Notre Dame Cathedral, Ste.-Chapelle and the palace at Versailles.    The storms tore off roofs, toppled thousands of trees and caused flooding and avalanches that killed at least 130 people throughout Europe, 78 of them in France. More than a quarter of Frances electric grid was damaged. One insurance company said the cost of repairing damages from the storms would reach $5 billion.   SUZANNE DALEY
lead_paragraph: Back-to-back storms with gale force winds that reached 120 miles per hour ripped through France and other parts of Europe. abstract: shop talk: w
snippet: shop talk: w
lead_paragraph: Carlson: I never thought of Meg as someone who had a cause or thought of herself as a woman in journalism or a feminist. I saw Meg as just pure journalist, competing on the same ground. I don't like to admit it, but I got breaks. I was coming along at a time when people wanted to hire women, and I wouldn't call it affirmative action exactly, but in some ways it was. Meg never had any of that. But Meg needed to get to be where she was for me to able to think that I could get where I am.

abstract: CLOSE-Mary ''Molly'' G.., 94, of Niantic, CT, died Dec. 22, 1999, at her home. Miss Close was born in London, England on September 14, 1905, the daughter of Ralph Tompkins and Margaret Godfrey Close. She grew up in Westwood, NJ and moved to Niantic in 1965. She was a graduate of Westwood (NJ) High School & Arnold College of Hygiene & Physical Education and New York University. She taught at St. Xavier's Academy in Latrobe, PA., Thomas E. Bayard School in Wilmington, DE., St. Joseph College in Brooklyn, NY, and taught for 30 years at Bay Ridge High School in Brooklyn until she retired. Donations may be made to St. Agnes Church, 16 Haigh Avenue, Niantic, CT. or to the East Lyme Library, Society Road, Niantic, CT. 06357.

abstract: Best Bet      When it comes to win-win situations, the Islip Arts Council's annual Winter Chamber Music Series can't be topped. Talented young professional musicians get to perform (and be paid for their efforts), often trying out programs they will later play in New York City venues, and Long Island audiences get to attend significant concerts in lovely settings for a very appealing price -- all the events are free. The newest edition of the series begins today at 2 p.m. in the Carriage House at Bayard Cutting Arboretum in Oakdale. The Azure Chamber Ensemble, consisting of Susan Glaser, flutist; Leo Suzuki, violist; and Jennifer Hoult, harpist, offers a program featuring the Debussy ''Trio.''

abstract: SoHo cute, Cafe Eclectic is busiest after the movies let out on weekend nights but rarely is it empty. Its lush yard sale decor - 20 mismatched tables a hodgepodge of chairs and a clutch of crushed velvet sofas - keeps this coffeehouse true to its name and entirely comfortable in a ''Sunset Boulevard'' kind of way.    ''I used to hang out in New York cafes a lot, and I always wanted to open a cafe of my own'' says Julio Valentin Jr., 30, the owner, who has a fairly eclectic past himself. He grew up in Newark, where he still lives, joined the Army after graduating from high school and then the Newark Police Department. ''While I was an officer, I did a lot of reading about business and I researched cafes.''
lead_paragraph: SoHo cute, Cafe Eclectic is busiest after the movies let out on weekend nights but rarely is it empty. abstract: Sending a harsh message to followers of the Falun Gong spiritual movement, Chinese authorities gave prison sentences ranging from 7 to 18 years to three men and a woman who were said to be top organizers. Last summer the government declared the group an ''evil cult'' after 10,000 members mounted an illegal demonstration in Beijing.     Two of the sentences -- 18 years for one defendant and 16 years for another -- were stiffer than those meted out to democracy advocates in the last several years, a sign of how frightened the government is of a movement that has attracted millions of citizens.   ERIK ECKHOLM
lead_paragraph: Sending a harsh message to followers of the Falun Gong spiritual movement, Chinese authorities gave prison sentences ranging from 7 to 18 years to three men and a woman who were said to be top organizers. abstract: Barbara Noel Weady, the daughter of Sherry Brown of Hartford and Louis Weady of Guilford, Conn., was married on Friday to Matthew John Hennessy, a son of Mary Frances Hennessy and Judge Francis X. Hennessy of West Hartford, Conn. The Rev. Andrew Giardino performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Patrick and St. Anthony in Hartford.    The bride, 30, will continue to use her name professionally. She is an associate at Shipman & Goodwin, a law firm in Hartford. She graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University and received her law degree with honors from the University of Connecticut. She is a director of the Colonial Theater Renaissance Corporation, which promotes neighborhood revitalization on the west side of Hartford. Her mother works in Hartford as the state director and campaign manager for United States Senator Joseph I. Lieberman. Her father owns the Royal Printing Service in Guilford.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Noel Weady, the daughter of Sherry Brown of Hartford and Louis Weady of Guilford, Conn., was married on Friday to Matthew John Hennessy, a son of Mary Frances Hennessy and Judge Francis X. snippet: Terry Teachout reviews Michael John LaChiusa's Marie Christine at Vivian Beaumont Theater; describes work as opear, even though LaChiusa himself specified it be advertised as 'a new musical'; photo of Audra McDonald in title role (M)
lead_paragraph: THE neon sign in front of the Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center calls Michael John LaChiusa's ''Marie Christine'' ''a new musical.'' So do all the posters. Whether or not Mr. LaChiusa specifically requested that the show be advertised in this way, there can be little doubt that he approves, since he recently wrote an essay for Arts & Leisure in which he firmly stated that ''Marie Christine'' was a musical, not an opera.

abstract: Daphne Merkin article on her
snippet: Daphne Merkin article on her
lead_paragraph: My father died last March, at the age of 91, in his own bed, surrounded by his family; it was a sober, patriarchal, even old-world death, befitting his life. He had been ailing for close to two years, from heart failure and then lymphoma, but it still came as a surprise to see him yielding at last instead of rallying, as he had so many times before. My mother took the most extraordinary care of him, which included packing him off to the office for a few hours every day, right up until the week of his death. I rarely visited my father at his office, where he worked as an investment banker, but I knew that its ongoing affairs were more crucial to him, in many ways, than the life he led at home -- just as I knew that his public face as a philanthropist was easier to read than his private face as a father or husband. My father was an Orthodox Jew who had grown up in Leipzig, Germany; he remained committed to Jewish causes until his death, and his knowledge of the dizzying intricacies of Israeli politics was impressive. Throughout his life my father supported Jewish scholarship; he also helped endow the kosher kitchen at Mount Sinai, as well as the Merkin Concert Hall on West 67th Street (which is silent from Friday at sundown to Saturday at sundown, in observance of the Sabbath).

abstract: June Pusbach O'Neill discusses her book The Great New England Sea Serpent, and how she came to champion legendary creature that reportedly has haunted waters off New England for more than three centuries; interview; photo (M)
snippet: June Pusbach O'Neill discusses her book The Great New England Sea Serpent, and how she came to champion legendary creature that reportedly has haunted waters off New England for more than three centuries; interview; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN June Pusbach O'Neill tells people that she has written a book about the New England sea serpent, she usually gets a blank stare in reply, one that seems to say: ''Oh, you pathetic soul. Is that what you are doing with your life?'' But Mrs. O'Neill just laughs about it. The reaction comes with the territory, of course; few topics rank as high on the ridicule meter as sea serpents.

snippet: Joan Chatfield-Taylor article on colorful festival of Virgin of Candelaria, held each January in Puno, on shores of Peru's Lake Titicaca; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: IN January, the rains turn Peru's high plains into a river of silvery green grass, flowing between mountainous outcroppings and an occasional jumble of dun-colored adobe and cinder block buildings. In this muted landscape, it was pure surrealism to drive into a town called Ayaviri and find almost everyone in bear costumes, spangled drum-majorette dresses, silver and black matador suits or many-skirted dresses and shawls of cut velvet and damask.

lead_paragraph: For the 1960's hedonist baby boomer turned early-to-bed parent of the 80's and 90's, the work and life of Shel Silverstein form a seminal developmental frame. abstract: Clifton Brown article offers global predictions for future of golf in 21st century (M)
snippet: Clifton Brown article offers global predictions for future of golf in 21st century (M)
lead_paragraph: Basketball players added muscles and multimillion-dollar sneaker contracts. American yachts lost the America's Cup, gained it back, then lost it again. Grass all but disappeared on tennis courts. The natural stuff almost became extinct in baseball and football before injuries and nostalgia spurred its comeback. Lights finally shone at Wrigley Field. Europe became a major talent pool for the National Hockey League; golf and tennis benefited from America's diversity. What could happen next, on and off the field? A look at nine sports.

abstract: west meets east**A
snippet: west meets east**A
lead_paragraph: In China, Grace Zia Chu had been a gym teacher; in 1950's America, she became Madame Chu, a well-known Chinese-cooking expert whose Manhattan cooking classes and cookbooks initiated a whole generation of Americans in the mysteries of the stir-fry. Today, we are struck by the enormous gulf that Madame Chu sought to span and by the tone with which she spanned it: she opens her groundbreaking 1962 cookbook, ''The Pleasures of Chinese Cooking,'' with the tremendous poise of an ambassador. ''We Chinese,'' she begins, ''like to think of cooking as a distinctive art form.''

abstract: Israeli artist Udi Aloni creates wallscapes that display commercial advertisements on New York City buildings; wallscapes, unlike painted billboards, are printed via disk onto vinyl mesh material and hung flat like posters against sides of buildings; Aloni photo (M)
snippet: Israeli artist Udi Aloni creates wallscapes that display commercial advertisements on New York City buildings; wallscapes, unlike painted billboards, are printed via disk onto vinyl mesh material and hung flat like posters against sides of buildin...
lead_paragraph: When he stands on 42nd Street in Manhattan, Udi Aloni can see his ideas towering over the milling crowds. And with his photo-crisp advertisements for Apple Computer, the Gap, Old Navy and DKNY looming 40 feet high on the faces of skyscrapers, there is no question that Mr. Aloni, a 40-year-old Israeli artist, is making an impression on the Big Apple. From 10th Avenue to Broadway, Mr. Aloni's huge, high-resolution signs, called wallscapes, overlook every intersection.

abstract: Segal Co, in it annual executive compensation report on companies with more up to $200 million in revenue, finds most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as predomninant form of long-term incentives (S)
snippet: Segal Co, in it annual executive compensation report on companies with more up to $200 million in revenue, finds most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as predomninant form of long-term incentives (S)
lead_paragraph: For some executives, a yearly compensation package that includes a cash bonus must seem positively quaint. These days, most chief executives are asking for and receiving stock options as the predominant form of long-term incentives, according to Howard B. Goldsmith, vice president at the Segal Company, a human relations consulting concern in Manhattan. In its annual executive compensation report on companies with up to $200 million in revenue, Segal found that the stock-option warriors -- those whose compensation came primarily from stock options -- were in the high-technology area.

abstract: Letter from Robert Goldenberg comments on issue of single-sex swim times at town-owned pool in West Hempstead (S)
snippet: Letter from Robert Goldenberg comments on issue of single-sex swim times at town-owned pool in West Hempstead (S)
lead_paragraph: Discussing the request for single-sex swim times at a town-owned pool in West Hempstead, Lee Boyar wrote [letter, Dec. 26] that accommodation of such a request ''would also be inappropriate if the religious practice [possibly motivating the request] were imbued with ultra-conservative belief about women.'' The request may be sound or unsound, and granting the request may be wise or unwise, but surely the decision cannot be based on the political correctness of the beliefs held by those who made the request! I cannot think of any grounds for resolving this matter that would be more ''inappropriate'' than that.

abstract: Preview of new styles for new millennium, featuring vulgarity, ornamentation, extravagance and frippery; photos (M)
snippet: Preview of new styles for new millennium, featuring vulgarity, ornamentation, extravagance and frippery; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: PAPER magazine, the guide to downtown fashion and night life, has always been a reliable index of what's next. So when the magazine gave a book party to toast ''Abfab to Zen: Paper's Guide to Pop Culture'' not long ago, it was notable that the editors chose not a grungy club on Rivington Street but the newly renovated Russian Tea Room. Guests mingled in the eye-befuddling interior, decorated with mirrors, mosaics, a 15-foot revolving see-through bear filled with live fish and a gold tree laden with Faberge-inspired eggs. ''It was a bar mitzvah in Las Vegas,'' said Kim Hastreiter, a co-editor of Paper, who is planning an article for the March issue on the new vulgarity.

abstract: STEINAM-William N. ''Bill''. A Greenwich, CT. resident, died on December 23, 1999 at Greenwich Hospital in his 95th year. Born April 26, 1904 in New York City, he was a son of the late Joseph and Edna Foster Steinam. He attended Harvard University and was an expert in commercial real estate. He is survived by two daughters, Ellen S. Mellis of Stamford, CT., and Margot Barron of Sonoma, CA., and three grandchildren. He was predeceased by his wife, Catharine Stein Steinam.

abstract: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they did not even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper. But they made a difference in the way they lived. And they made a difference in Westchester, where they lived.     Some were young, just in their 40's. Others had 90 or more years to make their mark. Some of their accomplishments were very public. Others were very private. Many were teachers at heart, even if they never set foot in a classroom or made a formal lesson plan.

abstract: GLUCK-Samuel E.. A mining geologist, engineer, and philosopher. Age 74, on December 31, 1999. Survived by wife Phyllis Gold Gluck; sons Josiah, Theodore and Sebastian; sister-in-law Zina Gold Stern (Dr. Ernest Stern); and cousins. BA Ohio State; Colorado School of Mines; Ph.D. in Philosophy, Columbia. Professorships included Hofstra; College of Mount Saint Vincent. An industrial consultant in heavy industry. His publications and lectures, here and abroad, were fiery and humorous. He also inspired non-traditional students to fulfill their ambitions and dreams. Fair minded, ethical, championing safety and workers' rights through testimony and writing. An extraordinary person, kind and compassionate who loved his family deeply. His affection for Columbia never wavered, and he often said that if he were not a Jew he would want to be buried in the crypt of St. Paul's Chapel on campus. Services Sunday, January 2, 11:15 AM, Plaza Memorial, Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street).

lead_paragraph: Fred Saigh, a former owner of the St. Louis Cardinals who was forced out of baseball in 1953 when he was sentenced to federal prison for income-tax evasion but kept the team in St. Louis by selling it to the locally based Anheuser-Busch brewery, died Wednesday at a hospital in Chesterfield, Mo. He was 94.

abstract: Amy Noelle Francetic, a daughter of Irene Francetic of Racine, Wis., and the late John Francetic, was married last evening to Jason Arthur Rubinstein, the son of Leslie and Paul Rubinstein of New York. The Rev. Kelly Denton-Borhaug, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony, with Rabbi Charles Familant taking part, at the Memorial Church of Stanford University in Stanford, Calif.    Ms. Francetic, 33, is keeping her name. She is the chief executive and an owner of Zowie Entertainment, a company in San Mateo, Calif., that makes toys that can be operated through personal computers. She graduated from Stanford. Her father was a plant manager for the Western Publishing Company in Racine.

lead_paragraph: Contrary to what is stated in the Dec. 19 article, ''A New Church, but Some Old Resentments,'' the 225-seat St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Center Moriches was not torn down to make way for a parking lot. abstract: Mike Wise article offers predictions for future of basketball in 21st century (M)
snippet: Mike Wise article offers predictions for future of basketball in 21st century (M)
lead_paragraph: Basketball players added muscles and multimillion-dollar sneaker contracts. American yachts lost the America's Cup, gained it back, then lost it again. Grass all but disappeared on tennis courts. The natural stuff almost became extinct in baseball and football before injuries and nostalgia spurred its comeback. Lights finally shone at Wrigley Field. Europe became a major talent pool for the National Hockey League; golf and tennis benefited from America's diversity. What could happen next, on and off the field? A look at nine sports.

abstract: Ariel Swartley comment on recent World Festival of Sacred Music, held in Los Angeles; photos; event was first of five multiethnic, ecosensitive millennial celebrations planned around world, under aegis of Dalai Lama (M)
snippet: Ariel Swartley comment on recent World Festival of Sacred Music, held in Los Angeles; photos; event was first of five multiethnic, ecosensitive millennial celebrations planned around world, under aegis of Dalai Lama (M)
lead_paragraph: IT is a somewhat surreal experience at any time, the slow, almost noiseless ascent via electric tram from the Getty Center's mandatory off-street parking, up a long dry incline peppered with imported greenery, to the museum's isolated hillside perch. Even more so on a recent night, midway through the American segment of the World Festival of Sacred Music -- the first of five pan-ecumenic, multiethnic and ecosensitive celebrations planned under the aegis of the Dalai Lama to take place on consecutive continents in the coming millennial months. Behind us, vistas of city lights unfolded like star maps. High above, the museum's floodlit walls glowed celestially white against the blackness. I was reminded -- Hollywood, after all, lay just beyond the freeway -- of all those comedies, wishfully divine, in which heaven is accessed by up-to-the minute forms of transportation.

abstract: Kristin Lee Buckler, the daughter of Linda L. Buckler and Norman F. Buckler of Scottsdale, Ariz., was married on Thursday to Dr. Gilbert Darin Anthony Padula, the son of Dr. Tatiana Capone Padula of Rochester Hills, Mich., and the late Gilbert N. Padula. The Rev. Robert Schuster performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at St. Hugo of the Hills Church in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.    Mrs. Padula, 24, is a student at New York Law School. She graduated from Oakland University. Her parents work in Scottsdale, her father as the western regional sales manager for Synthesys Technologies, which develops medical software, and her mother as a contract analyst for the Franchise Finance Corporation of America.

abstract: Frank Ric
snippet: Frank Ric
lead_paragraph: The two most famous fictional TV news anchormen of the 1970's -- Ted Baxter of ''The Mary Tyler Moore Show'' and Howard Beale of ''Network'' -- may not have been directly inspired by Jim Jensen, but they could have been. Jensen, who worked at WCBS from 1964 to 1995, was the very model of a modern local newsman. With his deep Midwestern baritone, rangy good looks and a humorless, macho manner that suggested he could reach out of the tube and slug someone, he laid down the news with the authority of -- well, if not God, then at least Charlton Heston at full Old Testament throttle.

abstract: In a vivid reminder that many people along the Texas-Mexico border regard the region as one country instead of two, the mayors of Laredo and its Mexican sister city, Nuevo Laredo, walked across a bridge above the Rio Grande shortly before the new year arrived and celebrated the new millennium with an international hug and a kiss. snippet: D Dominick Lombardi reviews photography exhibit at Macy Pavilion of Westchester Medical Center; photos (M)
lead_paragraph: ART can have a positive effect on one's soul. This can easily be overlooked or disfavored, especially at a time when the most offensive or provoking works are getting most of the attention. One institution in particular, the Gallery at the Macy Pavilion at Westchester Medical Center here, believes in ''nurturing the spirit'' through beauty and selects works for exhibition accordingly.

abstract: Interview with movie director Tim Robbins on ventriloquism in light of 1999 death of ventriloquist Senor Wences; photo (M)
snippet: Interview with movie director Tim Robbins on ventriloquism in light of 1999 death of ventriloquist Senor Wences; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Q: Your new film includes an aging ventriloquist. What accounted for the heyday of that now-overlooked genre? Did ventriloquism ever have a heyday? Seriously, I think what worked for the really popular ventriloquists, like Senor Wences and Edgar Bergen, is that the puppet had high disregard for the manipulator -- the nastiness that goes back and forth that's mostly directed toward the ventriloquist. Probably mischievousness is a better word. The funny thing about Edgar Bergen, of course, is that he was a radio star. Think about that -- a ventriloquist who was a radio star.

abstract: Herbert Muschamp review criticizes building at One Union Square as example of use of public art to cover up for uninspired buildings; calls on Municipal Art Society to reconsider effects of unhappy consortium of art, architecture and real estate development in New York; photos of ten-story artwork, Metronome, at base of building and sculpture of giant hand protruding into space (M)
snippet: Herbert Muschamp review criticizes building at One Union Square as example of use of public art to cover up for uninspired buildings; calls on Municipal Art Society to reconsider effects of unhappy consortium of art, architecture and real estate d...
lead_paragraph: ONE UNION SQUARE SOUTH fails on three counts. The architecture is big and boring, the artwork glued to its main facade is pretentious, and the thinking that joined the two is out of date. This is the worst example yet seen of a formula that has helped to drain the life out of New York architecture in recent years: the use of public art to cover up for uninspired buildings. What we also have here is a crisis for the Municipal Art Society, the venerable civic organization that brokered this unhappy consortium of art, architecture and real estate development. If anything of value can be salvaged from this failure, it is the opportunity to examine the circumstances from which it arose.

abstract: Cofiroute, biggest French private highway operator, has brought its innovative techniques to Orange County, Calif, in experiment to privately finance road construction by building pay lanes down median of freeway; project, for which Cofiroute provided technological knowledge and $135 million in financing, lets motorists pass from toll-free lanes to pay lanes with help of an automated toll-collection plan that is similar to E-ZPass; in addition Cofiroute has introduced different rates according to time of day and day of week--system that is also being studied by other toll-road operators; highway, built on Riverside Freeway, is called 91 Express Lanes; it is first in country to compete with an adjacent public road; California project is example of how companies that build and operate roads are looking for new sources of revenue and new ways to enhance traditional revenue sources; photo of Route 91 (L)

abstract: For Eyes, discount eye chain, moves its sole Manhattan outlet to larger space (S)
snippet: For Eyes, discount eye chain, moves its sole Manhattan outlet to larger space (S)
lead_paragraph: For Eyes, a discount eyewear store with 124 locations nationwide, moved its sole Manhattan location from a shared space on West 23rd Street to a 10,000-square-foot showplace at 420 Lexington Avenue (between 43rd and 44th Streets) two months ago. Like the stores in Miami, Boston and Chicago, the New York For Eyes features frames by designers like Calvin Klein, Cynthia Rowley and Kenneth Cole, at discount prices. Their frames are sold with the proper lens as a complete set, starting at $59.95.

abstract: Steve Martin article reviews history and achievements, dubious and otherwise, of last one thousand years, and start of third millennium, or, as Martin suggests, the second millennium again, since it starts with two anyway; drawings (M)
snippet: Steve Martin article reviews history and achievements, dubious and otherwise, of last one thousand years, and start of third millennium, or, as Martin suggests, the second millennium again, since it starts with two anyway; drawings (M)
lead_paragraph: FOR me, and I assume for most of you -- since whatever I'm thinking so too is the nation -- it was difficult to know exactly what to celebrate on Dec. 31, 1999. Do I celebrate the end of the year, the end of the 20th century or the end of the millennium? I chose the one remaining option, and therefore I assume so did most of you: the end of the day. This made for significantly reduced partying intensity. However, waking up on Saturday, knowing that Friday was now over, I felt compelled to write about the past 2,000 years and the changes that would be wrought in this new age. This was indeed a challenge to me as I desired to write the history of humankind, past, present and future, without bothering to do any research.

abstract: Interview with June Pusbach O'Neill, author of The Great New England Sea Serpent; she is also amateur historian, whose book is about sea serpent that has reportedly haunted waters off New England for more than three centuries; photo (M)
snippet: Interview with June Pusbach O'Neill, author of The Great New England Sea Serpent; she is also amateur historian, whose book is about sea serpent that has reportedly haunted waters off New England for more than three centuries; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: WHEN June Pusbach O'Neill tells people that she has written a book about the New England sea serpent, she usually gets a blank stare in reply, one that seems to say: ''Oh, you pathetic soul. Is that what you are doing with your life?'' But Mrs. O'Neill just laughs about it. The reaction comes with the territory, of course; few topics rank as high on the ridicule meter as sea serpents.

abstract: Joe Lapointe article offers global predictions for future of hockey in 21st century; drawing (M)
snippet: Joe Lapointe article offers global predictions for future of hockey in 21st century; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: Basketball players added muscles and multimillion-dollar sneaker contracts. American yachts lost the America's Cup, gained it back, then lost it again. Grass all but disappeared on tennis courts. The natural stuff almost became extinct in baseball and football before injuries and nostalgia spurred its comeback. Lights finally shone at Wrigley Field. Europe became a major talent pool for the National Hockey League; golf and tennis benefited from America's diversity. What could happen next, on and off the field? A look at nine sports.

abstract: Prominent New Yorkers, past and present, are asked whether city will lose its edge or even become unnecessary in the increasingly technological 21st century or whether it will continue to be a magnet for talent and an incubator of progress; comments from Jane Jacobs, Felix G Rohatyn, Drew Nieporent, Luc Sante, Rev Calvin O Butts 3d, Vartan Gregorian, Jane Friedman, Leonard S Riggio, Ada Louise Huxtable, George E Rupp, Dr Arnold J Levine, the historian Mike Wallace, Robert A Caro, Judith Jamison, Graciala Daniele, Shelly Lazarus, Nathan Leventhal and Lorne Michaels; photos; drawing (L)
snippet: Prominent New Yorkers, past and present, are asked whether city will lose its edge or even become unnecessary in the increasingly technological 21st century or whether it will continue to be a magnet for talent and an incubator of progress; commen...
lead_paragraph: NEW YORK came of age when all that was new seemed to flow from the city, when crowded streets and the world's tallest building were matters of civic pride. Like all great cities in their times, New York thrived in the 20th century because it was a place where the energetic and the talented -- many from distant lands -- gathered to form a critical mass. It was the quintessential modern city, unrivaled in America, if not the world.

abstract: REESE-William W.. The Officers, Directors and Members of the New England Society in the City of New York greatly mourn the sudden and untimely passing of our devoted president-elect, William W. Reese. As a member and director for many years, he gave caringly and unselfishly to the Society. Our deep condolences to his beloved wife, Sonia, and the entire family. Cornelia H. Greenspan, President New England Society in the City of New York     REESE-William Willis, II. The Order of Colonial Lords of Manors in America expresses shock and deep sorrow at the death of our dedicated treasurer and dear friend, William Willis Reese, II, and sends its deepest sympathy to his widow, Sonia, his mother, and the rest of his family. Timothy Field Beard, President Joseph Kerr Pistell, Secretary     REESE-William W. The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York deeply mourns the loss of our newly elected Governor. A devoted member and benefactor since 1975. The Society will sorely miss our dear friend. M. David Sherrill, Deputy Governor James B. Gardiner II, Secretary     REESE-William W. The Huguenot Society of America records with deep sorrow the death of William W. Reese, a member since 1979, a Life Member since 1997, and a former President of the Society. Courtney A. Haff, President

abstract: Child support collections in New York reach $1 billion for 1999, 62 percent increase over record set in 1994 (S)
snippet: Child support collections in New York reach $1 billion for 1999, 62 percent increase over record set in 1994 (S)
lead_paragraph: As of Dec. 21, child support collections for 1999 reached $1 billion, a 62 percent increase over the $617 million collected by the state in 1994. The previous annual record was set last year when $933 million was collected, Gov. George E. Pataki's office said.

abstract: WELL, we survived.    If you remember back to the 1900's, it was touch and go. Or so it seemed. People feared something called Y2K. Terrorists abounded. Others thought time would expire with a bang.    Then there was a silent majority secretly hoping for a kind of inverse Y2K, a time-as-panacea where rather than all life's conveniences going haywire, all of life's little annoyances, from telemarketers to catalog profusion, would mysteriously clear up. It would be, as the joke goes, like playing country and western music backward: You'd get out of jail. Your dog would come back to life. Your wife would return. Your pickup would run smoothly.
lead_paragraph: WELL, we survived.

abstract: On the Street photos of some of 1999's curious fashion ideas (S)
snippet: On the Street photos of some of 1999's curious fashion ideas (S)
lead_paragraph: With fashion so unpredictable, it's risky to project what the 2000's may have in store. But here are a few of 1999's most provocative styles that may just prove influential. The year had its share of curious ideas (right), from sequined dresses over jeans for day to the mixing of clothes by different designers to the revival of brash color, as in this ensemble of trash bags.

abstract: Paul Griffiths comment on violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, who will perform with New York Philharmonic, playing works written for her by threecomposers; photo (M)
snippet: Paul Griffiths comment on violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter, who will perform with New York Philharmonic, playing works written for her by threecomposers; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THERE are ways other than recording for musicians to make sure that something of their personalities survives them: they can get themselves written into solo pieces or concertos. During a two-week stay with the New York Philharmonic beginning on Thursday at Avery Fisher Hall, the violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter will play works written for her by Witold Lutoslawski, Wolfgang Rihm and Krzysztof Penderecki, as well as more familiar 20th-century concertos by Sibelius, Berg and Bernstein. So here is a chance to hear how three prominent composers have created their own images of this extraordinarily dynamic, technically superb and expressive artist.

abstract: NEUHOFF-John R.. Of New York, New York, and Annapolis, MD, on December 28th, 1999, at age 75. Beloved husband of 50 years to Mary Hunter Neuhoff. Devoted father fo Christopher of New York, NY, Elizabeth Neuhoff Doughty (Richard) of Arnold, MD, Jerome (Katherine) of New York, New York, Cortland (Leslie Greene Bauman) of Winterthur, DE, and John (Patricia) of New York, NY. Adoring grandfather to Cara, Haley & Maya. Dear brother of Roger A. Neuhoff. Grateful to Rosetta Holmes, faithful helper for over 40 years. His love will remain in our hearts always. abstract: Perlman Music Program, school for gifted young musicians, will move to Shelter Island, NY; original plan to move to Sagaponack was shelved after vociferous opposition from some neighbors there (S)
snippet: Perlman Music Program, school for gifted young musicians, will move to Shelter Island, NY; original plan to move to Sagaponack was shelved after vociferous opposition from some neighbors there (S)
lead_paragraph: The Perlman Music Program, a school for gifted young musicians, has found a new home, but it won't be in Sagaponack. Instead, the program plans to move to Shelter Island, where it is under contract to buy the Peconic Lodge, a waterfront hotel, for $3 million. Subject to approval by the town Zoning Board of Appeals, which has to consider a zoning-change application, the purchase could go through by spring, putting the program in its new home this summer.

abstract: science fiction's final frontier, perhaps*
snippet: science fiction's final frontier, perhaps*
lead_paragraph: Even if humankind hasn't traveled beyond Earth's moon, our television transmissions have. And somewhere in the far reaches of the galaxy some alien race may be settling down in front of a viewing module getting ready to enjoy the adventures of the Starship Enterprise, only to find -- to their green-skinned horror -- that ''Star Trek'' or some other favorite science-fiction series has been unceremoniously canceled because of low ratings.

abstract: Boot camps for teenage criminals, idea much in vogue in recent years, have closed down in several states, amid increasing evidence that they have not worked; photo (M)
snippet: Boot camps for teenage criminals, idea much in vogue in recent years, have closed down in several states, amid increasing evidence that they have not worked; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: FIVE years ago, responding to an increase in serious juvenile crime, the state of Maryland initiated one of the nation's largest boot camp programs for teenage criminals. The program, called the Leadership Challenge, quickly became the model for other states. But last week, after reviewing a task force report that documented instances of physical abuse at their camps, Maryland officials appeared on the verge of conceding that the current initiative was a failure.

abstract: Comment on The Play's the Thing, Ferenc Molnar play which will be staged by New Jersey Rep at Lumia Theater in Long Branch, NJ, beginning January 7; cast getting instruction on pronunciation of Hungarian words in play (S)
snippet: Comment on The Play's the Thing, Ferenc Molnar play which will be staged by New Jersey Rep at Lumia Theater in Long Branch, NJ, beginning January 7; cast getting instruction on pronunciation of Hungarian words in play (S)
lead_paragraph: How do you say the name Sandor Turai like a Hungarian? Remember to click the r. ''And the ai is like oy,'' said Anne Vaughan, director of developement at New Jersey Rep in Long Branch. So much for Turai. As for Sandor, just say Shandor. Mrs. Vaughan, whose husband, Stuart Vaughan, is staging ''The Play's the Thing,'' which opens Friday at the company's Lumia Theater, was overhearing such pointers on pronunciation, freshly imparted by the executive producer, Gabor Barabas, who was born in Budapest. Budapesht, that is.

abstract: Portable packs of fragrance noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)
snippet: Portable packs of fragrance noted; photo (Pulse column) (S)
lead_paragraph: For those who can't commit to wearing a single scent for an entire day, L'Artisan Parfumeur personal sachets may do the trick. These portable packs of fragrance resemble shimmering silk tea bags and are filled with tiny perfumed beads. They're designed to be tucked into a shirt pocket, tied in the hair or thrown into a pocketbook. (They can also be used more conventionally in a dresser drawer or closet.) Marie Dumont, the company's creative director, said the goal was maximum aromatic versatility: wearers can switch scents at will. And the personal sachets also work for people with sensitive skin, who don't react well to direct application of perfumes or colognes. In addition to the spicy fragrance found in the tea bags, L'Artisan also offers small rectangular sachets in amber and blackberry scents, with colorful silk tassels intended to dangle outside a breast pocket. Prices are $10 each for the tea bags and $25 to $35 for the sachets. The first sachets arrived at Barneys New York last week, sold out and are on reorder. Have scratch, will sniff. ELLEN TIEN

abstract: For years, advocates for bicycle riders have urged the city to build a special ''fly-over'' ramp on the Manhattan side of the Queensboro Bridge to give cyclists and pedestrians easy access between the bridge and Second Avenue and points south. Now the city, which rejected the idea four years ago, plans to seek money for the $500,000 project.    In the fall, the Department of Transportation applied for money from the federal government to build the ramp, while the bridge is being renovated. But the financing was denied.

abstract: Profound demographic change facing Europe with influx of immigrants discussed; photo; traditionally homogeneous peoples may have to tolerate ethnic and racial newcomers in order to survive economically, given downturn in its own population growth (M)
snippet: Profound demographic change facing Europe with influx of immigrants discussed; photo; traditionally homogeneous peoples may have to tolerate ethnic and racial newcomers in order to survive economically, given downturn in its own population growth ...
lead_paragraph: EUROPEANS, it often seems, spent the last decade building resentments of American fast food, pop culture, corporate callousness and military might -- when they were not importing or trying to emulate them. They ended the century thinking they had staked out the parameters of Americanization and could now concentrate on erecting barricades around their traditional larders, languages and societies. But some demographers have a big surprise in store.

lead_paragraph: By the time we crested the grassy knoll and started down the logging road, Bianca, an 8-year-old German shorthair retriever, looked thoroughly disgusted. She waited patiently on the trail, ready to dive into the brush and search for that singular and elusive game bird, woodcock. Her knitted brows and tensed legs conveyed the question: what on earth is taking you so long?

abstract: Description of items in National Millennium Time Capsule, which is to be opened in 2100; photo of prototype on display at Smithsonian's National Museum of American History; actual capsule will be in National Archives (M)
snippet: Description of items in National Millennium Time Capsule, which is to be opened in 2100; photo of prototype on display at Smithsonian's National Museum of American History; actual capsule will be in National Archives (M)
lead_paragraph: ''WE choose freedom because it gives us the power to live, learn and love,'' wrote students from Tanapag Elementary School in the Northern Mariana Islands, a U.S. Commonwealth in the western Pacific. Their essay, along with Ray Charles's sunglasses, photos of Earth from space, a Twinkie, Corningware, a computer chip, the Bill of Rights, a World War II helmet, a cell phone and a piece of the Berlin Wall will be among the items sealed this summer in the National Millennium Time Capsule until 2100.

abstract: Editorial on huge potential of electronic commerce, which is already reshaping retail markets
snippet: Editorial on huge potential of electronic commerce, which is already reshaping retail markets
lead_paragraph: At first glance, sales over the Internet do not look impressive, accounting for between 0.3 and 3 percent of retail sales. But a survey released last week by the Boston Consulting Group and Shop.org, the trade association of online retailers, shows that e-commerce during the holiday season has quadrupled since last year, the first Christmas season for which Internet sales were important. E-commerce looks poised to transform entire sectors of the economy.

abstract: Nureyev: His Life   By Diane Solway. Morrow, $16.    The author draws on extensive interviews and research to provide fresh material on the Russian dancer's life and career, particularly his Soviet years and his defection in 1961. This balanced biography is ''informative and filled with vivid anecdotes,'' Jennifer Dunning wrote here in 1998.    The Peculiar Memories of Thomas Penman   By Bruce Robinson. HarperPerennial, $13.    The hero of this darkly funny first novel by the writer and director of ''Withnail and I'' is a 13-year-old asthmatic schoolboy searching for identity as he copes with his exotically dysfunctional family in working-class England in the grim 1950's. He is an obsessive snooper, and what he's most keen to find is the key to his grandfather's extensive pornography collection. ''Never before has the painful, knotty journey to maturity been depicted with such gusto, and never has the venerable Bildungsroman received such riotously profane treatment,'' Patrick McGrath wrote here last year.    Secrecy: The American Experience   By Daniel Patrick Moynihan. Yale University, $10.95.    In this withering tour of nearly a century of official secrecy, the New York senator argues that the use of classified information and misinformation has caused much more harm than good. ''It is a dismaying tale,'' Sam Tanenhaus wrote here in 1998, though Moynihan tells it ''with uncommon liveliness and a mordant wit.'' In All the Laws but One: Civil Liberties in Wartime, by William H. Rehnquist (Vintage, $14), the chief justice of the United States reviews prominent cases in which civil liberties issues have arisen during times of war, from the 1860's to the internment of Japanese-Americans in World War II. ''Rehnquist presents full and fascinating human profiles'' and conveys ''what it must have been like to grapple with these issues in a time of crisis,'' Jeremy Waldron wrote here last year.    Ingratitude   By Ying Chen. University of California, $13.95.    This compact novel is narrated from the grave by a woman who committed suicide to punish her mother and thus escape the traditional Chinese culture of obedience. The result is ''a sustained philosophical exploration studded with passionate outbursts, a glimpse of a consciousness liberated from family and social expectations,'' Elizabeth Schmidt wrote here in 1998.    Ark Baby   By Liz Jensen. Overlook, $13.95.    This raucous, unruly novel is a satirical jab at Darwinism and the notion of scientific certainty through 150 years of British life, up to the early years of the new millennium, when a fertility crisis threatens the survival of Homo britannicus. '' 'Ark Baby' is written in an exuberantly naughty style that suggests Jensen shares a certain kinship with writers like Peter Carey and Fay Weldon,'' Alida Becker wrote here in 1998.    Hip Hop America   By Nelson George. Penguin, $13.95.    A New York music critic traces the evolution of rap music and its influence on culture and society, in the process chronicling his own intense love-hate relationship with hip-hop. In 1998 our reviewer, Laura Jamison, called this ''an invaluable, entertaining and well-written account.'' In Elevating the Game: Black Men and Basketball (University of Nebraska, $15), George explores the history of basketball and how the integration of black players from colleges around the nation advanced the game. The result is a ''folksy yet scholarly study'' and ''a rich, welcome addition to sports literature,'' Michael E. Ross wrote here in 1992.    Meetings With the Archangel: A Comedy of Spirit   By Stephen Mitchell. HarperPerennial, $13.    The celestial visitor in question stops by to deliver a primer on the afterlife and give the novel's narrator a chance to review his spiritual progress, as well as provide the author with an opportunity to display his religious learning. In 1998 our reviewer, David Guy, called this a ''fascinating and beautifully written'' book.    Joy of Man's Desiring   By Jean Giono. Counterpoint, $16.    This earthy French novel about the loves and toils of a group of peasants in the rugged, isolated hills of Provence is a pagan allegory about the fragile communion between man and nature. ''It is a beautiful story of renewal . . . set in terms of a kind of cosmic faith, and in a lovely and fearless imagery,'' Katherine Woods wrote here in 1940.    Canone Inverso   By Paolo Maurensig. Owl/Holt, $12.    This Italian novel, steeped in musical imagery and themes, revolves around a haunted 17th-century violin and its effect on the friendship of two boys in Central Europe during the 1930's. Last year our reviewer, Jonathan Keates, admired ''the mournful beauty of this sparely proportioned, soberly recounted story.''    The Grieving Time: A Year's Account of Recovery From Loss   By Anne M. Brooks. Herodias, $11.    This slender, heartfelt book is a monthly journal kept by the author after her husband's death from cancer. The ''entries are sometimes startling in their candor,'' one critic wrote in 1985. ''It will linger in the mind and give comfort'' for a long time.   Scott Veale

abstract: HSIEH-Jui Sheng, Ph.D.. Age 78, of Southport, CT, beloved husband of Mary Wang Hsieh, died on Thursday, December 30, 1999 in Bridgeport, CT. Born in China, he came to the U.S. in 1948 and had lived in Belle Mead, NJ for 22 years before moving to CT in 1998. Dr. Hsieh graduated from Wuhan University in China in 1943, and earned his Masters Degree in Mechanical Engineering from the University of Kentucky in 1950 and his Ph.D. from Ohio State in 1955. He taught at the University of Bridgeport, then at New Jersey Institute of Technology for 31 years until his retirement in 1991. He authored 3 text books, ''Principles of Thermodynamics'' (McGraw-Hill), ''Solar Energy Engineering'' (PrenticeHall), and ''Engineering Thermodynamics'' (Prentice-Hall), and was listed in the World and America editions of ''Who's Who.'' In addition to his devoted wife of 38 years, he is survived by a son Lawrence and his wife Janice; two daughters, Esther and her husband William, Vivian and her husband Tad; four grandchildren;, one brother, Chi Sheng Hsieh; a stepbrother, Dong Sheng Hsieh; a stepsister, Zhou Ru Hsieh; many nieces and nephews. Private services will be held in CT. Memorials can be made to: The Bridgeport Hospital's Medical I.C.U., 267 Grant St, Bridgeport, CT 06610.

abstract: David Hajdu artic
snippet: David Hajdu artic
lead_paragraph: The first time I saw the face of Evil, I was 8 or 9. It was a little after midnight, and I had sneaked out of the bedroom and felt my way into the basement, where my father kept an old black-and-white TV with a cracked wooden cabinet in his workshop. I clicked it on in the dark and froze in terror at a sight I had never seen upstairs before bedtime: a human monster, repulsive in a one-piece bodysuit, twirling a man over his head, cackling demonically. He was Gorilla Monsoon, the announcer said with a suitable tremor, and for some time I thought he existed only on a broken TV in the basement at night.

lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the director Norman Jewison misstated the title of the Charles Fuller play in which Mr. Jewison saw Denzel Washington perform. abstract: New Yorkers, concerned about Y2K computer problems and possibility of terrorist attack during New Year's Eve elebration in Times Square, awake to city that in year 2000's first hours looks and behaves pretty much way it did in 1999; things work and no terrorists intrude on gaiety; photo of city workers removing garbage in Times Square (M)

lead_paragraph: In the bleary afterglow of the pulsating mass party in Times Square, New Yorkers awoke yesterday to a city that in the year 2000's first hours of innocent youth looked and behaved pretty much the way it did in 1999. Things worked. The terrorists stayed home.

abstract: Benedict Nightingale reviews London stage productions of Alan Bennett's The Lady in the Van starring Maggie Smith, Nick Stafford's Battle Royal starring Simon Russell Beale and Zoe Wanamaker, and Michael Boyd's production of Midsummer Night's Dream at Barbican; scene photos (M)
snippet: Benedict Nightingale reviews London stage productions of Alan Bennett's The Lady in the Van starring Maggie Smith, Nick Stafford's Battle Royal starring Simon Russell Beale and Zoe Wanamaker, and Michael Boyd's production of Midsummer Night's Drea...
lead_paragraph: ALAN BENNETT has been much on the minds of British theatergoers of late. Two different actors, each complete with specs, floppy hair and mournful Yorkshire accent, perform the playwright himself in ''The Lady in the Van,'' the dramatic memoir he recently opened at the Queen's. The National Theater is staging ''Battle Royal,'' which is by the lesser-known Nick Stafford but has been widely seen as a sequel to Mr. Bennett's ''Madness of George III.'' We would not have been too astonished if the dramatist, who has occasionally appeared on the London stage in the past, had rematerialized as a melancholy sprite in the magnificently original ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' that the Royal Shakespeare Company is presenting at the Barbican.

abstract: Janet Malcolm article on Kurt Robert Eissler, psychoanalyst and author, who died in 1999; cites his role in preserving Sigmund Freud's work and thinking; photo (M)
snippet: Janet Malcolm article on Kurt Robert Eissler, psychoanalyst and author, who died in 1999; cites his role in preserving Sigmund Freud's work and thinking; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: In preparation for writing about the psychoanalyst, writer and scholar Kurt Robert Eissler, who died in February, I went to the library of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute to read the memorial tributes that colleagues traditionally put on record there. Eissler, who was born in Vienna and came to America in 1938 to escape Hitler, had been one of the institute's ornaments. He was the author of 12 books, among them ''Goethe: A Psychoanalytic Study'' and ''Talent and Genius: The Fictitious Case of Tausk Contra Freud.'' In addition to his writing and a full-time psychoanalytic practice, he created, and for many years single-handedly ran, the Sigmund Freud Archives, an enterprise designed to save from oblivion the scattered letters, photographs and papers of Freud, and to preserve the recollections of Freud's living colleagues, relatives and patients through tape-recorded interviews.

abstract: THE SPORTS WORLD OF THE 20TH CENTURY embraced everyone form Babe Ruth to Kobe Bryant. It was crammed with thrills and disappointments and was punctuated by the fantastic finishes that left millions of sports fans holding their breaths, always believing that it's not over till it's over and that somehow their heroes would win. Here are some snapshots of moments that brought tears of joy and despair.   BY CARL NELSON

abstract: Kevin Filipski reviews new DVD release of 1982 movie Pink Floyd the Wall; photo (M)
snippet: Kevin Filipski reviews new DVD release of 1982 movie Pink Floyd the Wall; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IN one of the strangest cinematic collaborations ever, the Pink Floyd lyricist Roger Waters, the animator Gerald Scarfe and the director Alan Parker famously butted heads during the making of ''Pink Floyd The Wall,'' the 1982 film adaptation of the British group's best-selling 1979 album ''The Wall,'' about the alienation and mental breakdown of a burnt-out rock star. The newly released 94-minute DVD (Columbia Music Video, $29.99) includes an accompanying documentary, ''Retrospective,'' in which the principals look back nearly two decades, bemused at the most unpleasant shoot.

abstract: Robert S Boynston article on Louise Patterson, New York leftist at center of African-American intellectual scene during final days of Harlem Renaissance, who died in 1999; Patterson led 1932 trip by black intellectuals and artists to Soviet Union; photo (M)
snippet: Robert S Boynston article on Louise Patterson, New York leftist at center of African-American intellectual scene during final days of Harlem Renaissance, who died in 1999; Patterson led 1932 trip by black intellectuals and artists to Soviet Union;...
lead_paragraph: What a sight they were, the 22 young African-American artists, writers, journalists and scholars who boarded the German steamer Europa on June 14, 1932, for an adventure in the Soviet Union. Still giddy from the gala send-off the night before in Harlem, they milled around the Brooklyn pier waiting for Langston Hughes, who at the last minute ran up the gangplank with a typewriter, Victrola and a boxful of Louis Armstrong records. Most of them had never been abroad, but now they were on their way to Moscow to make ''Black and White,'' a film about ''Negro life'' in America.

abstract: Editorial says Pres Yeltsin's sudden resignation shows once again why he will be remembered as practitioner of the unexpected political stratagem, betting that impulsive, bold move will turn Russia toward more promising future; sees powerful advantage for Acting Pres Vladimir Putin
snippet: Editorial says Pres Yeltsin's sudden resignation shows once again why he will be remembered as practitioner of the unexpected political stratagem, betting that impulsive, bold move will turn Russia toward more promising future; sees powerful advan...
lead_paragraph: In suddenly resigning as Russian president on Friday, Boris Yeltsin showed once again why he will be remembered as a practitioner of the unexpected political stratagem. Like so many of Mr. Yeltsin's gambits over the years, the move upended expectations and scrambled Russian politics. It also came with a promise of immunity from prosecution for Mr. Yeltsin for any misdeeds of his government. That will likely roil the coming presidential campaign, a fitting legacy for a courageous but disappointingly erratic man who guided Russia through the first years of a turbulent, still unfinished journey from tyranny to democracy.

abstract: Richard J Scholem reviews Shallot, Thai-Japanese restaurant in Lake Ronkonkoma, NY (M)
snippet: Richard J Scholem reviews Shallot, Thai-Japanese restaurant in Lake Ronkonkoma, NY (M)
lead_paragraph: SHALLOT is short on aesthetics and long on flavor and value. This unpretentious four-month-old Thai and Japanese storefront restaurant at 735 Hawkins Avenue in Lake Ronkonkoma (631-981-0303) serves tasty, inexpensive, often exotic dishes. Unlike most of its Chinese-Japanese restaurant counterparts, Shallot, with its Thai-Japanese staff and owners, represents both cuisines equally well; there are no weak sisters or junior partners.

Blue'' set at the 20th Century Fox studios, David Milch, the co-creator of the series, with Steven Bochco, sat on a wooden chair restlessly tapping his foot. snippet: Tongue-in-cheek look back at great events of 21st century; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: LONG ISLAND was a pretty dull place back in the 1900's. The most notable events were the opening of the Long Island Expressway in 1955, and the first Amy Fisher made-for-television movie in 1993. Fortunately, the 21st century has been much more dramatic. What's left of the Island has been transformed beyond Robert Moses's wildest dreams. Let's look back on some of the great events of the past hundred years.

abstract: KIRSCHMAN-Dorothy ''Dottie'' Freeman. Age 93, died peacefully at home on December 27 with her dear friend Betty Brown at her side. She was preceded in death by her husband Lewis Kirschman and her sisters, Irma Bacharach and Julia Bloch. She is survived by her children Richard Kirschman of Dogtown, California, and Dr. Ellen Kirschman of Oakland, CA., and their companions Doris Ober and Steve Johnson; her nephews Burt Bacharach, James Blume, Fritz Blume, and Roger Bloch; her nieces Gloria Jerome, Mary Jo Luxemberg and their families; the Ortega family and many, many friends. She will be remembered for her years of service as a volunteer at New York Hospital, her wit, her humanity, her social grace and her pluckiness. Contributions may be made to the Point Reyes Clinic, Box 862, Point Reyes Station, CA. 94956. No services.

abstract: SHEABER-Myron. The Cystic Fibrosis Association of Greater New York marks with profound sorrow the passing of Mike Sheaber, our distinguished colleague, who served with dedication for so many years as a member of the CFA Board of Directors in support of research and scholarship grant programs to help broaden the horizons and bring the ''breath of life'' to CF children and young adults. Our hearts go out to Maxine, his beloved wife and our very good friend; a long-time advocate for cystic fibrosis children and past Vice President of the CF Association of Greater New York. Our deep felt condolences to his cherished children and grandchildren and to all the family. Mike was a uniquely insightful, caring, giving and extraordinarily fine man and friend. We shall miss him. Phyllis L. Kossoff, Chairman Norton Hight, President and CEO

lead_paragraph: ONE of Lynne Lehrman Weiner's regrets is that at the age of 2 in 1928 when she was asked by Sigmund Freud to sing him a nursery song, she said no, preferring to play with his dogs. abstract: Valerie Gladstone article on traveling through Spain on luxurious vintage train, Al Andalus; photos; map (M)
snippet: Valerie Gladstone article on traveling through Spain on luxurious vintage train, Al Andalus; photos; map (M)
lead_paragraph: STANDING in the big, bright, modern Santa Justa railway station in Seville, Al Andalus looked anachronistic, like Greta Garbo surrounded by hip 90's starlets. The brown-and-gold luxury train, most of its cars built in the 1920's, exuded understated class in the midst of the other sleek but characterless trains. Over the loudspeaker the names of cities rang out, and people hurried to their gates. No such public fanfare for those of us who were soon to travel on Al Andalus -- reservations must be made weeks in advance.

abstract: Jenny McPhee reviews book Partisan Wedding by Renata Vigano; drawing (M)
snippet: Jenny McPhee reviews book Partisan Wedding by Renata Vigano; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: PARTISAN WEDDING (University of Missouri, paper, $19.95), Renata ViganRated R's spare and heart-wrenching story collection, is centered on women involved in the Italian resistance during World War II. The author, who died in 1976, was herself a courier, or staffetta, for the partisans who fought the Germans near Bologna; she fictionalized her experiences and those of other women she knew in these captivating and vivid stories. The title story describes the humble wedding of a servant, Marina, to a partisan in a hilltop hideout. Set against the backdrop of wartime Italy, the ominous mood surrounding the ceremony, together with the bride and groom's innocence, establishes the tone for the collection and introduces one of the book's dominant themes: how the clandestine war was fought on a personal level. In ''Campalbo'' a 13-year-old girl whose father was shot by the Germans proudly risks her life to bring newspapers to the partisans hiding in the hills. Many of ViganRated R's stories depict women deliberately using their sexuality in order to achieve a desired goal. In ''Red Flag,'' a woman hides ammunition under her used sanitary napkins. In ''Argelide,'' a former prostitute poses as the madam of a brothel so that Germans won't suspect her house as a partisan meeting place. ''The Last Action'' tells the story of a German sympathizer who seduces a partisan in order to get him to reveal his colleagues' names. Suzanne Branciforte's translation beautifully renders ViganRated R's simple but passionate prose into English, and her informative introduction rightfully claims for ViganRated R the invaluable contribution her writing has made to the literature of World War II. Jenny McPhee

abstract: Maira Kalman Endpaper article describes death of graphic designer Tibor Kalman, who chose to spend last days at resort in Puerto Rico; drawings (M)
snippet: Maira Kalman Endpaper article describes death of graphic designer Tibor Kalman, who chose to spend last days at resort in Puerto Rico; drawings (M)
lead_paragraph: When it became clear that there was no more hope, Tibor said we had to go somewhere warm for a few days. We could be together, and he could be in the ocean. A trip to the Caribbean seemed lunatic. But Tibor's physical therapist and friend, Deno, agreed to come. We went to the Hyatt Dorado in Puerto Rico, which had quiet bungalows on a celestial beach. Then Tibor announced that he was not going back home.

abstract: Letter from Rhoda S Schaefer objects to implication in Geri Barish's Dec 26 letter that those who survive breast cancer have courage and will; says those who die also had courage and will (S)
snippet: Letter from Rhoda S Schaefer objects to implication in Geri Barish's Dec 26 letter that those who survive breast cancer have courage and will; says those who die also had courage and will (S)
lead_paragraph: Like Geri Barish [letter, Dec. 26], I was disturbed by the Dec. 12 discussion of Barbara's Johnson's ability to serve in the Nassau County Legislature because she is a breast cancer survivor. What shocked and disturbed me even more was Ms. Barish's implication that those of us who have survived have ''mustered the courage and will to fend off the disease and continue to lead productive lives.'' Of the many relatives, friends and 1 in 9 founders and board members who have lost their battle with breast cancer, not one died because she lacked courage and will.

lead_paragraph: THE next time some policy strategist or ivory-tower academic suggests raising the retirement age to 70 for collecting full Social Security benefits, I wish he would get up from his ergonomically designed chair, go to Bloomfield, N.J., and spend a day with William Gelenites or John Cuffari.

abstract: Murray Chass article offers global predictions for future of baseball in 21st century (M)
snippet: Murray Chass article offers global predictions for future of baseball in 21st century (M)
lead_paragraph: Basketball players added muscles and multimillion-dollar sneaker contracts. American yachts lost the America's Cup, gained it back, then lost it again. Grass all but disappeared on tennis courts. The natural stuff almost became extinct in baseball and football before injuries and nostalgia spurred its comeback. Lights finally shone at Wrigley Field. Europe became a major talent pool for the National Hockey League; golf and tennis benefited from America's diversity. What could happen next, on and off the field? A look at nine sports.

abstract: Richard Ford article recalls dinner with writer Willie Morris, who died in 1999; photo (M)
snippet: Richard Ford article recalls dinner with writer Willie Morris, who died in 1999; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: Back in 1968, when I was a kid writer and Willie Morris was the famous author of ''North Toward Home'' and the highly public editor of Harper's Magazine, I sent him short stories. We were Mississippians, though not acquainted. And my stories would always bounce back with a typed note: this or that was ''interesting''; ''clearly'' I possessed a writerly ''talent.'' This one wasn't ''right for'' Harper's but ''definitely'' would be publishable elsewhere. A good quarterly maybe. ''Do try us again. . . . '' Sincerely, Willie Morris.

abstract: Kathleen Velsor, assistant professor at State University of NY at Old Westbury, has been exploring local Quaker connection to early development of Underground Railroad, informal network that helped smuggle runaway slaves north in 30 years before Civil War; she contends effort began on Long Island; photo (M)
snippet: Kathleen Velsor, assistant professor at State University of NY at Old Westbury, has been exploring local Quaker connection to early development of Underground Railroad, informal network that helped smuggle runaway slaves north in 30 years before C...
lead_paragraph: TO most people, ''Uncle Tom's Cabin,'' the antislavery novel by Harriet Beecher Stowe, conjures up images of runaway slaves and the antebellum South. To Kathleen Velsor, an assistant professor in the teacher education program at the State University at Old Westbury, the tale summons sprawling plantations along the winding streets of Old Westbury, not estates of the McMansion variety, but Tara-style spreads where slaves once worked the fields.

abstract: New York City's mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, declared victory in his war on welfare. The mayor, a likely Senate candidate, said he had met the deadline he set 18 months ago to end welfare by ''engaging'' all available adult recipients in work or work-preparation in exchange for aid.     But critics loudly disputed his figures, noting for example that recipients counted as successes included thousands merely referred for evaluation for work.   NINA BERNSTEIN
lead_paragraph: New York City's mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, declared victory in his war on welfare. The mayor, a likely Senate candidate, said he had met the deadline he set 18 months ago to end welfare by ''engaging'' all available adult recipients in work or work-preparation in exchange for aid.

abstract: For schoolchildren in the 1950's or 60's, there were few sounds more terrifying than the wail of an air raid siren. No matter that it was only a test: The sound will forever conjure up visions of Soviet jets and mushroom clouds.    But 50 years after cities from coast to coast installed the early warning systems, the sirens have become little more than annoying relics of the cold war. This year, Baltimore will become the latest city to abandon the system and its tests of 122 sirens that blared from speakers around town each Monday at 1 p.m. A new network of radio-controlled sirens, which do not require routine testing, will be installed to alert people to impending natural disasters or terrorist attacks.
lead_paragraph: For schoolchildren in the 1950's or 60's, there were few sounds more terrifying than the wail of an air raid siren. No matter that it was only a test: The sound will forever conjure up visions of Soviet jets and mushroom clouds.

abstract: Westchester music notes; photo; Amram Jam is planned to help David Amram, whose uninsured home in Putnam Valley was destroyed by fire in October (S)
snippet: Westchester music notes; photo; Amram Jam is planned to help David Amram, whose uninsured home in Putnam Valley was destroyed by fire in October (S)
lead_paragraph: FOR nearly half a century, musicians in need could count on David Amram to volunteer his time and talents on their behalf. Now he is in need -- his uninsured Putnam Valley home was destroyed by fire in October -- and more than a dozen colleagues are planning an Amram Jam next Saturday at 8 p.m. at the Tarrytown Music Hall to raise money for rebuilding. Among the artists will be Chuck Mangione, Max Roach, Clark Terry and Jon Hendricks, along with the actors Keir Dullea and Mia Dillon, the television personality Bill Boggs, Mark Morganelli and his Jazz Forum All-Stars and Mr. Amram, performing on piano, French horn, flutes and sundry folk instruments from his own collection. All the performers have donated their services, and benefit tickets are priced at $25. The number to call for reservations is 631-1000.

abstract: SPURGEON-Gertrude (nee Terry). On December 29, 1999 age 94. Beloved wife of the late Thomas W. Spurgeon, Jr. Loving aunt of Lee Salisbury of Fairbanks, Alaska and Robert Salisbury of St. Petersburg, Florida. She is also survived by seven great-neices and great-nephews. A pillar of the nursing community, she was Head Nurse at Montefiore Hospital for many years. Funeral service on Tuesday at 10:00 a.m. at John F.X. McKeon & Son, Inc. 3129 Perry Avenue, Bronx, NY. abstract: Luc S
snippet: Luc S
lead_paragraph: Lili St. Cyr, who died last January at the age of 80, was one of the last survivors of an era that now seems as remote as the Hapsburg dynasty. That era might be called the age of burlesque, which makes it sound rather grand, and let's say it lasted from 1893 until 1960, or thereabouts. Burlesque was a stratum of entertainment, not exactly underground but not quite legit -- in the theatrical sense of the word -- which might or might not involve singers, comedians, chorus lines or canned-ham raffles. Its essential feature, however, was women slowly removing most or all of their clothing. Lili St. Cyr excelled at this art and introduced several refinements, like her trademark emergence from an onstage bubble bath with the bubbles selectively clinging to her salient parts.

abstract: James Tosone article on controversy over racial profiling by New Jersey State Police; drawing (M)
snippet: James Tosone article on controversy over racial profiling by New Jersey State Police; drawing (M)
lead_paragraph: PROFILING -- the state police practice of stopping motorists suspected of criminal activity based on their race -- is back in the news. Last week, New Jersey agreed to let an independent federal monitor oversee its efforts to reform the practice. Less noticed though, was when State Superior Court Judge Theodore Bozonelis ruled in the fall that the attorney general's report declaring that profiling exits applied not only to actions on the New Jersey Turnpike but off it as well.

abstract: John Cook article on William H Whyte, who studied and wrote about organization of small urban spaces and died in 1999; photo of his cumulative sighting map depicting where people were situated on New York City library steps (S)
snippet: John Cook article on William H Whyte, who studied and wrote about organization of small urban spaces and died in 1999; photo of his cumulative sighting map depicting where people were situated on New York City library steps (S)
lead_paragraph: In his quest to understand why public spaces work (or don't work), William H. Whyte became, you might say, a streetwalker. He loitered in parks, plazas and subway stations, clipboard in hand, dutifully recording the physical and social landscape. His suggestions for making spaces more inviting and vibrant were applied to several city parks, most prominently Bryant Park, and published in ''The Social Life of Small Urban Spaces'' and ''City.'' Below is a typical Whyte research tool -- what he called a cumulative sighting map. It depicts precisely where people were situated on the front steps of the New York Public Library at 12:30 p.m. and then at 1:30 p.m. during four days in July 1972.

abstract: D J R Bruckner reviews book Earth From Above, photographs of Yann Arthur-Bertrand, with text translated from French by David Baker; photo (M)
snippet: D J R Bruckner reviews book Earth From Above, photographs of Yann Arthur-Bertrand, with text translated from French by David Baker; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: In a sense, the aerial photographs of Yann Arthus-Bertrand are happy accidents: he took them from aircraft in 60 countries, and composition on the fly is chancy. But the prints are proof that, if the earth itself is not alive, its whole surface is always moving. Wind, water, tectonic plates and people are slow agents, but the marks of change are vast; the images capture eons in a moment. Whether you look down on the Lakagigar volcanoes in Iceland or the man-made windbreaks of the Aran Islands, you know Galileo said more than he meant when he insisted, ''It moves.'' Almost 200 of Arthus-Bertrand's images are lavishly reproduced in EARTH FROM ABOVE (Abrams, $65). The project was sponsored by Unesco, and the book has commentaries by French scientists who worry about humanity covering the planet too fast. But the photographs undermine their eloquence; to paraphrase John Lyly, the pictures are honey though the words are gall. From above, acres of carpets laid out on the sands of Morocco or even the dumps of Mexico City are as gorgeous as the autumn forests of Quebec or the mineral ''forest'' of Madagascar. Shots of the sprawl of monstrous cities are not reassuring, but over all one marvels at how naturally humanity's endless sand-castling fits into nature. And what a work nature is! Everywhere -- in cosmic brush strokes of bacteria in the Grand Prismatic Spring of Yellowstone or minerals washed over by the Rio Carrao in Venezuela -- the earth creates color and patterns that reduce human art to its proper place. ''Earth From Above'' is translated from French (by David Baker), and here and there one is reminded of the pitfalls of translation, as when it tells us the Yankees are ''the most winningest team'' in baseball, and of how iffy proofreading is in any language, as when it says the Maldives are ''120 isles or islets, of which almost 420 are inhabited.'' But it is a terrific book to look at and think about. D. J. R. Bruckner

abstract: the artists the art world couldn't8
snippet: the artists the art world couldn't8
lead_paragraph: Frederick Hart died at the age of 55 on Aug. 13, two days after a team of doctors discovered he had lung cancer, abruptly concluding one of the most bizarre stories in the history of 20th-century art. While still in his 20's, Hart consciously, pointedly, aimed for the ultimate in the Western tradition of sculpture, achieved it in a single stroke, then became invisible, and remained invisible, as invisible as Ralph Ellison's invisible man, who was invisible ''simply because people refuse to see me.''

abstract: Alice Giffuni letter objects to disparaging comments about Albano Terme, Italy, where she has spent every July for 20 years; comments were in Daisann McLane's Nov 28 (1999) travel article (S)
snippet: Alice Giffuni letter objects to disparaging comments about Albano Terme, Italy, where she has spent every July for 20 years; comments were in Daisann McLane's Nov 28 (1999) travel article (S)
lead_paragraph: To the Editor: I was dismayed while reading Daisann McLane's article to find Abano Terme dismissed as a main street of tacky shops and concrete-box hotels. Having gone to Abano every July for more than 20 years, I have seen it grow from a small quiet town to a very modern, clean and thriving quasi-city, with hotels in every price range, good restaurants, shops and, yes, even good pizzerias. For several years, the center of town has become a pedestrian mall, with many cafes, free concerts and exhibitions.

snippet: lott, disenchanted, is weighing a union challenge
lead_paragraph: Ronnie Lott spent nine years with the San Francisco 49ers and earned a reputation as one of the best safeties ever to play the game. abstract: Vicki Goldberg reviews photographs by John Coplans and Manabu Yamanaka on subject of aging; shows are at Andrea Rosen and Stephan Stux galleries; photo (M)
snippet: Vicki Goldberg reviews photographs by John Coplans and Manabu Yamanaka on subject of aging; shows are at Andrea Rosen and Stephan Stux galleries; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: THE demographics of nudity in the arts have never quite matched the demographics of whatever population the arts were playing in. In ancient Greece, young men displayed their every charm in stone for a couple of centuries before naked young women were allowed to join them. In late-18th-century neo-Classicism, warriors tended to doff all their clothes while their wives or the women they had brought to grief, both of whom probably outnumbered them by war's end, generally remained covered.
