(+)          Rankings reflect sales, for the week ending Dec. 18, at almost 4,000 bookstores plus wholesalers serving 50,000 other retailers (gift shops, department stores, newsstands, supermarkets), statistically weighted to represent all such outlets nationwide. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger (+)indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available from The New York Times on the Web: www.nytimes.com/books.    And Bear in Mind  (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)    DISGRACE, by J. M. Coetzee. (Viking, $23.95.) The ''disgrace'' of the title belongs to the central character of this novel (winner of this year's Booker Prize in Britain), a Cape Town intellectual whose sexual sin, later visited on his daughter, is made to reflect the old guilt of white privilege.    EMPIRE EXPRESS: Building the First Transcontinental Railroad, by David Haward Bain. (Viking, $34.95.) An authoritative, engaging history of the gigantic enterprise that linked the coasts of America in 1869, and of the robber barons and immigrant workers who did it.    THE GOODLIFE, by Keith Scribner. (Riverhead, $23.95.) A novel that ponders why crime stories so fascinate us while telling a hair-raising tale of a kidnapping gone wrong, using five narrative points of view without ever getting confused or woozy.    MAILER: A Biography, by Mary V. Dearborn. (Houghton Mifflin, $30.) Norman Mailer carefully examined from without (no interviews) by a writer who appreciates the equal importance of his life and his work in understanding America in the second half of the 20th century.    NAT KING COLE, by Daniel Mark Epstein. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A life of this American singer of tales follows its perpetually seductive yet profoundly reserved subject from boyhood (only gospel songs allowed) through 40's jazz prowess and 50's pop stardom to his untimely death.    OSBERT SITWELL, by Philip Ziegler. (Knopf, $30.) An elegant, expertly written life of Sir Osbert Sitwell, an ineffable aristocrat with a temporary literary reputation and a permanent conviction that he, his sister Edith and his brother Sacheverell were made of superior clay.    REMBRANDT'S EYES, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $50.) A huge, digressive, learned, personal, often fascinating book defending Rembrandt's genius, as if it needed defending.    THE SORCERER'S APPRENTICE: Picasso, Provence, and Douglas Cooper, by John Richardson. (Knopf, $26.95.) Picasso's biographer takes time out to give an account of his own early life and his relationship with the rich and prickly art historian and collector Douglas Cooper.    TERESA OF AVILA: The Progress of a Soul, by Cathleen Medwick. (Knopf, $26.) The saint (b. 1515) is drawn here as a flesh-and-blood human being -- a levitation-prone mystic who was also a hardheaded businesswoman adroit at securing financial angels.    WALTER BENJAMIN AT THE DAIRY QUEEN: Reflections at Sixty and Beyond, by Larry McMurtry. (Simon & Schuster, $21.) A peculiar book, part memoir, part tour de force, part commonplace book, in which the author of ''Lonesome Dove'' regrets what he thinks is his failure to subvert fallacies about the Old West.

abstract: Karen Schoemer article on Frank DeVol, songwriter and composer who died
snippet: Karen Schoemer article on Frank DeVol, songwriter and composer who died
lead_paragraph: Some may scoff and snicker at the mere mention of Frank DeVol, whose crowning professional achievement was to give the world the ''Brady Bunch'' theme. But even those who think the show marked some kind of nadir in Western civilization have to admit that the song was pretty darn catchy. As the music bounced along in tempo with those nine bobbing heads, the story of ''a lovely lady'' and ''a man named Brady'' became permanently etched in a generation's mushy consciousness.

abstract: Performers comment on providing voices for animated characters in light of 1999 dh
snippet: Performers comment on providing voices for animated characters in light of 1999 dh
lead_paragraph: She was best known not by her face, her name or even her character's name, but by the one she hollered in an instantly recognizable pitch: ''Fre-e-e-ed.'' That alone made Jean Vander Pyl one of the best-known voices around. In recent years, as animation has exploded again as a category in feature films and prime-time television, performers of all sorts have learned what it is that makes a ''voice actor'' like Vander Pyl so good.

lead_paragraph: BACH fanatics have long fantasized about an auditory time machine that might carry them back to the 18th century and to the Thomaskirche in Leipzig, where they could hear Bach leading his cantatas. abstract: Q. I rented out my Manhattan co-op apartment to two men for use as a home business. At the interview, the men told the board that all that was needed for the business was a desk, a phone and a fax, and that only rarely would clients come to the office. The board approved the lease and the men paid me one month's rent and two months' security. Twenty-one days after the lease began the men had still not moved into the unit.  Then, after one of them told the chairman of the co-op board that he intended to open a Holistic Medical Center, which would require major renovations and would serve hundreds of clients, the board rescinded its approval. I have refused to return the rent and security deposit on the ground that the tenants had broken the lease. Now I am being sued. What is the law in such a matter? . . . Wayne Martens, Manhattan.    A.  Felix Nihamin, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that while the co-op may not be a party to the lease agreement between the letter-writer and the tenants, it appears that the board's approval of the sublet was required. It also appears that the approval was granted based upon representations made by the tenants. Accordingly, Mr. Nihamin said, if the tenants later changed their plans -- thereby prompting the board to withdraw its approval -- it would be the tenants' own actions that resulted in their inability to move into the apartment.
lead_paragraph: Q. I rented out my Manhattan co-op apartment to two men for use as a home business. At the interview, the men told the board that all that was needed for the business was a desk, a phone and a fax, and that only rarely would clients come to the office. The board approved the lease and the men paid me one month's rent and two months' security. Twenty-one days after the lease began the men had still not moved into the unit. Then, after one of them told the chairman of the co-op board that he intended to open a Holistic Medical Center, which would require major renovations and would serve hundreds of clients, the board rescinded its approval. I have refused to return the rent and security deposit on the ground that the tenants had broken the lease. Now I am being sued. What is the law in such a matter? . . . Wayne Martens, Manhattan.

abstract: Ever since it achieved independence from France in 1960, Ivory Coast has been considered a model of stability and prosperity in Africa. So it came as a shock, both in Africa and in France, when soldiers mutinying over low pay went on a looting spree and, one day later, a military junta announced a coup, the first in the country's history.     The leader of the nonviolent coup, Gen. Robert Guei, a former armed forces chief ousted by President Henri Konan Bedie, said he took action largely because Mr. Bedie was creating ethnic divisions.   DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

abstract: Joseph Horowitz article on Disney's classic animated film Fantasia, and new Fantasia/2000, second animated classical musical medley; photo (M)
snippet: Joseph Horowitz article on Disney's classic animated film Fantasia, and new Fantasia/2000, second animated classical musical medley; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: IN 1939 the composer Paul Hindemith visited Hollywood, full of enthusiasm for Walt Disney's first full-length cartoon feature, ''Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.'' Hindemith headed for the studio in which Disney and Leopold Stokowski were working on the second full-length cartoon feature, ''Fantasia.'' But its cartoon renderings of Bach and Beethoven repulsed Hindemith; he thought the new medium was being abused by philistines.

abstract: Contrasts be
snippet: Contrasts be
lead_paragraph: Harry Callahan, the abstract photographer from the Midwest, and Raghubir Singh, the realist from Rajasthan, are not on the same page, metaphorically speaking. One was Western, the other Eastern. One looked inward, the other outward. Callahan, an influential teacher of photography at the Institute of Design in Chicago and the Rhode Island School of Design, had important predecessors (Laszlo Moholy-Nagy), colleagues (Aaron Siskind) and students (Linda Connor, Ray K. Metzker, Emmet Gowin). He photographed weeds in water and scarred walls, but mostly, over and over again, in exposure and double exposure, he shot the body of his wife, Eleanor, as an intimate landscape. Singh, meanwhile, often complained of the ''wholly Western,'' angst-ridden nature of photography, saying, ''The Indian photographer had to cut his own route.'' He photographed Benares, Bombay, Calcutta, Kashmir -- landscapes teeming with bodies and buildings and public ritual.

abstract: Baseball Notebook article focuses on feats from previous turn of century; photo (M)
snippet: Baseball Notebook article focuses on feats from previous turn of century; photo (M)
lead_paragraph: How far Major League Baseball has come in 100 years. In 1900 the National League snubbed the newly named American League, denying the upstart equal status, even refusing to acknowledge the league's existence. In the first year of this new century, the leagues are not only considered equal but they also have become blurred by the elimination of separate league offices and league presidents.

abstract: Sgt Joseph Manto of New Jersey National Guard is awarded state's Medal of Valor for rescue of two Lodi police officers, who were trapped by floodwaters of Tropical Storm Floyd (S)
snippet: Sgt Joseph Manto of New Jersey National Guard is awarded state's Medal of Valor for rescue of two Lodi police officers, who were trapped by floodwaters of Tropical Storm Floyd (S)
lead_paragraph: No one seems to know when the last Medal of Valor was awarded in New Jersey, but now one has been presented to Sgt. Joseph Manto of the National Guard for the rescue of two Lodi police officers who were trapped by floodwaters during Tropical Storm Floyd. The Medal of Valor is the highest honor a National Guard member can receive for civilian action.

abstract: Michael Doneff opens Nice House, a home furnishing store, in Greenwich Village (S)
snippet: Michael Doneff opens Nice House, a home furnishing store, in Greenwich Village (S)
lead_paragraph: In the Nice House holiday window display at 117 Perry Street (between Hudson and Greenwich Streets) stand three matching plastic soul dancer dolls. abstract: Rob Hoerburger tribute
snippet: Rob Hoerburger tribute
lead_paragraph: When I met Dusty Springfield in 1995, she was in the pocket -- a musician's term akin to ''in the zone'' for athletes. She was enjoying renewed acclaim for her 60's recordings, which covered a virtually unplottable graph of moods and styles, from the girl-groupy joy ride of ''I Only Want to Be With You'' to the breathy eroticism of ''The Look of Love.'' She had just won a round in her battle with cancer and seemed in no hurry to get back to the recording studio. ''Although, if someone let me record an album of every cover I've ever dreamed of singing, I might think about it,'' she coolly intoned.

abstract: Sean (Puffy) Combs has the indisputable ability to attract attention. The rap impresario throws lavish parties, drapes himself in furs and jewelry, dates the movie star Jennifer Lopez and all but begs people to look his way. Some say this is a job requirement for a hip-hop star; others find it a tad excessive.    Last week Mr. Combs, 30, attracted more attention -- the unwanted kind -- when he was arrested after an early-morning shootout in a Manhattan nightclub. The arrest led to inevitable newspaper photographs depicting Mr. Combs skulking away from a police station.

That is not to say there are no fabulous restaurants that would repeatedly draw us back for occasions ranging from a casual repast with a peckish friend to a formal bash celebrating one of life's great events. There are, and they are listed below. But observant readers will notice that this year's choice picks number fewer than those in the past. And the primary cause for these cuts is ungracious or inattentive service.

abstract: Chip Brown article on William Woodward
snippet: Chip Brown article on William Woodward
lead_paragraph: Anyone who knew Woody Woodward felt a dreadful pity at how the drama of his life was resolved that Sunday morning in May when he stepped into the abyss outside the kitchen window of his Manhattan apartment and fell 14 stories to his death. He was 54 years old. He left a 6-year-old daughter, an estranged wife and an estate worth upwards of $60 million. His old Harvard pals; his Newport sailing mates; the women who left soup at his door when he was under the weather and who were smitten by his almost unsporting mix of charm, looks, wounded romanticism and old money -- they all cast about for reasons. Was it a reprise of the manic-depression that he seemed to have under control? The ordeal of a bitterly contested divorce? Or had their funny, fragile, self-absorbed friend been propelled by something more perverse, which is to say the larger tragedy of the Woodward family itself? He had contested his family's legacy of self-destruction all his life, until the last moment, when, abruptly, he embraced it.

abstract: Prof Douglas Brinkley tribute to civil righ
snippet: Prof Douglas Brinkley tribute to civil righ
lead_paragraph: America has spent the past several years acknowledging the indisputable heroes of World War II: the G.I.'s who stormed Omaha Beach, liberated concentration camps, fulfilled Gen. Douglas MacArthur's pledge to return to the Philippines and so much more. But members of that same generation who led the modern civil rights movement have yet to receive the same treatment, and portrayals of them still often give off a whiff of un-Americanism, a lasting effect of the 1950's Red scare, which labeled as a Communist rabble-rouser anyone -- and certainly any black -- who threatened the social order. It's a troubling paradox when considering the lives of three extraordinary, yet dimly remembered, heroes of the civil rights movement: James Farmer, Daisy Bates and Frank M. Johnson Jr.

abstract: Home Clinic column on repairing or replacing balustrade; drawings (S)
snippet: Home Clinic column on repairing or replacing balustrade; drawings (S)
lead_paragraph: A WELL-CONSTRUCTED staircase is made of many components: treads, risers and stringers that fit together like a fine cabinet. Some staircases are enclosed between two walls, but most are usually built against one wall with the opposite side being open. For safety reasons, the open side should be enclosed with a balustrade. The balustrade is a series of vertical posts, called balusters. These support the handrail. One end of the handrail is usually anchored to a wall or a railing at the top of the stairs. At the other end of the balustrade, at the foot of the stairs, is the newel post. It supports the handrail and anchors the balustrade.

abstract: As 1999 trading ended in an anticlimactic fashion, the date buzzing an alarm in investors' ears may have been Monday, April 17, not Jan. 1.     Joseph Barthel, chief investment strategist at Fahnestock & Company, told Reuters on Thursday that some people, who were waiting for tax reasons, to take profits in January chose to do it sooner, fearing that the rally was ending. Some portfolio managers all of a sudden as we step into the New Year think that people will start to sell on the first day of the year, he said.

abstract: The hijackers of an Indian Airlines jet ended an eight-day standoff with Indian officials when they released more than 150 hostages at an airport in Afghanistan in exchange for the release of three prominent Muslim militants that had been held by India. Both the hijackers and the Indian officials had been under intense pressure by the ruling Taliban militia in Afghanistan to end the crisis.    The Indian Airlines Airbus was seized by the hijackers on a flight from Nepal on Dec. 24. The hostages were flown to New Delhi after their release.

lead_paragraph: Among the disasters that did not happen, planes did not fall from the sky, terrorists did not have their way, and after nearly 24 nonstop hours as anchor of ABC's extravagant New Year's coverage, Peter Jennings did not turn into Jerry Lewis and start singing ''You'll Never Walk Alone.'' abstract: In a welcome anticlimax to two years of dire warnings, the new millennium arrived over the weekend without a computer-driven meltdown of the globe's electronic infrastructure. So far even  the countries that did not spend vast sums to prepare for a Y2K-bug disaster have been spared major problems, raising questions about whether all the planning and expense were necessary. The speculation about what might have happened had there been no preparation is intriguing and inevitable. But common sense suggests that inaction  was not an option for government and business leaders once the experts determined the existence of a threat to power grids, defense systems, air transport, financial communications and other vital linkages.    Among most computer specialists, the fear of a serious crisis was real. As just about everyone came to learn, their anxiety was that computers would break down because of an inability to recognize the year 2000. A year or so ago, Wired magazine reported that many leading software engineers were themselves planning to spend the New Year's weekend in remote places with stocks of water, cash and food on hand. That fear now seems exaggerated, but it was not entirely fanciful. It reflected the essential fact that even the experts do not fully comprehend the complexity of the systems that now undergird the world's computers. John Koskinen, chairman of the President's Council on Year 2000 Conversion, has warned that it may take weeks or months to be sure that the millennium bug is completely behind us.
lead_paragraph: In a welcome anticlimax to two years of dire warnings, the new millennium arrived over the weekend without a computer-driven meltdown of the globe's electronic infrastructure. So far even the countries that did not spend vast sums to prepare for a Y2K-bug disaster have been spared major problems, raising questions about whether all the planning and expense were necessary. The speculation about what might have happened had there been no preparation is intriguing and inevitable. But common sense suggests that inaction was not an option for government and business leaders once the experts determined the existence of a threat to power grids, defense systems, air transport, financial communications and other vital linkages.

abstract: Much of the e-commerce industry wants a new tax loophole: an exemption from taxes on goods and services sold over the Internet and on fees paid for access to the Internet. At stake in this debate is not just money, but political power.    For businesses that sell only in cyberspace, a tax-free Internet would be a bonanza, offsetting the costs of shipping goods. But under existing rules, companies that sell both in stores and on the Web -- so-called clicks-and-mortar enterprises -- must collect sales taxes on their Internet sales, putting them at a significant competitive disadvantage.
lead_paragraph: Much of the e-commerce industry wants a new tax loophole: an exemption from taxes on goods and services sold over the Internet and on fees paid for access to the Internet. At stake in this debate is not just money, but political power.

abstract: SEVERAL years ago, Scott Sullivan had a hallway conversation at work with Robert Hess about an idea: putting Braille on pills.     But Mr. Sullivan, a patent agent, and Mr. Hess, a patent lawyer, realized their concept had a flaw. What if one of the raised dots chipped off? A blind person might misread the pill and take the wrong medication. But as they tossed the notion around and realized that Braille was just a code, it came to them: Why not use a bar code instead?

abstract: JERRY JONES, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, put his team's 26-18 victory yesterday in perspective and inadvertently put the Giants in perspective as well.    ''I don't want to get too foaming at the mouth over winning this game,'' he said. ''We should beat the Giants here at home with as much at stake as we got and the players we've got. We should beat them.''
lead_paragraph: JERRY JONES, the Dallas Cowboys' owner, put his team's 26-18 victory yesterday in perspective and inadvertently put the Giants in perspective as well.

abstract: Financially, AT&T's emergence as the nation's No. 1 cable television company could well be the business world's all-time biggest wager. Since 1998, AT&T has committed more than $100 billion to acquire two of the biggest cable providers, Tele-Communications Inc. and the MediaOne Group.    But the long-distance giant's bet is not just on the cable TV business. Its far more ambitious strategy is to use its cable networks to deliver a panoply of new digital services to homes, including local phone calls, high-speed Internet access and even futuristic sorts of interactive television (think ordering a pizza on your TV).
lead_paragraph: Financially, AT&T's emergence as the nation's No. 1 cable television company could well be the business world's all-time biggest wager. Since 1998, AT&T has committed more than $100 billion to acquire two of the biggest cable providers, Tele-Communications Inc. and the MediaOne Group.

abstract: Several times in each of the last few decades, Silicon Valley has been home to a truly big gamble. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh transformed the computer industry, but other high-stakes wagers like the Amiga or the Go Corporation have fizzled.    In fact, most of the valley's big gambles have failed for setting goals that proved far too ambitious. In the early 1980's there was Trilogy, a premature effort to build an ultrafast mainframe computer. In the early 1990's, Microunity caught the valley's imagination with a microprocessor intended to be the standard for interactive cable systems, which failed to emerge.
lead_paragraph: Several times in each of the last few decades, Silicon Valley has been home to a truly big gamble. In 1984, the Apple Macintosh transformed the computer industry, but other high-stakes wagers like the Amiga or the Go Corporation have fizzled.

abstract: Jacob Frenkel, the chief of Israel's central bank, who was to have stepped down today, agreed today to stay on the job another week while Prime Minister Ehud Barak continues to look for a successor. abstract: Some of the most powerful names in advertising are betting that three heads will be better than one -- or even two.    Three giant agency companies are planning to join forces to create the world's No. 4 advertising behemoth in revenue, at $1.8 billion, and No. 5 in billings, at more than $13 billion. The deal would unite the two largest privately held agency companies, the Leo Group in Chicago and the MacManus Group in New York, as Dentsu, the biggest agency in Japan, invests an undisclosed amount of cash to acquire about a 20 percent stake in the merged operation.
lead_paragraph: Some of the most powerful names in advertising are betting that three heads will be better than one -- or even two.

abstract: For the players in the digital music industry, the coming year may feel like a marathon poker game. The growing consumer interest in downloading and listening to music online is good news for the various types of companies that already have seats at the table. But all will face decisions on which  hands to play and which to fold.     Some companies, like MP3.com and Garageband.com, are betting that they can give music away for free, in the MP3 technical format, and survive on Web-based advertising. Others, like Virgin Jamcast and Yahoo Digital, intend to charge consumers who want to download and store songs; but the success of that model will depend on how consumer friendly and copyright secure each of a handful of competing downloading technologies turns out to be.
lead_paragraph: For the players in the digital music industry, the coming year may feel like a marathon poker game. The growing consumer interest in downloading and listening to music online is good news for the various types of companies that already have seats at the table. But all will face decisions on which hands to play and which to fold.

abstract: EPSTEIN-Nathan B. Age 89, of Tarrytown, NY, died January 2, 2000. Beloved father of Barbara (Paul) Rigney and Susan (Kevin) Bannon. Cherished grandfather of Michael and Katie Bannon. Senior Vice-President of Lerner Stores Corporation. Former Board member of American Retail Foundation, past President of Temple Beth Abraham, Tarrytown, former member of Tarrytown Planning Board, past President of the Board of Education of Public Schools of Tarrytown, past President of Tarrycrest Swim Club. Former Treasurer of Volunteer Service Bureau of Westchester, former volunteer executive with International Executive Service Corp. Board member and Treasurer of F.E.G.S. (Federated Educational Guidance Services). Funeral service Tuesday, 10 AM, Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Interment Sharon Gardens. Donations in his name may be made to F.E.G.S., 114 5th Ave, NYC 10010.

abstract: KIRK-Edward J. On January 1, 2000, age 68, of Oradell. Beloved husband of Bridget C. Kirk (nee Griffin). abstract: DAN ROSTENKOWSKI bounds out of his office and barks: ''Grab your coat, let me show you the neighborhood.''     Here is the house, he says, his house, the one his Polish grandfather built. There, across the street, is the famous church, St. Stanislaus Kostka, the one he moved a highway to save. His eyes are gleaming, twinkling, as he lurches from tale to tale. He looks trim, stylish even in his soft gray turtleneck. He has swapped steak and potatoes for fish and linguine. And make that one martini, not four. ''I sleep better at night,'' he says.
lead_paragraph: DAN ROSTENKOWSKI bounds out of his office and barks: ''Grab your coat, let me show you the neighborhood.''

abstract: THERE is something about being around so many winners that makes people want to make ever bigger bets.    So after a year when the only thing flying higher than Internet stocks was the price of the television ads that the start-up companies bought with their stock money, people and companies in the media and technology industries are feeling lucky. And many are now prepared to bet their fortunes -- or at least test their skills as visionaries -- that they can find success in something the rest of us may not yet be able to see.
lead_paragraph: THERE is something about being around so many winners that makes people want to make ever bigger bets.

abstract: DOCTORS and scientists are thrilled with New York's new tax on cigarettes, and with good reason. Once the higher tax kicks in, cigarettes in New York will be more expensive than anywhere else in the country. The price will inevitably turn some smokers into nonsmokers and deter many young people from ever picking up one of those noxious weeds.    But the medical community and lawmakers who approved the new tax aren't the only ones cheering.
lead_paragraph: DOCTORS and scientists are thrilled with New York's new tax on cigarettes, and with good reason. abstract: It was only when Mario Fernandez saw the headline, ''Pinochet Under Arrest,'' that the dam broke and he finally found it possible to talk about the beatings, the electric shocks, the cigarette burns, the terrible sense of humiliation and alienation.    ''My body froze; I had an intense allergic reaction, and I didn't know whether to laugh or cry,'' said Mr. Fernandez, trembling at the memory. He ran to his wife and wept on her shoulder, and, at long last, took her advice to seek therapy.
lead_paragraph: It was only when Mario Fernandez saw the headline, ''Pinochet Under Arrest,'' that the dam broke and he finally found it possible to talk about the beatings, the electric shocks, the cigarette burns, the terrible sense of humiliation and alienation.

abstract: Beginning with ''The Matrix'' on Easter weekend and accelerating into hyperdrive with the success of ''Star Wars: Episode I  -- The Phantom Menace,'' American moviegoers went on a nine-month binge that drew record crowds to theaters, created a record number of $100 million hits and shattered several long-cherished assumptions about how the film business works.    Although final figures for the year will not be available until later this week, it is abundantly clear that 1999 was the second consecutive record year at the nation's box offices.
lead_paragraph: Beginning with ''The Matrix'' on Easter weekend and accelerating into hyperdrive with the success of ''Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace,'' American moviegoers went on a nine-month binge that drew record crowds to theaters, created a record number of $100 million hits and shattered several long-cherished assumptions about how the film business works.

abstract: Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., who as chief of naval operations in the early 1970's ordered the Navy to end racial discrimination and demeaning restrictions on sailors, then faced a haunting personal anguish that he attributed to the defoliant Agent Orange, died yesterday at the Duke University Medical Center in Durham, N.C. He was 79 and lived in Arlington, Va.    The cause was complications from surgery for a chest tumor.
lead_paragraph: Adm. Elmo R. abstract: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty last fall to a tear-gas-filled week in Seattle that badly damaged his global economic agenda.    But some of his biggest victories in 1999 were also scored abroad, from the air campaign over Serbia that largely halted ethnic bloodshed to the Northern Ireland accord that offers the first prospect of peace there.
lead_paragraph: For much of his presidency, Bill Clinton's own aides have frequently complained that his attention to foreign policy was sporadic. The trait got him in trouble in Bosnia, and often resulted in some nasty surprises -- from the defeat of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty last fall to a tear-gas-filled week in Seattle that badly damaged his global economic agenda.

abstract: Deutsche Bank, which holds 15 percent of the near-bankrupt German builder Philipp Holzmann, said over the weekend that it intended to sell the stake as it divests itself of industrial holdings.    ''It's our long-term strategy to sell our industrial portfolio, Holzmann included,'' said Klaus Thoma, a spokesman for Deutsche Bank. He denied the bank intended to sell the stake ''soon,'' as reported in a prerelease of Frankfurter Allgemeine Sonntagszeitung.

abstract: Eighteen months ago the Pentagon strongly opposed a plan to create a permanent international criminal tribunal, fearing that a strong and independent court would expose American troops sent overseas to prosecution outside the American judicial system.    Now, as a result of NATO's air war against the Serbs last spring, members of the American military have already undergone the scrutiny of just such a court: the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia. Experts on international law say that may create political and legal precedents for requiring Americans to submit to international judicial review.
lead_paragraph: Eighteen months ago the Pentagon strongly opposed a plan to create a permanent international criminal tribunal, fearing that a strong and independent court would expose American troops sent overseas to prosecution outside the American judicial system.

abstract: Microsoft trails America Online so badly in the online business that some industry experts say it should stick to its software knitting and end its ill-starred march into cyberspace.    Instead, Microsoft is redoubling its efforts. The formula will be the same, roughly, as the one the company followed with its come-from-behind winners, the Office productivity suite and the Internet Explorer browser. The recipe: competitive products, aggressive marketing and pricing.

abstract: As president, Carlos Saul Menem dominated Argentine news coverage for more than a decade by selling off much of the government and pegging the peso to the dollar -- not to mention racing sports cars, throwing his wife out of the presidential palace and dating women half his age.     Now out of power for barely three weeks, Mr. Menem has managed to remain at the center of attention. He has sometimes even managed to overshadow the always demure President Fernando de la Rua, who campaigned promising a new style of government.
lead_paragraph: As president, Carlos Saul Menem dominated Argentine news coverage for more than a decade by selling off much of the government and pegging the peso to the dollar -- not to mention racing sports cars, throwing his wife out of the presidential palace and dating women half his age.

abstract: Detectives are investigating the deaths of five people in four attacks on Saturday, another New Year's holiday accompanied by a spate of homicides, the police said yesterday.    The victims included a man who was shot in the hallway of a Harlem apartment building and a Queens livery cab driver who the police said was killed by a couple who also robbed him and then fled in a yellow cab. Two other victims were found in an abandoned building in Brooklyn. The last died in the kitchen of a  Brooklyn apartment, shot by her boyfriend, the police said. No arrests had been made in any of the cases last night.
lead_paragraph: Detectives are investigating the deaths of five people in four attacks on Saturday, another New Year's holiday accompanied by a spate of homicides, the police said yesterday.

abstract: In retrospect -- after watching the explosion of sound, light and confetti that illuminated Times Square a few hours later -- the performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony that the New York Philharmonic contributed to the celebration on Friday evening may have seemed a bit staid. One could even argue, given the frequency with which the Philharmonic plays the Beethoven symphonies, that making the Ninth the centerpiece of a program billed as the ''Concert of the Millennium'' was a commonplace move.     Oddly, though, it was exactly that quality of normalcy that made the Philharmonic's offering a particularly cherishable moment in a day of televised fireworks and barely concealed fears about terrorism and computer glitches. There is, after all, much to be said for setting aside a few moments at the turn of the year (let alone the century and the millennium) for the combination of sober reflection, idealistic hopefulness and celebratory release that this last and biggest of Beethoven's symphonies represents.
lead_paragraph: In retrospect -- after watching the explosion of sound, light and confetti that illuminated Times Square a few hours later -- the performance of Beethoven's Ninth Symphony that the New York Philharmonic contributed to the celebration on Friday evening may have seemed a bit staid. One could even argue, given the frequency with which the Philharmonic plays the Beethoven symphonies, that making the Ninth the centerpiece of a program billed as the ''Concert of the Millennium'' was a commonplace move.

abstract: The booming economy is worsening a severe shortage of the low-wage workers who care for the nation's growing numbers of frail elderly people, health care experts say. abstract: Having done little more than break the ice in their first encounter last month, Israeli and Syrian leaders enter knottier terrain on Monday as they resume American-brokered negotiations ambitiously aimed at reaching a peace accord by the summer.    The mere fact of their meeting was achievement enough when the Israelis and the Syrians revived their peace effort in December after a four-year stalemate. This time the two sides will be forced to tackle directly the tangle of issues that have bedeviled their previous efforts at peacemaking: borders, security and the opening of normal relations.
lead_paragraph: Having done little more than break the ice in their first encounter last month, Israeli and Syrian leaders enter knottier terrain on Monday as they resume American-brokered negotiations ambitiously aimed at reaching a peace accord by the summer.

abstract: The Internet's abun dance  of information, goods, tastes and sources of authority -- creates unparalleled opportunities for individuals to get exactly what they want. But this plenitude threatens political and cultural authorities who believe in telling individuals what they can have rather than letting them choose for themselves. It was inevitable, therefore, that the growth of the Internet would lead to complaints that its diversity undermines media standards, traditional morality and political authority. It was inevitable that the Internet would face calls for censorship.    And it was equally inevitable that the Internet would clash with American pharmaceutical regulations. The United States government approaches patient choice in medication as Singapore does free speech: its pronouncements sound reasonable and tolerant until you threaten its prerogatives.

abstract: MARKS-Sol. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Chemotherapy Foundation mourn the sad passing of Sol Marks, Honorary Trustee and staunch benefactor for over 25 years. His sophisticated understanding and dedicated efforts were influential in expanding the Foundation's grant programs and advancing chemotherapy research and clinical science to improve the control, cure, and prevention of cancer through innovative medical therapies. His warmth of spirit and loyalty will be remembered with affection and gratitude always. Ezra M. Greenspan, M.D. Chairman and Medical Director Barry Richter President The Chemotherapy Foundation

abstract: Her name was Charlotte Green, and she was 101 years old when she died of kidney failure at a hospital in Manhattan on Saturday afternoon, a few hours after the year 2000 began. By the ordinary measures of a life in this city of power and riches that had been her lifelong home, she was an unknown woman.    She had never married, and for 60 years had worked for a Wall Street law firm as a secretary, librarian and chief clerk, retiring 22 years ago. And if it had not been for the span of her life, which gave her a foothold in three centuries, perhaps no one would have cared enough to write about her.
lead_paragraph: Her name was Charlotte Green, and she was 101 years old when she died of kidney failure at a hospital in Manhattan on Saturday afternoon, a few hours after the year 2000 began. By the ordinary measures of a life in this city of power and riches that had been her lifelong home, she was an unknown woman.

abstract: In a world of jealous nation-states and cutthroat geopolitics, the odds of transforming the Internet into a self-governing institution might seem long. But that is the bet the Clinton administration placed in creating the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, and 2000 will likely determine the future of Internet self-governance.    Most of 1999 was rocky for Icann, the nonprofit group picked by the Commerce Department at the end of 1998 to assume administration of the Internet's addressing system. It cleared a major hurdle in November, when Network Solutions, the company that had been granted a government-blessed monopoly in the lucrative business of registering dot-com names, finally agreed to open the market to competition and to recognize Icann's authority.
lead_paragraph: In a world of jealous nation-states and cutthroat geopolitics, the odds of transforming the Internet into a self-governing institution might seem long. But that is the bet the Clinton administration placed in creating the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, and 2000 will likely determine the future of Internet self-governance.

abstract: A sea change has taken place in the American election system without our noticing it. The ''independentation'' of the primaries will determine our next president.     In olden times -- a decade or so ago -- state primary elections were often battlegrounds for partisans within each party. Liberal Democrats would wrestle with ''new'' or ''blue dog'' Democrats to choose candidates, just as economic conservatives would joust with social conservatives to pick G.O.P. nominees. Nor was it only ideological: Young Turks would go up against entrenched leadership.
lead_paragraph: A sea change has taken place in the American election system without our noticing it. The ''independentation'' of the primaries will determine our next president.

abstract: It may have seemed like an easy decision: whether to put the runaway hit ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' on its regular schedule. But ABC executives agonized for weeks over how to handle the jewel they stumbled over in their summer-clearance bin.    In the end, the network took the choice that guaranteed the biggest short-term payoff: it slotted ''Millionaire'' three nights a week beginning next Tuesday for the rest of the season.
lead_paragraph: It may have seemed like an easy decision: whether to put the runaway hit ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' on its regular schedule. But ABC executives agonized for weeks over how to handle the jewel they stumbled over in their summer-clearance bin.

abstract: A fresh warning about the Year 2000 computer problem was issued yesterday, as television news anchors told viewers that software crashes that failed to occur on Jan. 1 could occur this morning, the first regular workday of the New Year. Most of the workers had gone home by midafternoon. Some that remained were watching the Jets game.

abstract: Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani have reached agreement on a plan to redevelop Governors Island with a hotel and conference center, stores, apartments, public parkland and a branch of at least one major American museum, state officials said today.    The agreement represents a major step forward in a campaign by the city and state to persuade the federal government to give New York exclusive rights to own and develop the island, a former Coast Guard base off Manhattan's southern tip.

abstract: Music rarely divides itself into eras as neatly as it did with the century that just ended. The 1900's were the disc era, when both musicians and listeners took for granted that music could be captured and repeated. Not too long from now it may be seen as a brief historical interlude between sheet music and the Internet.    The phonograph was treated as a dictation machine for a decade after Thomas Edison invented it in 1877. Cylinders of recorded music were first sold in 1890. But in 1901 the cylinder gave way to the disc, and the rest is in the grooves. Recording preserved music that would have vanished into the air, and it changed practically everything else that was related, from the length of songs to the way they were performed, learned, sold and savored. It catalyzed a century of mind-boggling musical invention in blues, jazz, show tunes, country-and-western, gospel, salsa, soul, rock, hip-hop and all their subgenres, along with international idioms from bossa nova to juju to reggae. The immediacy and portability of recordings established a new, intimate relationship between performers and listeners, while ideas bounced around the world, leaving no style completely pure.
lead_paragraph: Music rarely divides itself into eras as neatly as it did with the century that just ended. The 1900's were the disc era, when both musicians and listeners took for granted that music could be captured and repeated. Not too long from now it may be seen as a brief historical interlude between sheet music and the Internet.

abstract: When the doors to the Seattle Seahawks' locker room opened after today's game, running back Ricky Watters stormed through, carrying his luggage toward the team bus with his head down, muttering, ''I'm not waiting to see if they can win a game.'' His team had not been able to do that, and he was not interested in navigating the National Football League's maze of playoff possibilities.    Around the room, other players dressed slowly, speaking quietly about lost opportunities. The Seahawks had come to Giants Stadium needing a victory over the Jets to assure themselves of a playoff berth. Now, after walking off the field with a disappointing 19-9 loss, they had a hard time considering the possibility that they could still back into the postseason.
lead_paragraph: When the doors to the Seattle Seahawks' locker room opened after today's game, running back Ricky Watters stormed through, carrying his luggage toward the team bus with his head down, muttering, ''I'm not waiting to see if they can win a game.'' His team had not been able to do that, and he was not interested in navigating the National Football League's maze of playoff possibilities.

abstract: Have an idea to sell something over the Internet: furniture, groceries, greeting cards, junk? In a year of Internet frenzy, paper millionaires were minted almost daily as companies with nary a profit and often no sales issued stock to the public and watched it soar. But the most likely route to riches seemed to be creating a company that would provide services to other companies exploiting the Web.    Akamai Technologies hit it right with a process to speed up delivery of content over the Internet. It was begun by an M.I.T. professor, Thomson Leighton, and a student, Daniel Lewin, each of whom held 9.6 million shares, according to a regulatory filing. If they have held on, those stakes are now worth $3.145 billion each. The stock rose 458 percent on its first day of trading in late October, and by the end of the year, it was up 1,160 percent. On average, I.P.O.'s gained 67 percent in their first day of trading this year.
lead_paragraph: Have an idea to sell something over the Internet: furniture, groceries, greeting cards, junk? In a year of Internet frenzy, paper millionaires were minted almost daily as companies with nary a profit and often no sales issued stock to the public and watched it soar. But the most likely route to riches seemed to be creating a company that would provide services to other companies exploiting the Web.

abstract: Bill Miller did the near impossible -- again. The fund he manages, Legg Mason Value Trust, beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in 1999. It has been that kind of decade for Mr. Miller, 49, a former military intelligence officer and philosophy student given to quoting Shakespeare and William James. Even as investors piled into index funds, his fund beat the S.& P. 500 in each of the last nine years, the only fund to do so. (Peter Lynch's consecutive win streak lasted seven years.)    Last year, Value Trust returned 26.7 percent, compared with the S.& P.'s 21 percent gain.  Mr. Miller bet big a few years ago on technology stocks, including America Online, but last month said he now favors financial stocks, bonds, turnaround companies and small stocks.
lead_paragraph: Bill Miller did the near impossible -- again. The fund he manages, Legg Mason Value Trust, beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index in 1999. abstract: JUST as Amazon.com has, for better or worse, led millions of would-be entrepreneurs toward the e-commerce promised land, so too has the success of the Dell Computer Corporation led countless manufacturers to believe that their future success rides on the ability to sell directly to consumers over the Internet.    The benefits are manifest: tighter control of inventory, better information about customers and, most of all, a simpler distribution system with no retailers or distributors to inflate the price of the product.
lead_paragraph: JUST as Amazon.com has, for better or worse, led millions of would-be entrepreneurs toward the e-commerce promised land, so too has the success of the Dell Computer Corporation led countless manufacturers to believe that their future success rides on the ability to sell directly to consumers over the Internet.

abstract: Michelle Shocked decided to write 30 new songs, enough music for two full sets, when she was booked in late November for three nights at the Bottom Line. Working with the guitarist Fiachna O'Braonain (of the Hothouse Flowers), she made her deadline for her first set on Thursday night, when she introduced more than a dozen songs in nearly as many styles.     Ms. Shocked, who still calls herself a folk singer, used to make a defiant show of eclecticism. Now, she and her fans jovially assume it.
lead_paragraph: Michelle Shocked decided to write 30 new songs, enough music for two full sets, when she was booked in late November for three nights at the Bottom Line. abstract: The top performer in New York City tournaments in 1999 was Marty Fleisher of Manhattan, who became Player of the Year, which takes all events into account, and Team Player of the Year. Both races were hard fought and were decided at the conclusion of the New York regional tournament last week. Adam Wildavsky placed second in both races, and Aaron Silverstein was in contention until the end.    The Long Island Player of the Year title was won, for the fourth straight year, by Mel Colchamiro of Merrick. The diagramed deal helped him win a Regional Knockout Teams at the Fall Nationals in Boston in November. He sat South, playing with his wife, Janet, who opened one heart. The one-spade response, in the partnership style, promised a five-card suit because they use the Flannery convention. A two-diamond opening would have shown four spades and five hearts, so the responder can conceal a four-card spade suit without risk of missing a 4-4 fit.

abstract: The initial working title was ''Tennessee,'' for the state from which the story's three main characters emerge, but now it is being referred to as ''Pearl Harbor,'' for the battle that forms the film's centerpiece. But it was not the titles that raised eyebrows when Walt Disney Studios recently announced its latest project with the producer Jerry Bruckheimer. It was the film's startling budget.    In an era of increased cost-cutting, when the common wisdom is that big-budget movies are having a harder time clicking, Disney's chairman, Joe Roth, approved Mr. Bruckheimer's budget of $145 million.

abstract: In the beige adobe house nestled against the snow-dusted Sangre de Cristo mountains, the lights are on, the phones have dial tones, the computer is online, and Edward Yourdon is reaching into a stack of cardboard boxes to hand a visitor a free copy of ''Time Bomb 2000.''    ''Best wishes, Ed Yourdon 1/1/ 2000,'' he inscribes in the flyleaf of a 630-page tome that sold 250,000 copies over the last two years. But the back cover conjures up a darkly different New Year's Day: ''Saturday, January 1, 2000: Suddenly, nothing works. Not your phones, not the cash machine, not even your fancy new VCR.''
lead_paragraph: In the beige adobe house nestled against the snow-dusted Sangre de Cristo mountains, the lights are on, the phones have dial tones, the computer is online, and Edward Yourdon is reaching into a stack of cardboard boxes to hand a visitor a free copy of ''Time Bomb 2000.''

abstract: In a battle that features elements of Greek drama, Katherine Betts, the 35-year-old editor in chief of Harper's Bazaar, must take on her former mentor, Anna Wintour, the editor in chief of Vogue magazine, as she reshapes Hearst Magazine's faltering 132-year-old fashion flagship. abstract: New York awoke on Saturday morning to discover that Times Square was still there. Perhaps the place should be checked every morning. Times Square, after all, is dedicated to the passing moment. When its moment passes, the spirits of place will not look back for long. But until that day comes, Times Square will remain the ultimate crossroads of space and time. These dimensions warped into a heightened configuration on Friday night, when thousands gathered to watch the ball drop as the Earth revolved New York City into the new millennium's dawn.    Even ephemeral things have a history, however. And the spectacle we see at Times Square first took shape in 1932 in the imagination of the German architect Oskar Nitzchke. That year, Nitzchke began to design a project he called la Maison de la Publicite (Publicity House). Intended for a site on the Champs-Elysees, the proposed building featured what people would later call a media wall. An immense crane, attached to the building's roof line, would be constantly at work, arranging and rearranging an ever-changing array of illuminated commercial signs deployed across a metal grid facade.
lead_paragraph: New York awoke on Saturday morning to discover that Times Square was still there. Perhaps the place should be checked every morning. Times Square, after all, is dedicated to the passing moment. When its moment passes, the spirits of place will not look back for long. But until that day comes, Times Square will remain the ultimate crossroads of space and time. These dimensions warped into a heightened configuration on Friday night, when thousands gathered to watch the ball drop as the Earth revolved New York City into the new millennium's dawn.

abstract: Is there a market for the words of authors ignored and scorned by traditional publishers? abstract: If not for Mike Richter, the Rangers' first game of the new century would have ended like so many others here have concluded in the last century -- with a Canadiens victory.    The Canadiens came into the game with a 188-56-37 record in Montreal against the Rangers, who were 1-12-3 here in their last 16 regular-season matchups. These Canadiens hardly resemble their storied forebears. Still, Richter had to be brilliant in goal to preserve a 2-2 tie after Rangers defenseman Sylvain Lefebvre scored -- a rarity for him -- 10 minutes 10 seconds into the third period.
lead_paragraph: If not for Mike Richter, the Rangers' first game of the new century would have ended like so many others here have concluded in the last century -- with a Canadiens victory.

abstract: What product blew off the shelves in '99? Cellular phones. What stock blew off the charts? Qualcomm, which owns valuable patents on a fast-growing cell phone technology and decided to jettison its phone-making operation during the year. The stock had surged twentyfold in late December when a PaineWebber analyst said it could double in the next 12 months, causing yet another buying frenzy. On the last day of the year, the stock split four for one, ending the year with a 2,619 percent gain. During the year, Qualcomm's market value soared from less than $4 billion, to $116 billion, after issuing more shares.

abstract: EVENTS    'Here's to Us'  By tradition, 30th anniversaries call for a gift of pearls. And figuratively, tradition will be observed when the 30th-anniversary season of the Lyrics and Lyricists series of songwriter salutes at the 92nd Street Y begins at 8 p.m. on Saturday. In performances also at 2:30 and 8 p.m. on Sunday and at 2 and 8 p.m. next Monday, the pearls are songs by Cy Coleman, whose classics include ''Witchcraft'' and and the Broadway scores for ''Sweet Charity''and ''Little Me.'' David Zippel, Mr. Coleman's lyricist on ''City of Angels,'' will be host and narrator. Performers will include Debbie Gravitte and her husband, Beau Gravitte. Information: (212) 996-1100.    Grand Reopening  With a program offering the premiere of a fanfare by Sir Harrison Birtwistle, the Cleveland Orchestra will return to Severance Hall in Cleveland at 9 p.m. on Saturday for the first time since March to celebrate the conclusion of a two-year, $36 million renovation and expansion of the hall. The project included restoration of the detailing and architecturally distinctive spaces like the lobby and grand foyer of the 2,000-seat auditorium, which opened in 1931. Information: (800) 686-1141.

abstract: The Legal Aid Society has sued the state to try to force it to provide residential treatment for severely mentally ill children who now are on waiting lists and languish in inappropriate settings for months, sometimes more than a year.    But the shortage of residential treatment facilities is just part of a much larger crisis in the delivery of services to thousands upon thousands of mentally ill children who are suffering grievously, and who often are a threat to themselves or others.

abstract: In a game that had the same winner and the same loser as the 1998 Orange Bowl, if not the same national championship implications, Nebraska overpowered and wore down Tennessee in the second half tonight for a 31-21 victory in the Fiesta Bowl.    After letting a 17-0 lead shrink to 3 points, the No. 3-ranked Cornhuskers (12-1) pounded out scoring drives of 96 and 99 yards in the second half and finished the game with 23 consecutive running plays. Nebraska totaled 321 yards on the ground, led by 108 from Dan Alexander, who scored Nebraska's first touchdown. Fullback Willie Miller added 87 yards, quarterback Eric Crouch 64 yards and Correll Buckhalter 59 yards.
lead_paragraph: In a game that had the same winner and the same loser as the 1998 Orange Bowl, if not the same national championship implications, Nebraska overpowered and wore down Tennessee in the second half tonight for a 31-21 victory in the Fiesta Bowl.

abstract: DEAR DIARY:    On the week before Christmas, Rockefeller Center was swarming with the usual holiday crowds. Onlookers, three people deep, hovered above the rink watching the skaters glide around the ice. Suddenly, in the center of the rink, a man dropped to one knee and held out his hand to a young woman who was looking down at him, smiling. A small circle of skaters formed around the couple. A hush fell over the hundreds of fascinated witnesses, including myself. We held our breath and watched. People began murmuring, ''He's proposing, he's proposing.'' While the murmuring was going on, the young woman must have said yes because the couple began hugging each other. Everyone, skaters and spectators, applauded. It was a great moment.   ALISON ONEACRE
lead_paragraph: DEAR DIARY:

abstract: Every evening, just at dusk, I carry two hay bales into the middle pasture. One goes into the high feed-bunk, the other into the feeder just below it. Each bale is bound by two strings of sisal baling twine. I cut the strings near their knots, which were tied by a mechanical baler sometime late last summer in a Massachusetts hayfield. The bale springs apart, and the hay falls into flakes. I coil the strings into a neat loop and put them in my pocket. There is at least one coil of twine in every jacket I own and another in the hip pocket of every pair of jeans. On this place, baling twine is the thread of life.     Not that it gets used for much. It ties down tarps and ties up tomato vines and rose canes. It piles up day by day in an empty grain sack or a cardboard box in the barn. The horses are easier to catch with a double length of twine-string, as my farming cousins called it, than with a proper halter, and the horses are also gentle enough to be led that way. I know ranch hands in Wyoming who never ride out without a loop of the stuff -- usually the orange plastic kind -- knotted to a saddle-string or a D-ring. It is hard to describe the emergency that only a length of baling twine would fix, but you would know it if you ever rode into one.
lead_paragraph: Every evening, just at dusk, I carry two hay bales into the middle pasture. One goes into the high feed-bunk, the other into the feeder just below it. Each bale is bound by two strings of sisal baling twine. I cut the strings near their knots, which were tied by a mechanical baler sometime late last summer in a Massachusetts hayfield. The bale springs apart, and the hay falls into flakes. I coil the strings into a neat loop and put them in my pocket. There is at least one coil of twine in every jacket I own and another in the hip pocket of every pair of jeans. On this place, baling twine is the thread of life.

abstract: A top assistant to Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, said today that it would be all but impossible for Mr. Putin to lose the presidential election tentatively set for March. For now, at least, no one seemed to disagree.    After cramming his first two days as acting president with campaign-style speeches, news conferences, a trip to a war zone and a chat with President Clinton, Mr. Putin kept away from cameras today.

abstract: Long ago, political parties had a heavy hand in picking their presidential nominees. Now, in most big states except New York, voters do the picking in primaries or political caucuses. Through an arcane system that requires even candidates who have qualified nationally for federal election funds to amass signatures and jump through qualifying hoops, New York's political parties have, by mutual legislative agreement, limited the candidates on their ballots to two Democrats, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, and as few as one Republican in some areas, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.    The Democrats have made it easier for candidates' names to appear on their ballot, requiring  a campaign to get only 5,000 valid signatures statewide, as opposed to about 20,000 for the Republicans.  But even the lesser requirement is onerous, undemocratic and outdated. New York's entire  ballot-qualification exercise ranks as a political throwback to the old party-boss days before voters could see and assess the various candidates on television. For that reason, states like California automatically add the names of those considered ''viable'' by the media. Some states include any candidate qualified for federal funds or ask for a modest filing fee. Unlike New York, these states want to offer voters a basic political right: the ability to choose among all available candidates for a given office.
lead_paragraph: Long ago, political parties had a heavy hand in picking their presidential nominees. Now, in most big states except New York, voters do the picking in primaries or political caucuses. Through an arcane system that requires even candidates who have qualified nationally for federal election funds to amass signatures and jump through qualifying hoops, New York's political parties have, by mutual legislative agreement, limited the candidates on their ballots to two Democrats, Vice President Al Gore and former Senator Bill Bradley, and as few as one Republican in some areas, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.

abstract: It is said the unexamined life is not worth living. But what about the examined life?    Once, you could have argued that there was a dearth of media coverage of the media. But that was before Brill's Content, before Matt Drudge, before the online ''magazines'' Slate and Salon began hammering away at the media on a daily and even hourly basis, before trade publications like The Hollywood Reporter started online editions and before the appearance of Mediagossip.com, a daily compilation of media stories from around the country. Even Editor and Publisher, the once-sleepy chronicle of the newspaper industry, is breathing with new life.
lead_paragraph: It is said the unexamined life is not worth living. But what about the examined life?

abstract: When Justin A. Volpe told a federal judge last month that a fellow police officer had been wrongly convicted of helping him brutalize Abner Louima in a Brooklyn station house, he cast renewed doubt on whether the legal system had identified the right man as his accomplice.     The second trial stemming from the attack opens today, and it may help shed light on the issue: Was it Charles Schwarz who held Mr. Louima down as he was attacked in a station house bathroom with a broken broomstick -- as the government claims and the jury found, by convicting him? Was the accomplice another officer, Thomas Wiese, as Mr. Volpe now maintains? Or did Mr. Volpe act alone on Aug. 9, 1997, as lawyers for the defendants in the second trial have said?
lead_paragraph: When Justin A. Volpe told a federal judge last month that a fellow police officer had been wrongly convicted of helping him brutalize Abner Louima in a Brooklyn station house, he cast renewed doubt on whether the legal system had identified the right man as his accomplice.

abstract: To Yolande George, winter means staying toasty warm indoors.  Though she has lived in New York for 13 years, she explained, she just can not get used to the biting winds and frigid temperatures, the layers of clothing and the pain in her joints. ''Every time it's wintertime,'' said Ms. George, who left Trinidad for Harlem, ''I get angry.''    But yesterday, Ms. George did exactly what she avoids on most January days - she went outside to enjoy the weather.

abstract: In June, Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman of the Oracle Corporation, announced that the company would reinvent itself as an e-business -- a company that uses the power of the Internet in every aspect of its operations. He set a goal of reducing annual costs by $1 billion in 12 to 18 months.    At the time, many analysts brushed off the announcement as more hyperbole from a chief executive known for same. But as the months passed, it became clear that Mr. Ellison was putting his money where his mouth is -- and reaping some early returns on the investment. In the quarter ended Nov. 30, Oracle exceeded Wall Street's earnings estimates, in large part because of a 5.5 percent gain in profit margin that the company attributed to cost-cutting.
lead_paragraph: In June, Lawrence J. Ellison, the chairman of the Oracle Corporation, announced that the company would reinvent itself as an e-business -- a company that uses the power of the Internet in every aspect of its operations. He set a goal of reducing annual costs by $1 billion in 12 to 18 months.

abstract: The Clinton administration has urged the Supreme Court not to hear an appeal in a discrimination case brought on behalf of hundreds of H.I.V.-positive prisoners in the Alabama prison system, where all inmates with the virus that causes AIDS are barred from educational and recreational programs and even from religious services where they might mix with the general prison population.    If the court takes the administration's advice, it will leave intact a sweeping ruling that bars these inmates from more than 70 programs available to other prisoners, including work-release programs that can shorten their incarceration.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton administration has urged the Supreme Court not to hear an appeal in a discrimination case brought on behalf of hundreds of H.I.V.-positive prisoners in the Alabama prison system, where all inmates with the virus that causes AIDS are barred from educational and recreational programs and even from religious services where they might mix with the general prison population.

abstract: Many Miami Dolphins players and coaches spent early this afternoon staring at the television while sprawled about a stadium lounge in the bowels of Fed Ex Field, and they were not watching cartoons. Miami needed help from other teams in other games to get into the playoffs, and their coming contest against Washington was basically irrelevant to those postseason dreams. So it was understandable that Coach Jimmy Johnson was snuggled up to the set as if he were watching home videos.    Miami needed for either Seattle to lose to the Jets or for Kansas City to lose to Oakland in early games to get in. Both things happened, and the Dolphins knew they were in the playoffs before taking the field against Washington.
lead_paragraph: Many Miami Dolphins players and coaches spent early this afternoon staring at the television while sprawled about a stadium lounge in the bowels of Fed Ex Field, and they were not watching cartoons. Miami needed help from other teams in other games to get into the playoffs, and their coming contest against Washington was basically irrelevant to those postseason dreams. So it was understandable that Coach Jimmy Johnson was snuggled up to the set as if he were watching home videos.

abstract: THE FAN-MAKER'S INQUISITION  By Rikki Ducornet  212 pages. Henry Holt. $22.      ''A fan is like the thighs of a woman,'' is the first line of ''The Fan-Maker's Inquisition,'' Rikki Ducornet's new novel, and that simile summons up contradictory reactions. For one thing it is a bit of a stretch, and that gives it a contrived, even a smug quality. But it is also a provocative image, the fan that opens and closes like Ms. Ducornet's story itself, which soon unfolds into a knowing, smoldering historical tableau. By the end of this novel, which is set in revolutionary France, Ms. Ducornet has taken us on a moral and philosophical journey through two highly fraught epochs.
lead_paragraph: THE FAN-MAKER'S INQUISITION

abstract: Mike Holmgren walked toward the middle of Giants Stadium yesterday after his team had been tripped, 19-9, by the Jets, mumbled something to the Jets coaches, and walked away, unsure where his final steps would lead. He made his way to the locker room, to his players, and told them they were lousy in execution but great in effort.     Then Holmgren did what plenty of football fans did yesterday afternoon -- he plopped in front of a TV and sorted through the menu of games that would decide which teams were in the playoffs.
lead_paragraph: Mike Holmgren walked toward the middle of Giants Stadium yesterday after his team had been tripped, 19-9, by the Jets, mumbled something to the Jets coaches, and walked away, unsure where his final steps would lead. abstract: Gennie Phillips, president of the Helpline Soul Rescue Ministry in Brooklyn, said that until two years ago, her group had never fixed up a house or renovated an apartment building.    But that lack of expertise did not stop the group from joining in a federal urban renewal program and buying more than 100 buildings to renovate. And it did not stop the federal government from guaranteeing $20 million that Helpline borrowed to finance the renovations.

abstract: The merger last year of Doubleclick and Abacus Direct was the first official marriage of companies that gathered information about people's activities online and off line. Doubleclick, which serves advertisements on thousands of Internet sites and monitors users' activities on those sites, could suddenly combine that information with catalog purchases tracked by Abacus.    Previously Doubleclick had ignored the personal identity of Web surfers, but by using information about users' offline purchases, it can charge higher ad rates. Since the merger was announced in June, Internet advertising companies have forged ahead with efforts to identify people on Web sites, find out more about their offline lives, and show them ads that match that information.
lead_paragraph: The merger last year of Doubleclick and Abacus Direct was the first official marriage of companies that gathered information about people's activities online and off line. Doubleclick, which serves advertisements on thousands of Internet sites and monitors users' activities on those sites, could suddenly combine that information with catalog purchases tracked by Abacus.

abstract: New Year's Eve comes smack in the busy middle of the Metropolitan Opera's season. So in most years the company has tended to click on the default mode in its organizational brain and just present the traditional work for the occasion, ''Die Fledermaus.'' Strauss's popular operetta offers a frothy score, plenty of opportunities for inserted comedic shtick and a grand, silly, sentimental party scene at Prince Orlofsky's palace as its entire middle act. Naturally, surprise guests turn up at the party and sing something. That's all part of the musty tradition.    Of course this New Year's Eve was the countdown of all countdowns. Might the Met have thought a little harder and come up with something fresh?

abstract: ELLIOTT-Timothy Charles Venn. Tim, passed away at home in Manhattan, early morning December 30 after a short but courageous battle with pancreatic cancer, at age 51. Born in Dorset, England, educated at Harrow School, Cambridge University, and in the far flung reaches of the world, Tim's humor and selfless concern for others remained intact until the end. While several global advertising agencies have lost a rare breed of leader, the world has lost an irreplaceable eccentric and lover of life far too soon. May his generosity, spirit and enthusiasm be remembered with more than the glasses that will be raised to him. Tim is survived by Daryl, his wife and partner in life's great adventures, family members in England and Canada and a legion of godchildren, friends and admirers around the world. A service will be held in celebration of his life on Friday, January 7th at 1:PM at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave and 66th. Contributions in his memory in lieu of flowers can be made to Visiting Nurse Service of NY, 1250 Broadway, 4th Flr, NY, NY 10001, care of Renee Martinez or The Lustgarten Foundation for Cancer Research, P.O. Box 2141, New York, New York 10116.

abstract: Half awake in the dawn, I knew I was in a bedroom in Berlin. In the bed an attractive young German woman was having a bad dream. She tossed and turned and uttered anguished cries. Suddenly I was in the dream. A U-boat with a knight's head on the conning tower was cruising through the Atlantic's gray depths. Around it exploded a half-dozen depth charges. The boat tilted on its side and began to sink.    Now I -- and the woman -- were inside the boat, watching the drowning men gasp for a last breath as the water rose around them. We swam through the chaos until we reached the control room, where the captain, the woman's husband, awaited death with stoic defiance.
lead_paragraph: Half awake in the dawn, I knew I was in a bedroom in Berlin. In the bed an attractive young German woman was having a bad dream. She tossed and turned and uttered anguished cries. The boat tilted on its side and began to sink.

abstract: And now, said Hungary one day late, let the millennial celebrations begin.     Not the worldwide ones, but rather those marking 1,000 years since Hungary became a nation. And what a nation: a windswept battlefield settled by Siberian horsemen on the doorstep of Europe, a vast plain whose borders have always been up for grabs, a history of angry subjugation at the hands of Ottomans, Austrians and Soviets, a disenfranchised nobility scattered across the globe, and all of it linked by a language whose only living relative -- and not a close one at that -- is Finnish.
lead_paragraph: And now, said Hungary one day late, let the millennial celebrations begin.

abstract: How do you take a company known in part for its sleepy trade magazines like Soybean Digest and Lapidary Journal and transform it into a smoking hot new-media company?     Before Tom Rogers became the chief executive of Primedia last fall, the company was primarily known as a large publisher of special-interest and trade magazines. Apart from the most recognizable titles -- New York, Seventeen and Modern Bride -- the company publishes more than 100 niche magazines from American Baby to World War II, and also produces and distributes video products like Channel One and the Law Enforcement Television Network.
lead_paragraph: How do you take a company known in part for its sleepy trade magazines like Soybean Digest and Lapidary Journal and transform it into a smoking hot new-media company?

abstract: When Paul J. Maszczak was tapped more than three years ago to head his company's Year 2000 computer repairs, he recalled, ''I considered it the kiss of death.'' Instead of developing new software using the latest technology, he would be relegated to fixing programs written years or decades earlier.     But Mr. Maszczak now says that becoming Year 2000 manager at C. R. Bard Inc., a medical device manufacturer in Murray Hill, N.J., was one of the best moves in his 30-year career in data processing. The job lifted him out of the narrow confines of the information technology department, exposing him to all aspects of his company's business.
lead_paragraph: When Paul J. Maszczak was tapped more than three years ago to head his company's Year 2000 computer repairs, he recalled, ''I considered it the kiss of death.'' abstract: When they were hot, they were very, very hot. But when they were not, they were losers.    The story of the stock market in 1999 was of stocks that flew higher than at any time in the last decade. Enough of them soared that the major market indexes all closed the year at record highs. The best-performing stocks leaped not by hundreds, but by thousands of percentage points. Applying that standard, it was the year of the decade.
lead_paragraph: When they were hot, they were very, very hot. But when they were not, they were losers.

abstract: The Republican presidential candidates are all more or less calling for a foreign policy they see as reminiscent of President Ronald Reagan -- engaging with the world, but unilaterally, with a narrow interpretation of American national interests. And although the Republicans have criticized President Clinton as watering down United States influence by working through multilateral groups, Mr. Clinton recently shocked American allies by also seeming to embrace unilateralism: in Seattle, he backed off from firm support of the World Trade Organization.    Our current foreign policy debate is not over whether to retreat into isolationism, but over how we should relate to the rest of the world. Polls show that the large majority of Americans do not want to turn inward, but neither do they want to be the world's policeman. What is missing in the campaign rhetoric is any acknowledgment of something Ronald Reagan understood well: America's soft power.
lead_paragraph: The Republican presidential candidates are all more or less calling for a foreign policy they see as reminiscent of President Ronald Reagan -- engaging with the world, but unilaterally, with a narrow interpretation of American national interests. And although the Republicans have criticized President Clinton as watering down United States influence by working through multilateral groups, Mr. Clinton recently shocked American allies by also seeming to embrace unilateralism: in Seattle, he backed off from firm support of the World Trade Organization.
