abstract: Shankar Dayal Sharma, the emotional but decisive president of India in the turbulent years from 1992 to 1997, died on Dec. 26 in a hospital in New Delhi. He was 81 and lived in New Delhi.    A longtime member of the Congress Party, he was its president for a time. Dr. Sharma, whose doctorate was in law from Cambridge, was elected, with support from Congress and leftist groups, ninth president of India. That role is is largely ceremonial, though its powers include discretion in choosing a prime minister if no party has a parliamentary majority.
lead_paragraph: Shankar Dayal Sharma, the emotional but decisive president of India in the turbulent years from 1992 to 1997, died on Dec. 26 in a hospital in New Delhi. He was 81 and lived in New Delhi.

abstract: If all the hype surrounding Oprah Winfrey is to be believed, everything that she touches turns to gold: she not only transforms humble Midwestern housewives into best-selling blockbuster novelists but when she appears on the cover of a magazine -- as she did on Vogue in 1998 -- the magazine is sure to be a brisk seller.    Hearst Magazines has taken that logic to the next step, and will introduce a lifestyle magazine licensed by Ms. Winfrey this spring. The magazine's editor in chief, Ellen Kunes, describes the still-unnamed project as ''a personal-growth guide for the next century.''
lead_paragraph: If all the hype surrounding Oprah Winfrey is to be believed, everything that she touches turns to gold: she not only transforms humble Midwestern housewives into best-selling blockbuster novelists but when she appears on the cover of a magazine -- as she did on Vogue in 1998 -- the magazine is sure to be a brisk seller.

abstract: There was a certain air of hopelessness about the Giants from beginning to end today, despondency coupled with a dazed bewilderment, an aura of despair that pursues the team into the off-season.    The Dallas Cowboys' 26-18 victory at Texas Stadium was just the final act in a spiritless, daylong dissolution for the Giants. It began with the Green Bay Packers' defeat of the Arizona Cardinals in an early afternoon game, a result that all but mathematically eliminated the Giants from playoff contention.

abstract: The soldiers in Russia's 74th Brigade call the pile of bricks and concrete on the outskirts of this Chechen town ''the white wall.'' The bulwark lies in the shadow of the Caucasus Mountains and marks one of the deepest lines of the Russian advance into southern Chechnya.    It is also a primary target for hundreds of rebels hiding in Chechnya's high country. Russian troops here are anticipating a major attack in the next few days. So are the Chechen residents of Avtury. Many are packing up and getting out.

abstract: State Senator Efrain Gonzalez Jr. of the Bronx decided to open a Washington office for a Hispanic legislators' association a few years ago, figuring that he would have little trouble raising the necessary $40,000. Following something of a tradition among black and Hispanic members of the New York Legislature, Mr. Gonzalez called a lobbyist for Philip Morris, and came away with the entire amount.    A colleague from the borough, Assemblywoman Gloria Davis, receives $5,000 annually from Philip Morris, the world's largest tobacco company, for a Thanksgiving meal for the poor in her predominantly black district. Seeking aid for a program to teach nonviolence to young people, Ms. Davis said that she raised $22,000 from another cigarette giant, R. J. Reynolds.

abstract: Two head coaches were dismissed, another resigned and his top assistant took charge, a playoff quarterback was benched, another is injured and was replaced, and a Pro Bowl tackle is injured and will miss the postseason in what evolved into a black-and-blue barrage of National Football League moves yesterday.    Pete Carroll of the New England Patriots and Ray Rhodes of the Green Bay Packers were dismissed after their teams failed to reach the playoffs. Bill Parcells resigned as the Jets' head coach and his longtime defensive coordinator, Bill Belichick, is the new Jets leader.
lead_paragraph: Two head coaches were dismissed, another resigned and his top assistant took charge, a playoff quarterback was benched, another is injured and was replaced, and a Pro Bowl tackle is injured and will miss the postseason in what evolved into a black-and-blue barrage of National Football League moves yesterday.

abstract: STONE-Morton D. died on January 2, 2000 at the age of 91. He leaves behind his beloved wife, Dorothy Stone, and his loving family, John Stone and Barbara Schaefer, Alice Stone Nakhimovsky, Alexander Nakhimovsky, Isaac and Sharon Nakhimovsky, and his dear brother Brandon D. Stone. A 1929 graduate of St. Johns Law School, he went on to serve his country in Europe during World War II, ending his service in the Judge Advocate's Office. As a practicing attorney for 53 years, with a concentration in real estate and then medical law, he became one of the founders of HIP. A tireless advocate for doctors in malpractice litigation, he went on to found the Group Council Mutual Insurance Company of Greater New York. His lifelong fascination with how things work included obtaining his ham radio license and a U.S. patent.
lead_paragraph: STONE-Morton D. died on January 2, 2000 at the age of 91. abstract: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that Bruce Teitelbaum, the man he has relied on in recent years to defend his administration and carry out many of his political orders, will manage his campaign if the mayor runs, as expected, for the United States Senate this year.    His afternoon announcement coincided with a carefully worded statement issued by Mr. Teitelbaum's lawyer saying that, according to federal prosecutors and the Brooklyn district attorney's office, Mr. Teitelbaum is ''presently neither a target nor a subject'' of a criminal investigation into the collapse of a Brooklyn building that killed a construction worker in November. The accident has stirred questions about City Hall's influence over building practices in the Orthodox Jewish section of Williamsburg.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that Bruce Teitelbaum, the man he has relied on in recent years to defend his administration and carry out many of his political orders, will manage his campaign if the mayor runs, as expected, for the United States Senate this year.

abstract: A 60's Image Maker Marches On      In the mid-1960's, Roman Polanski tried to set up David Bailey, the British fashion photographer, with a young French actress whose looks were not the kind to divide opinion. Her name was Catherine Deneuve, and at first, Mr. Bailey declined his friend's offer. ''She's not my type,'' he said. ''She's too short.''    Mr. Bailey eventually met Ms. Deneuve, who starred in Polanski's ''Repulsion,'' and married her. This was between long love affairs with Jean Shrimpton and Penelope Tree, women his camera turned into icons. Mr. Bailey was the original ''modelizer,'' to borrow a term from 1990's media parlance. He was Austin Powers, a character inspired by his exploits, with a toothbrush.
lead_paragraph: A 60's Image Maker Marches On

abstract: Bypassed for consideration as this season's national champion, Nebraska spent the 2000 Fiesta Bowl laying a foundation for the next national title by laying waste to Tennessee on Sunday night, 31-21.    ''This is a great step to propel us to next season,'' said Dan Alexander, whose 108 yards and a touchdown led a relentless Cornhusker running attack. Third-ranked Nebraska (12-1) amassed 321 yards, 238 in the second half, and ate up the final 7 minutes 25 seconds of the clock in a replay of its 42-17 manhandling of Tennessee in the 1998 Orange Bowl.
lead_paragraph: Bypassed for consideration as this season's national champion, Nebraska spent the 2000 Fiesta Bowl laying a foundation for the next national title by laying waste to Tennessee on Sunday night, 31-21.

abstract: LOEB-Anne-Marie (Nany), died peacefully at the age of 83 on December 27, in Bern, Switzerland. She was the beloved and devoted wife of the late Victor Loeb, cherished mother/mother-in-law of Marion Meyer-Robboy, Francois Loeb, Claire Loeb, Viviane Tobler, Sylvie Paraskevopoulos, the late Claude J. Meyer, Stanley Robboy, Ruth Loeb, Thomas Tobler, and Costas Paraskevopoulos. A sister and brother-in-law, Francoise and Maxence Meyer, also survive her. She is the beloved grandmother of eight, and great-grandmother of two. The funeral was held in Bern, Switzerland. Donations in her memory can be made to the Israel Museum in Jerusalem or the charity of your choice.

abstract: Ever wondered why tickets are sold out at the box office for a basketball game or a Broadway show, but ticket agencies seem to have a large supply? There is often a reason, says the New York State Attorney General's Office: bribery.    A continuing investigation by the office has found that ticket brokers use bribery to obtain tickets for Broadway shows, concerts and sporting events, tickets that should be available to the public at box office prices. The brokers are able to acquire hundreds of seats, creating a virtual stranglehold on the most-sought tickets, according to investigators.
lead_paragraph: Ever wondered why tickets are sold out at the box office for a basketball game or a Broadway show, but ticket agencies seem to have a large supply? There is often a reason, says the New York State Attorney General's Office: bribery.

abstract: With his commitment of credibility fulfilled, with his personal legacy secure, all that was left for Bill Parcells to do today was to honor Bill Belichick's service, and Leon Hess's trust. All that remained was for Parcells to let the clock run out, without fumbling the handoff of the Jets.    Parcells said, ''I coached as hard as I could, right to the end,'' and that included his giving Belichick the ball with the best chance of breaking away from Parcells's intimidating presence. Super Bowl musings aside, the timing on this play was perfect, after an 8-8 season that should not be difficult to improve on, and before the detested Robert Kraft could lure Belichick back to New England to replace the fired Pete Carroll.
lead_paragraph: With his commitment of credibility fulfilled, with his personal legacy secure, all that was left for Bill Parcells to do today was to honor Bill Belichick's service, and Leon Hess's trust. All that remained was for Parcells to let the clock run out, without fumbling the handoff of the Jets.

abstract: NYC & Company, the city's tourism bureau, which is run by one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's closest former advisers, announced a promotional campaign yesterday featuring the mayor in a series of radio commercials to be broadcast upstate. Democrats immediately criticized the advertisements as badly disguised taxpayer-financed commercials for Mr. Giuliani's unannounced Senate campaign.    The commercials, which begin, ''Hi, this is Mayor Rudy Giuliani and I wanted you to come to New York City this winter and paint the town red,'' are similar to ads promoting the city that the mayor has done for the last four years, but this is the first time they are to be broadcast upstate.
lead_paragraph: NYC & Company, the city's tourism bureau, which is run by one of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's closest former advisers, announced a promotional campaign yesterday featuring the mayor in a series of radio commercials to be broadcast upstate. Democrats immediately criticized the advertisements as badly disguised taxpayer-financed commercials for Mr. Giuliani's unannounced Senate campaign.

abstract: Nearly 30 years after the deadliest prison rebellion in American history, a federal judge in Rochester is expected to announce a settlement today giving compensation to the inmates who were beaten and tortured by law enforcement officers during the uprising at Attica.    As of late yesterday, there was no official word on the amount of the settlement, the number of inmates who may receive awards or other details. Lawyers involved in the negotiations said details would be announced at a hearing this morning before Judge Michael A. Telesca of Federal District Court.
lead_paragraph: Nearly 30 years after the deadliest prison rebellion in American history, a federal judge in Rochester is expected to announce a settlement today giving compensation to the inmates who were beaten and tortured by law enforcement officers during the uprising at Attica.

abstract: For the first time, Mississippi legislators will gather on Tuesday to choose the state's next governor, employing a provision rooted in the state's racially sundered history to settle a contemporary political deadlock.     Voters thought they would be the ones choosing a governor when they went to the polls on Nov. 2. But after the ballots were counted, Lt. Gov. Ronnie Musgrove had 49.5 percent of the vote, and Mike Parker, a former congressman, 48.6 percent, with the rest going to two other candidates. Because no candidate received a majority, the decision was left to the Mississippi House of Representatives, under a provision of the State Constitution, adopted in 1890.
lead_paragraph: For the first time, Mississippi legislators will gather on Tuesday to choose the state's next governor, employing a provision rooted in the state's racially sundered history to settle a contemporary political deadlock.

abstract: To the Editor:    I have a simple solution to the home health care shortage (news article, Jan. 3). Many temporary agencies that place home health aides in homes misclassify the workers as independent contractors, exempting these workers from minimum-wage and unemployment-compensation protections and preventing them from receiving Social Security benefits when they are ready to retire or become disabled themselves.

abstract: Trying to repair some of the damage to Coca-Cola's public image, the company's incoming chairman and chief executive, Douglas N. Daft, has been negotiating intensely with Carl H. Ware, the company's lone black senior vice president who in November announced his intention to leave the company, in hopes of persuading him to accept a high-profile job.     A person close to the situation said yesterday that Mr. Daft began the talks soon after he was named to succeed M. Douglas Ivester, who shocked the company and the business world last month by abruptly announcing his own resignation. The jobs under discussion for Mr. Ware, who is president of the company's Africa division, include ''expanded responsibilities,'' the person said.
lead_paragraph: Trying to repair some of the damage to Coca-Cola's public image, the company's incoming chairman and chief executive, Douglas N. Daft, has been negotiating intensely with Carl H. Ware, the company's lone black senior vice president who in November announced his intention to leave the company, in hopes of persuading him to accept a high-profile job.

abstract: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says that the next New York schools chancellor should be a good administrator and manager, not necessarily someone with experience as an educator -- ''the kind of person,'' he said, ''that could run a very, very complex business or multinational corporation.''    But the idea that the school system needs a manager is a straw man. Chancellors do not fail in New York because they don't have the management skills to cope with a large and complex system.
lead_paragraph: Mayor Rudolph Giuliani says that the next New York schools chancellor should be a good administrator and manager, not necessarily someone with experience as an educator -- ''the kind of person,'' he said, ''that could run a very, very complex business or multinational corporation.''

abstract: WALTZMAN-Stuart Alan, M.D., 63. Devoted and adoring husband to Dava, father to Michael, Howard and Lynn, grandfather to Robert, brother to Susan and beloved friend. A graduate of Cornell University, Class of 1957, and Chicago Medical School, Class of 1961, he trained in Psychiatry at Hillside Hospital of Long Island Jewish Medical Center and was commissioned as a Captain in the U.S. Army from 1965 through 1967. He was an accomplished and respected psychiatrist: A former Director of Liaison Psychiatry at Jacobi Hospital, a member of the faculty of the Department of Psychiatry at Albert Einstein College of Medicine, Attending Physician at Norwalk Hospital and a Private Practitioner for over 30 years in Westport, CT. He had an uncanny perception of people and a remarkable appreciation for life. He was a lover of sports, classical music, golden retrievers and the Florida Keys. His compassion, loyalty, intelligence, sense of humor and ability to use these traits to interact were a source of pleasure to all who were fortunate enough to have associated with him. To know him was to be enriched beyond comprehension. To have lost him will leave a vacuum never ending. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, January 5th, at 10 AM, in the Perkin Auditorium at Norwalk Hospital, Norwalk, CT. Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021.

Donations in his memory may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Box E, 1275 York Ave., NY NY 10021.

abstract: Magazine Publishers of America, New York, named two editorial executives to receive the 1999 Henry Johnson Fisher Award. They are Myrna Blyth, senior vice president, publishing director and editor in chief at The Ladies' Home Journal and More magazines, New York, part of the Meredith Publishing Group unit of the Meredith Corp., and Michael R. abstract: GAYNER-Dr. Irving C., Manhattan, formerly of Forest Hills, died on January 2 at age 87. Pre-deceased by his wife of 46 years, Esther Kasman Gayner, survived by his son Stephen, of New York City and Jay of San Francisco, and his grandchildren Samantha and Gillian. Practiced dentistry in East New York and Canarsie for 48 years. Served in the Second World War. A man of wit and wisdom, with a reverence for knowledge. abstract: Humana Inc., the troubled managed-care company, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $400 million to $500 million in the fourth quarter, the latest in a series of charges and one-time items. The latest charge will result in a loss for 1999, wiping out operating profits projected at 63 cents a share.     The write-off reflects disappointing results from Humana's 1997 purchase of the Physicians Corporation of America for $270 million in cash and $130 million in debt. Humana indicated that it would lower the value assigned to good will in the purchase, which suggests that the price, which was considered low at the time, was still too high.
lead_paragraph: Humana Inc., the troubled managed-care company, said yesterday that it would take a pretax charge of $400 million to $500 million in the fourth quarter, the latest in a series of charges and one-time items. The latest charge will result in a loss for 1999, wiping out operating profits projected at 63 cents a share.

abstract: South Korea's trade surplus widened 17 percent in December, as more shipments of semiconductors, automobiles and computers drove exports to a record for a third month. The trade surplus reached $2.9 billion from $2.5 billion in November, the Commerce, Industry and Energy Ministry said. The export boom -- fueled partly by the devaluation of the won in 1997 -- has allowed South Korea to rebound from its worst-ever recession in 1998. The trade surplus for all of 1999 fell to $24.5 billion from $39 billion in 1998.

abstract: SNYDER-Susan. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died Saturday, January 1, 2000 after a long and courageous battle with breast cancer, at age 53. Loving wife of Marc A. Snyder, mother of Rachel Snyder and Michael Snyder and daughter of Lee Krupnick and the late Samuel Krupnick of Saint Louis, MO.     SNYDER-Susan. We profoundly mourn the untimely death of our dear friend and colleague. Her loving exuberance remains strong in our hearts and minds. We pray that she may yet encounter a kinder and more gentle providence, and extend our most sincere sympathy to her beloved Mark, Michael, Rachel and the bereaved family. Lee and Ralph Kern
lead_paragraph: SNYDER-Susan. Of Scarsdale, N.Y. Died Saturday, January 1, 2000 after a long and courageous battle with breast cancer, at age 53. Loving wife of Marc A. Snyder, mother of Rachel Snyder and Michael Snyder and daughter of Lee Krupnick and the late Samuel Krupnick of Saint Louis, MO.

abstract: The world's top maker of household appliances by sales, Electrolux, said it might lose about 240 million kronor, or $28 million, because of unauthorized currency trades by an employee. Many companies use currency transactions to protect earnings made overseas from fluctuations in foreign exchange. The employee, whom Electrolux declined to identify, was ''outside his authority'' because he was betting on the direction of many currencies, said Lars Goran Johansson, a spokesman. Electrolux, a Swedish concern, became aware of the trades last week.
lead_paragraph: The world's top maker of household appliances by sales, Electrolux, said it might lose about 240 million kronor, or $28 million, because of unauthorized currency trades by an employee. abstract: There are hardly two more incompatible words in the English language than ''bride'' and ''fashion.''    The former makes you think of hideous gobs of fattening lace, while the latter brings to mind minimalist shrouds, eccentric veils and a mother-in-law weeping softly into her hankie. ''Here Comes the Bride'' does not go with sheer Helmut Lang bloomers any more than a Prada nylon slip goes with a full slap of makeup and an illusion veil. It's bizarre, it's tricky -- it's the sartorial equivalent of saying, ''I do,'' backward.
lead_paragraph: There are hardly two more incompatible words in the English language than ''bride'' and ''fashion.''

abstract: St. John's had looked forward to last night's game against Pittsburgh as a measuring stick in the Big East, a league that began conference play last night with no member having a losing record.     But the rulers were packed away early at Alumni Hall, made as obsolete as an abacus by an overmatched and overwhelmed Pittsburgh team. The undersized and undermanned Panthers merely provided warm bodies for what amounted to a controlled -- and not very, at that -- scrimmage for the Red Storm, as they thrashed Pittsburgh, 82-58.

abstract: At first glance, Natalia Sarygina doesn't look like much of a glass-ceiling smasher. She wears a sequined minidress to work, is pleased with her $25,000-a-year salary and has a conventional take on gender roles, in Russian-laced English.     ''I think man is a man, he's more strong,'' she says. ''A woman? It's a woman,'' she shrugs, applying thick makeup in her stamp-size trailer in Manhattan.

abstract: As scientists look back at all the discoveries made in the 1990's, the so-called Decade of the Brain, one finding stands out as the most startling and, for many scientists, the most difficult to accept: people are not necessarily born with all the brain cells they will ever have.     In fact, from birth through late adolescence, the brain appears to add billions of new cells, literally constructing its circuits out of freshly made neurons as children and teenagers interact with their environments. In adulthood, the process of adding new cells slows down but does not stop. Mature circuits appear to be maintained by new cell growth well into old age.
lead_paragraph: As scientists look back at all the discoveries made in the 1990's, the so-called Decade of the Brain, one finding stands out as the most startling and, for many scientists, the most difficult to accept: people are not necessarily born with all the brain cells they will ever have.

abstract: Waking up in the year 2000 to face nothing worse than the debris in Times Square, some may have decided that Washington had hyped the prospect of an attack by Osama bin Laden and his allies beyond reason.    But that conclusion is wrong. The danger posed by Mr. bin Laden and like-minded radical Islamists will not fade into memory along with fears of Y2K power failures and sewer backups. On the contrary: aggressive intelligence and law enforcement efforts by many countries may have precluded attacks over the last few weeks -- as in Jordan -- but the forces now personified in Western minds by Mr. bin Laden are here to stay.
lead_paragraph: Waking up in the year 2000 to face nothing worse than the debris in Times Square, some may have decided that Washington had hyped the prospect of an attack by Osama bin Laden and his allies beyond reason.

abstract: In a televised speech to the nation, South Korean President Kim Dae-jung proposed that Seoul and Pyongyang open discussions on forming an inter-Korean economic community. Mr. Kim proposed a joint study to establish an economic community between the two Koreas because both stand to gain from economic cooperation. ''I hope that North Korean officials will respond favorably,'' he said. There was no immediate response from North Korea.     Samuel Len

abstract: For 65 million years, the fossil triceratops now displayed at the National Museum of Natural History in Washington lay protected in its rocky cocoon, immune to the ravages of the outer world. abstract: EUROPE    BRITAIN: NAZI SUSPECT DEPORTED -- Britain ordered the deportation to Australia of Konrad Kalejs, 86, suspected of being a Nazi death squad officer responsible for the murder of up to 30,000 Jews, Communists and Gypsies in Latvia in World War II. Mr. Kalejs, an Australian citizen of Latvian descent, was found living in a retirement home in England. The police said they had no grounds for arresting Mr. Kalejs and Australia said it had already decided not to prosecute him.   Sarah Lyall (NYT)    FRANCE: OUSTED PRESIDENT ARRIVES -- The former President of the Ivory Coast, Henri Konan Bedie, who was ousted in a military coup on Dec. 24, arrived in Paris. He had been staying in Togo since the coup and flew into Orly airport aboard the Togolese presidential jet. Togolese officials said Mr. Bedie, who has an apartment in Paris, is expected to take up residence there.   Suzanne Daley (NYT)

abstract: Mediocrity would be a step up for the Rangers right now.    The Rangers' streak without a victory was extended to seven games by Pierre Turgeon and the St. Louis Blues, who won by 5-2 last night at Madison Square Garden. Turgeon extended his point streak to 15 games with a picture-perfect assist before delivering the backbreaking goal at 14 minutes 40 seconds of the third period to give the Blues an insurmountable 4-2 lead. The streak ties Turgeon with Pittsburgh's Jaromir Jagr for the longest in the National Hockey League this season.
lead_paragraph: Mediocrity would be a step up for the Rangers right now.

abstract: Percy Ellsworth was stuffing his belongings into a garbage bag, searching through the piles that filled his locker for a souvenir, a reminder of his time with the Giants. Today, he was still a Giant but was well aware that it might be the last time that he, and many of his teammates, set foot in the Giants' locker room.    Ellsworth, a free safety, is an unrestricted free agent, and he figures to draw interest from teams based on his six interceptions this season. It is believed that his price tag is likely to venture into a range the Giants will not match, especially with last year's first-round draft pick, Shaun Williams, waiting his turn behind Ellsworth.
lead_paragraph: Percy Ellsworth was stuffing his belongings into a garbage bag, searching through the piles that filled his locker for a souvenir, a reminder of his time with the Giants. Today, he was still a Giant but was well aware that it might be the last time that he, and many of his teammates, set foot in the Giants' locker room.

abstract: OPPENHEIMER-Kathe. Born December 25, 1900. Died December 31, 1999. Beloved mother of Axel (deceased), Stephen, Ruth, Andrea and Coco. Studied law at University of Munich, married Alfred Jarislowsky. Widowed 1929; took charge of a major German industrial group including an investment bank, gradually sold off major items during the Hitler days, remarried Heinz Oppenheimer and emigrated to Holland, then via France to the U.S. in March 1941. She leaves 13 beloved grandchildren and five great grandchildren. There will be a gathering of friends and family Friday, January 14th, 1-4PM at her home. Contributions to The Helen Keller Foundation.
lead_paragraph: OPPENHEIMER-Kathe. Born December 25, 1900. Died December 31, 1999. Beloved mother of Axel (deceased), Stephen, Ruth, Andrea and Coco. abstract: Haley Moran-Wollens is not an elite athlete. She is a 13-year-old who, like lots of other teenagers, wants to be fit. And, like a growing number of teenagers whose parents can afford it, she has a personal trainer.    In her case, the trainer is Rodica Vranceanu, who charges $75 an hour for after school workouts at Radu Physical Culture, a gym in Midtown Manhattan.

abstract: USDAN-Selma G. 75. Passed away unexpectedly December 28, 1999. With overwhelming grief and sadness, we announce the death of our beloved mother and best friend, Selma Goldfein Usdan. She touched all who knew her by her graciousness, keen intelligence and extraordinary degree of competence. Born in, and a lifelong resident of Englewood and Fort Lee, NJ she was an employee of Drexel Burnham Lambert and its successor Burnham Securities, Inc. for the last 34 years. She was the consummate professional. Her outward gentleness, tact and reserve masked a steely determination and ability to deal with all kinds of people who crossed her path. This same determination enabled her to graduate from St. Peter's College at age 59. In addition to her son, Jim, daughter, Adrienne, and daughter-in-law, Lisa, she is survived by cousins, nieces, nephews, and extended family, all of whom respected and loved her. Her death leaves us with a hole in our hearts. Her tastefulness, and appreciation of the fine and performing arts was well known to all who knew her, particularly her love of the opera. Private cremation. Memorial service will be held Tuesday, January 4, at 6 pm at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 81st & Madison in Manhattan. Rest in peace, mom. We will love you, cherish your memory and miss you always. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to U JA/Federation or the Metropolitan Opera Society.
lead_paragraph: USDAN-Selma G. 75. Passed away unexpectedly December 28, 1999. With overwhelming grief and sadness, we announce the death of our beloved mother and best friend, Selma Goldfein Usdan. abstract: During the preseason, Stephon Marbury shared his philosophy on playing with pain. He talked of fighting through a fractured toe during his second season with the Minnesota Timberwolves in order to reach his goal of playing in every regular-season game.     ''Every day, all I said to myself was: 'I'm going 82. I'm going 82,' Marbury said in October. Being hurt is all mental. You can be hurt and still play. If you're injured, you can't play. I don't deal with hurt. I don't deal with pain. I just play. I've gotten to a point where pain doesn't bother me anymore. I'm just out there hoopin'. You love playing basketball and when you're hurt and you're out there ballin', the pain goes away and you don't feel it until after the game.''
lead_paragraph: During the preseason, Stephon Marbury shared his philosophy on playing with pain. He talked of fighting through a fractured toe during his second season with the Minnesota Timberwolves in order to reach his goal of playing in every regular-season game.

abstract: The Bank of France governor, Jean-Claude Trichet, said France's gross domestic product should rise 3 percent in 2000. The growth should be followed by a further reduction in unemployment, he said. The French government has said gross domestic product should rise by 2.3 percent in 1999 and by between 2.6 percent and 3 percent in 2000. The French unemployment rate fell to 10.8 percent in November from 11 percent in October.
lead_paragraph: The Bank of France governor, Jean-Claude Trichet, said France's gross domestic product should rise 3 percent in 2000. The French unemployment rate fell to 10.8 percent in November from 11 percent in October.

abstract: It was an orderly and, by all accounts, peaceful transition of power in the Nassau County Legislature today as the Democrats were sworn in to become the majority party in this overwhelmingly Republican county for the first time in memory.    But even amid the cheers and induction festivities, with schoolchildren leading the Pledge of Allegiance and a Police Department brass band playing lively versions of familiar songs, the problems of Nassau County's lingering budget crisis were never far below the surface.
lead_paragraph: It was an orderly and, by all accounts, peaceful transition of power in the Nassau County Legislature today as the Democrats were sworn in to become the majority party in this overwhelmingly Republican county for the first time in memory.

abstract: To the Editor:    An article Dec. 28 reports that leading scientists are explaining the mysteries of autism. We wish we shared their confidence, but we cannot.    The scientists quoted believe autism is a genetic condition, despite evidence that autism has risen 273 percent in a decade. Genetics cannot explain an epidemic. Yet these ''experts'' ignore the emerging data. That is bad science.

abstract: Smokers who think a history of depression means that they will have a harder time quitting are wrong, researchers from Rhode Island have found, but giving up cigarettes will not necessarily make them any happier.    Their new study runs counter to earlier research that found that people with depression had more trouble cutting back or quitting smoking.
lead_paragraph: Smokers who think a history of depression means that they will have a harder time quitting are wrong, researchers from Rhode Island have found, but giving up cigarettes will not necessarily make them any happier.

abstract: For most people, it is enough to know that one second is the sixtieth part of a minute, which is one-sixtieth of an hour, which is one twenty-fourth of the time it takes the Earth to make one complete revolution.     But nature is not nearly so tidy. All kinds of factors constantly distort the standards by which ordinary people measure time, and something far more accurate than the Earth's rotation rate is needed to time such split-second events as course corrections for interplanetary space probes.
lead_paragraph: For most people, it is enough to know that one second is the sixtieth part of a minute, which is one-sixtieth of an hour, which is one twenty-fourth of the time it takes the Earth to make one complete revolution.

abstract: One night recently, when I was on call in the emergency room at my hospital, paramedics wheeled in an elderly woman on a stretcher at 2 a.m. She was having severe chest pain, which an EKG immediately confirmed was a serious heart attack.    The E.R. sprang into action. Doctors whisked her into a treatment room, put her on a monitor, placed an oxygen mask over her face, and began an IV drip of nitroglycerin. (The paramedics had already given her an aspirin.) Though in pain, she was alert, clear-headed and quiet. The only indication of an emergency was in the buzz of the many doctors and nurses around her.
lead_paragraph: One night recently, when I was on call in the emergency room at my hospital, paramedics wheeled in an elderly woman on a stretcher at 2 a.m. She was having severe chest pain, which an EKG immediately confirmed was a serious heart attack.

abstract: An investigation ordered by City Hall has found that a major beneficiary of a program intended to help entrepreneurs outside the old-boy network is a company run by a white former union official and his sons.     Like many other big cities, Chicago reserves 25 percent of its contracts for businesses run by women or members of racial minorities. One of the big winners under the set-aside program has been a janitorial business, Windy City Maintenance, which lists its chief as Patricia Green. The city awarded the company tens of millions of dollars in contracts during the 90's.
lead_paragraph: An investigation ordered by City Hall has found that a major beneficiary of a program intended to help entrepreneurs outside the old-boy network is a company run by a white former union official and his sons.

abstract: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on the first trading day of the new year. As investor fears about the Year 2000 problem eased, they were replaced with a new one: that the Federal Reserve will begin raising interest rates aggressively.    Bonds came under pressure early, falling victim to the selling of issues bought as a safe haven before the changeover to 2000, sending yields to their highest levels in more than two years. Yields inched higher when the National Association of Purchasing Management's index of factory activity showed it had expanded for the 11th month in a row, and an index of prices paid by manufacturers rose.
lead_paragraph: Treasury prices fell sharply yesterday on the first trading day of the new year. As investor fears about the Year 2000 problem eased, they were replaced with a new one: that the Federal Reserve will begin raising interest rates aggressively.

abstract: No Parting Words For the 1900's      The New Yorker magazine ended the 1900's without saying ''Greetings, Friends'' one last time. ROGER ANGELL, a writer at The New Yorker who usually builds a page-filling rhyme around well-known names, let 1999 slip away without publishing an installment for the last year of the last decade of the last century of the last millennium -- or whatever last year was, since post-holiday, post-hangover purists insist that the milestone celebrated over the weekend was no more than two of those four.    ''It was Roger's choice not to do it last year,'' PERRI DORSET, a spokeswoman for The New Yorker, said yesterday. ''The year was uninspiring for Roger.''
lead_paragraph: No Parting Words For the 1900's

abstract: LIPSHIE-Geraldine On January 3, 2000. Beloved wife of Norman. Cherished daughter of Sydell Ballon. Loving mother of Greg, Tamara, Cara, Amy and Beth. Dear sister of Lois and adored Bubby to Madeleine, Claire, Melissa, William, Lila and Aaron. Services Tuesday 12:30pm at ''Riverside'', 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave. Contributions may be made in her memory to Parkinson Disease Foundation.     LIPSHIE-Geraldine. The friends and supporters of Colel ChabadLubavitch mourn the passing of our long-time friend, supporter and past guest of honor Geraldine Lipshie. A true woman of valor with the extraordinary Jewish values of giving and sharing, beloved wife of our very dear friend, leader and supporter Norman Lipshie who brought Colel Chabad to new heights. We send condolences to Norman, to the children Greg, Beth, Amy, Tamara, Cara and grandchildren. May they be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Sholom Duchman, Director Colel Chabad     LIPSHIE-Geraldine. Agriprocessors, Inc. and all its affiliates send condolences to our long-time good friend, Mr. Norman Lipshie. Through whose guidance our companies have attained great heights, on the passing of his noble wife, Geraldine Lipshie. Together with you we will miss Geraldine..who was much more than a friend. May you be comforted amongst the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Mr. & Mrs. Avraham A. Rubashkin Mr. & Mrs. Sholom M. Rubashkin Mr. & Mrs. Heshy Rubashkin Mr. & Mrs. Yossi Rubashkin Mr. & Mrs. Moshe Rubashkin     LIPSHIE - Geraldine.Congregation Emanu-El of the City of New York records with deep sorrow the death of our cherished member, Geraldine Lipshie. To her family and loved ones we express our profound sympathy. May beautiful memory bring comfort to those who mourn her passing. David E. Marrus, President Herbert C. Bernard, Secretary     LIPSHIE-Geraldine.Dear Geraldine, June will never be the same again. We will all miss you desperately. Rest in peace. Love, June Babies     LIPSHIE-Geraldine. abstract: NEUHOFF-John R. Of New York, New York, and Annapolis, MD, on December 28th, 1999, at age 75. Beloved husband of 50 years to Mary Hunter Neuhoff. Devoted father fo Christopher of New York, NY, Elizabeth Neuhoff Doughty (Richard) of Arnold, MD, Jerome (Katherine) of New York, New York, Cortland (Leslie Greene Bowman) of Winterthur, DE, and John (Patricia) of New York, NY. Adoring grandfather to Cara, Haley & Maya. Dear brother of Roger A. Neuhoff. Grateful to Rosetta Holmes, faithful helper for over 40 years. His love will remain in our hearts always. May his spirit soar. Services and burial are private. In lieu of flowers, your kind thoughts will be appreciated.     NEUHOFF-John. How we'll miss our dear friend John. We loved him. Our heart goes out to Taffy and the family. Suzanne and Shelly
lead_paragraph: NEUHOFF-John R. Of New York, New York, and Annapolis, MD, on December 28th, 1999, at age 75. Beloved husband of 50 years to Mary Hunter Neuhoff. abstract: The Clinton administration's achievement in guiding the nation through the perils of Y2K is a little like Mayor Rudy Giuliani's accomplishment in bringing down New York City's crime rate. It's very nice, but it would look even better if other people hadn't managed to do the same thing with less hysteria.    Our first challenge in the new millennium is deciding how to respond to the remarkable ease of the transition. Everybody worried that all those zeroes would cause computer crashes around the world. Nuclear power plants might explode, missiles might launch themselves, water and electricity shut down. There hasn't been so much disaster preparedness since the bomb shelter era. Now a lot of people are sitting around with two years' supply of peanut butter on hand and Sears is charging a premium to take back those generators.
lead_paragraph: The Clinton administration's achievement in guiding the nation through the perils of Y2K is a little like Mayor Rudy Giuliani's accomplishment in bringing down New York City's crime rate. It's very nice, but it would look even better if other people hadn't managed to do the same thing with less hysteria.

abstract: Agis Salpukas, a reporter for The New York Times who covered business news for much of his career, died yesterday. He was 60 and lived in Tenafly, N.J.    His body was found in the Hudson River off Manhattan, said Ellen Borakove, a spokeswoman for the New York City medical examiner. He was pronounced dead at 5:50 a.m. by the Emergency Medical Service.

abstract: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation and EOG Resources Inc. said yesterday that they had exchanged oil and natural-gas fields in the United States to cut costs and increase production. Occidental, the ninth-biggest United States oil company, received fields in California that produce about 12 million cubic feet of gas a day. It also got properties in the western Gulf of Mexico that produce 26 million cubic feet of gas equivalent a day. They are adjacent to fields Occidental already owns. EOG received properties in eastern Texas that are next to fields it owns. Occidental's shares fell 81.25 cents, to $20.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange, while EOG, formerly the Enron Oil and Gas Company, fell $2.0625, to $15.50.

abstract: Lycos Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to acquire a 14 percent stake in the Internet Commerce Services Corporation, a privately held provider of software and services for operators of e-commerce sites. Internet Commerce Services, or iCOMS, will provide support for Lycos's LycoShop online shopping Web site. Terms were not disclosed. Lycos, based in Waltham, Mass., operates Lycos.com, one of the most widely used Internet portals and search engines. The stock of Lycos rose $5.625 a share, to $85.1875, in Nasdaq trading.
